1201 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Brookins v. State


No. 22979


Supreme Court of Georgia


221 Ga. 181; 144 S.E.2d 83; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 415


June 14, 1965, Submitted  
July 8, 1965, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 26, 1965.


PRIOR HISTORY: Motion to quash indictment; constitutional question. Crisp Superior Court. Before Judge Horne.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant excepted to a judgment of the Superior Court of Crisp County (Georgia), which denied his motion to quash the indictment and to quash the array of a traverse jurors. Defendant contended that Negroes were systematically excluded from the selection of the grand jury and the traverse jury in violation of the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the United States Constitution.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court held that the trial court properly denied defendant's motion to quash the indictment and the challenge to the array. The court found that the jury commissioners succeeded in fulfilling their duty to familiarize themselves fairly with the qualifications of the eligible jurors of the county without regard to race and color. There was no evidence of a studied attempt to include or exclude a specified number of Negroes. On the contrary, there was a studied and forthright attempt to review the names of all prospective jurors, Negroes and whites, and include or exclude them as jurors according to their qualifications as individuals and not as members of a racial group. The court held that Ga. Code Ann. §§ 59-106, 92-6307, which required that the names of grand jurors were to be chosen from the tax digest and that the names of whites and Negroes were placed in separate places in the tax digest, respectively, were not violative of the 14th Amendment of the United States Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1202 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Vort v. Westbrook


No. 22885


Supreme Court of Georgia


221 Ga. 39; 142 S.E.2d 813; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 371


March 9, 1965, Argued  
May 10, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for damages; constitutional question. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Tanksley.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant father sought review of a judgment from the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which overruled the father's demurrer to the action for damages that was filed by plaintiff injured person.


OVERVIEW: The injured person filed an action against the father. The trial court overruled the father's demurrer to the action. The court reversed the trial court's judgment. Under Ga. Code Ann. § 105-113, the father was liable for the wilful and wanton acts of vandalism of his minor child that resulted in injury or damage to the person or property of another. The court held that the injured person did not have a cause of action against the father because the injured person had sustained bodily injuries only; the injured person had not sustained property damages. The court held that the term "vandalism" applied only to acts that resulted in an injury to property, not to bodily injuries that were unaccompanied by injuries to property. Finally, the court refused to consider the father's attack on the constitutionality of § 105-113 because § 105-113 was not applicable to the father and therefore, his rights were not affected by it.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment, which overruled the father's demurrer to the action for damages that was filed by the injured person.

 

1203 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Stephens v. Moran


No. 22932


Supreme Court of Georgia


221 Ga. 4; 142 S.E.2d 845; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 366


April 13, 1965, Argued  
May 6, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge McKenzie.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant commissioners sought review of a judgment from the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which granted plaintiff applicant's petition for a writ of mandamus that sought to compel the commissioners to regulate pursuant to 1937-38 Ga. L. 1937-38, Ex. Sess., p. 103 due to the commissioner's denial of his application for a liquor license.


OVERVIEW: The applicant filed a writ of mandamus that sought to compel the commissioners to regulate pursuant to 1937-38 Ga. L. Ex. Sess., p. 103 due to the commissioners denial of his application for a liquor license. The commissioners contended that although the municipality had adopted regulations that provided for grants of liquor licenses pursuant to that statute, they had been repealed, and filed general demurrers to the writ. The trial court issued the writ and denied the general demurrers. The court affirmed on the ground that although the statute, which legalized the sale of alcoholic beverages, vested the commissioners with wide discretion in the regulation of businesses that had been authorized to sell liquor, they were not vested with the authority to prohibit such sales. The court found that because the repealing ordinance issued by the commissioners made the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages prohibited, they had attempted to frustrate the intent of the statute and exceeded their authority. The court held that mandamus was the proper remedy in the matter because the issue involved a public right or enforcement of a duty.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that granted the applicant's petition for a writ of mandamus that sought to compel the commissioners to regulate pursuant to a certain statute that authorized the sale of alcoholic beverages.

 

1204 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Henson v. Georgia Industrial Realty Co.


No. 22857


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 857; 142 S.E.2d 219; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 652


February 9, 1965, Argued  
April 12, 1965, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied April 28, 1965.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction, etc. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Tanksley.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer filed an action against defendant city-county board of tax assessors, seeking a declaratory judgment that the board was not legally constituted and that the board acted without legal authority in assessing taxes against the taxpayer, and seeking an injunction prohibiting the board from collecting assessed taxes. The board filed general demurrers. The Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) overruled the demurrers. The board appealed.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer leased property for a railroad operation. Each year, the taxpayer returned the property for an assessment of taxes to the State. For three tax years after the board was created, the taxpayer failed to return the property to the city and county for an assessment of taxes. The board assessed an ad valorem tax against the taxpayer for the taxpayer's failure to return the property for assessment by the board. On appeal, the court determined that 1952 Ga. Laws 2825 was not unconstitutional. The court found that the legislature's adoption of the law before an amendment to the Georgia Constitution was ratified by the people did not constitute an ex post facto law as the effective date of the law depended upon ratification of the constitutional amendment and was after such ratification. The court concluded that the constitutional amendment was submitted by the Governor of Georgia in the proper form. The court determined, therefore, that the board was legally constituted and that the board acted with legal authority in assessing taxes against the taxpayer.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the superior court's judgment.

 

1205 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Ralston Purina Co. v. Acrey


No. 22880


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 788; 142 S.E.2d 66; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 633


March 8, 1965, Argued  
April 8, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Habersham Superior Court. Before Judge Smith.

Everette H. Acrey, a citizen, property owner and taxpayer of the City of Cornelia, brought this equitable suit in Habersham Superior Court against Ralston Purina Company, Inc., seeking to enjoin the defendant's alleged violation of a zoning ordinance of the City of Cornelia. The petition alleged that the Mayor and City Council of Cornelia adopted the zoning ordinance on June 4, 1962; that the defendant maintains, uses and operates a rendering plant located in an industrial zone within 400 yards of the plaintiff's home which is located in a residential zone; that the defendant completed construction of the rendering plant in November, 1963, and within a few days thereafter commenced operation of the plant; that the defendant has been operating the plant 24 hours a day, five days a week, since commencing; that the defendant daily brings to its plant the offal from approximately 180,000 chickens and processes and reduces the offal by cooking and pulverizing various portions into meal and by rendering it to produce large quantities of fats and oils; that such process gives off offensive and obnoxious odors; that more than [***2] 100 dwelling houses are within one-fourth mile of such illegally operated plant and unless equity intervenes a multiplicity of suits will result; that the operation and maintenance of the plant as described is violative of certain portions of the city's zoning ordinance; that the plaintiff has no adequate remedy at law and is entitled under Georgia law and specifically Ga. L. 1946, pp. 191, 202 (Code Ann. § 69-839), to equitable relief in the form of temporary and permanent injunction.

The pertinent provisions of the zoning ordinance are attached as an exhibit to the petition. The enacting clause sets out that the city commission "deems it necessary in order to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire panic and other dangers; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land, to avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate the adequate provisions of transportation, water sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements and otherwise to promote the public safety, health, convenience and general welfare in accordance with a comprehensive plan." The ordinance recites that it was adopted "in pursuance of the authority granted [***3] by the Charter of Cornelia as amended by the Act approved March 9, 1959 (Ga. L. 1959, p. 2178), as amended."

Among the purposes of the ordinance are: "to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire, panic, and other dangers; to promote health and the general welfare; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water sewerage, schools, parks, and other public requirements; to sustain the stability of neighborhoods; to protect property against blight and depreciation; to secure economy in governmental expenditure; to conserve the value of buildings; to encourage the most appropriate use of land and buildings . . ."

Under the provisions relating to industrial districts the ordinance states that the following uses are prohibited within an I (Industrial) Zone: distillation of bones; garbage, offal, dead animal reduction or dumping; rendering or refining of fats and oils; any other use that is noxious or offensive by reason of the emission or creation of odor, dust, fumes, smoke, gas, noise, vibration or similar substances or conditions which [***4] in the opinion of the planning commission would be detrimental to the community interest.

The defendant demurred to the petition on the following grounds: that the petition sets forth no cause of action; that the plaintiff is not entitled to the relief sought; that the zoning ordinance upon which relief is sought is null and void because the 1959 Act, supra, upon which it is based contravenes Art. I, Sec. IV, Par. I of the Georgia Constitution (Code Ann. § 2-401) since the 1959 Act is a special law for which provision had been made by a general law, Ga. L. 1946, p. 191; that it affirmatively appears from the petition that the City of Cornelia has not elected to come within the provisions of the 1946 Act; that the zoning ordinance is null and void because the special law upon which it is based contravenes Art. III, Sec. VII, Par. VIII of the Georgia Constitution (Code Ann. § 2-1908) in that it contains matter different from that expressed in the title.

The trial judge overruled all the grounds of the defendant's demurrer, to which judgment exception is taken.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant rendering plant appealed the judgment of the Habersham Superior Court (Georgia), which overruled all grounds of its demurrer in plaintiff property owner's action that sought to enjoin the plant's alleged violation of a city zoning ordinance.


OVERVIEW: The plant claimed that it had commenced its operations that were sought to have been enjoined almost a year and a half after the adoption of the zoning ordinance. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that it was incumbent upon one seeking to have used property for a nonconforming use after a rezoning ordinance to have shown that his prior use of the property was legal and not unlawful. The court ruled that even a nonconforming use would not have been protected unless it appeared that it was lawful at its inception. The matter was within the province of defensive pleadings and the property owner was not required to negative the possible defense. Additionally, the court found that the plant's general demurrer asserting that no cause of action was set forth had not raised the question whether the property owner was barred by laches and that because no ground upon which the doctrine of laches might have been applied appeared affirmatively from the allegations of the petition, it was not subject to demurrer. The court concluded that the ordinance was within the terms of Ga. Code Ann. § 69-835, which gave full power to cities to adopt zoning ordinances for certain specified purposes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the property owner in his action that sought to enjoin the plant's alleged violation of a city zoning ordinance.

 

1206 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Brown v. City of Marietta


No. 22833


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 826; 142 S.E.2d 235; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 644


February 8, 1965, Argued  
April 8, 1965, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied April 20, 1965.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Cobb Superior Court. Before Judge Manning.

Clifford Frasure and W. J. Brackett filed their petition against the Ordinary of Cobb County and alleged: The petitioners own real property and reside in the area of the alleged city limits of the City of Elizabeth. Under the provisions of an act of 1964 (Ga. L. 1964, Ex. Sess., pp. 2179-2201) the defendant is required to hold an election on the first Tuesday in October, 1964, for approval or rejection of the provisions of the act, which act attempts to amend, revise, and supersede an act incorporating the Town of Elizabeth in Cobb County, approved October 8, 1885 (Ga. L. 1885, p. 377). The 1885 act required the election of a mayor and five councilmen within six months or as soon as practicable. There has never been an election or any action of any type to effectuate the act of 1885. Citizens in the area embraced therein have never paid any taxes, no city officials have been elected or appointed, and no city services of any nature have been performed. The charter of the Town of Elizabeth has been abandoned, no attempt having been made to activate it for 79 years. It is impossible [***2] to determine the location of the engine house of the American Marble Cutting Company, which constitutes the basis for determining the boundaries of the Town of Elizabeth, and it is therefore impossible to prepare an accurate or valid voters' list. The act of 1964 establishes the same criteria for the boundary of the City of Elizabeth. The act of 1885 is null, void, and of no legal effect because of laches. It is unconstitutional and void in that it violates the Constitution, Art. I, Sec. I, Par. II (Code Ann. § 2-102), which provides that "protection to person and property is the paramount duty of government, and shall be impartial and complete," for the reason that "said act, while granting the town of Elizabeth the power to levy a tax on all property within its boundary, exempts therefrom all land, houses, stock or other property used for agricultural purposes." Such discrimination violates the quoted provisions of the Constitution of Georgia and the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the Federal Constitution (which is quoted) because of the discriminatory tax exemption. The act of 1885 is null and void for the reasons stated, and the act of 1964 is also [***3] null and void since "it is merely an attempt to revive that which is dead." In 1963 certain persons alleging themselves to be residents of the area embraced in the corporate limits of the Town of Elizabeth filed a petition requesting the defendant to call an election under the act of 1885. The housing Authority of the City of Marietta filed pleadings in Cobb Superior Court asking that the defendant be enjoined from holding this election, and the election under the act of 1885 was enjoined and restrained. This order being unreversed, it is res judicata as to the validity of the act of 1885. The act of 1964 is a local act and in conflict with Ga. L. 1963, pp. 251-252, which provides in Section 2: "No local act granting a municipal charter shall be enacted wherein any part of the proposed corporate boundary shall be less than three (3) miles distant from the corporate boundary of any existing municipality." Code Ann. § 69-1402. All of the lands embraced in the alleged city limits of the City of Elizabeth are within three miles of the City of Marietta. The petitioners are residents and taxpayers of the area described in the acts of 1885 and 1964, and they will be subject to all of [***4] the provisions of the act of 1964 and will become residents of the City of Elizabeth unless equity intervenes and enjoins the election provided for in the act of 1964. The petitioners have no adequate remedy at law.

The prayers were for process; for rule nisi requiring the ordinary to show cause why he should not be temporarily and permanently enjoined from conducting the election called for October 6, 1964, and from performing acts as provided by the act of 1964; that the court decree the acts of 1885 and 1964 null, void, and of no effect; and for other relief. Rule nisi was issued on September 29, 1964, requiring the ordinary to show cause as prayed, and until further order of the court he was enjoined from holding the election.

John T. Brown and seven other named persons, alleging themselves to be citizens of the area described in the acts of 1885 and 1964, prayed that they be made parties defendant and be allowed to appear, plead, and defend as though they had been named parties defendant. On October 5, 1964, the petition of Brown and others to be made parties defendant was allowed by the trial judge, and it was ordered that they be allowed to plead and defend in as complete [***5] manner as though they had been named parties. On the same date Brown and others filed their general and special demurrers to the petition, and an answer. On the same date (October 5, 1964) the Marietta Housing Authority filed a petition praying that it be allowed to intervene as a party plaintiff, and this intervention was allowed. On the same date (October 5, 1964) the City of Marietta, alleging that the proposed City of Elizabeth is within three miles of the corporate limits of the City of Marietta, moved that it be made a party plaintiff. This motion was allowed. On October 5, 1964, the judge of the superior court modified his restraining order of September 29, 1964, by providing that the ordinary "may hold the election" pertaining to ratification of the charter of the City of Elizabeth on October 6, and that the ordinary be enjoined only from certifying the results of the election. On October 24, 1964, the petition of Mrs. J. C. Patterson, Sr., to intervene as a party plaintiff was allowed. On November 5, 1964, the judge overruled the demurrers of the defendants John T. Brown and others, and the exception is to this judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, county ordinary and citizens, sought review of an order from the Cobb Superior Court (Georgia), which entered judgment in favor of plaintiffs, landowners and housing authority, provided that the ordinary could hold an election of town officers pursuant to an the provisions of the Act of 1964 (Ga. L. 1964, Ex. Sess., pp. 2179-2201) ratifying the a town charter, and enjoined the ordinary from certifying the results of the election.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs alleged that the ordinary was required to hold an election for approval or rejection of the provisions of the 1963 Act, which attempted to amend, revise, and supersede a 1885 act incorporating the town. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's decision and held that (1) the original town charter was not forfeited or terminated by a nonuser of its charter powers; (2) the invalidity of a charter provision purporting to exempt property used for agricultural purposes from taxation did not vacate, annul, or repeal the valid charter provisions of the town; (3) the trial court's order restraining and enjoining the ordinary from holding an election under the Act of 1885 incorporating the town was not res judicata as to the validity of the Act of 1885 because the trial court did not expressly or necessarily rule upon the validity of the 1885 act; and (4) where a municipality was created prior to the 1963 Act, the restrictions of the 1963 Act did not purport to apply to an amendatory act because such an interpretation would violate the plain and unambiguous language of the 1963 Act and the state constitutional prohibition against the enactment of retroactive laws.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment overruling the general demurrers of defendants and ordering the election of town officials.

 

1207 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


McAllister v. State


No. 22741


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 570; 140 S.E.2d 828; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 560


January 11, 1965, Argued  
February 4, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Fishing on Sunday; constitutional question. Springfield City Court. Before Judge Fetzer.

On June 15, 1964, in the City Court of Springfield the State filed an accusation charging plaintiff herein with the criminal offense of "Fishing on Sunday." This accusation was founded on Ga. L. 1961, p. 157, as amended by Ga. L. 1962, p. 2344. The 1961 Act amended Code § 26-6908, which prohibited all fishing on the Sabbath, to permit fishing on the Sabbath to all except commercial fishermen, and by Section 1 A excluded from the operation of the law all counties having a population of not less than 6,515 and not more than 6,650, according to the United States census of 1960 or any future such census. This exclusion applied only to the County of Clinch. The 1962 Act struck Section 1 A of the 1961 Act and enacted a new Section 1 A providing for the additional exclusion from operation of the law of all counties having a population of not less than 10,140 and not more than 10,150, which affected only Effingham County, and all counties of not less than 500 and not more than 2,000, which affected only Echols County. Thus, the new Section 1 A merely had the effect of excluding not only Clinch [***2] County, but also Effingham and Echols Counties from the operation of the law.

Plaintiff filed his motion to quash the accusation on the ground that the law on which it was founded is unconstitutional in that it violates the provision of Art. I, Sec. IV, Par. I of the Constitution of the State of Georgia (Code § 2-401) in that it attempts to enact special legislation in the nature of a local Act while there is a general State law covering the subject matter of said Act. Plaintiff subsequently amended his motion to quash to allege that the Act is unconstitutional in that it violates the provisions of Art. I, Sec. I, Par. II of the Constitution of the State of Georgia (Code § 2-102) in that it denies to defendant the equal protection of the laws. Plaintiff, however, states in his brief that "the attack as to unconstitutionality of the Acts only goes to that portion of the Acts as attempts to exclude the three counties from the operation of a general State statute." The motion to quash, as amended, was overruled, and the exception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the judgment of the Springfield City Court (Georgia) that overruled his motion to quash the accusation, charging him with fishing on Sunday, a violation of 1961 Ga. Laws 157.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with the criminal offense of fishing on Sunday, a violation of 1961 Ga. Laws 157. The act amended O.C.G.A. § 26-6908, which prohibited fishing on Sunday, to permit fishing on Sunday to all except commercial fishermen. The act excluded from its operation counties with a narrow population range. Only one county fit the description. The act was amended to exclude two more counties based on population. Defendant filed a motion to quash the accusation. The motion, as amended, was overruled. Reversing, the court found that the statute under which defendant was charged was unconstitutional because it attempted an arbitrary classification, which was discriminatory and repugnant to the Constitution of the State of Georgia. The act was special legislation, based on unreasonable classifications, because it attempted to classify one county at a time by population brackets so narrow that they could apply to just the one county. The act was also violative of Ga. Const. art. I, § 1, para. 2 because it denied citizens in three named counties a privilege granted to the rest of the citizens in the state without a legitimate basis.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that overruled defendant's motion to quash the accusation.

 

1208 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Senters v. Wright & Lopez, Inc.


No. 22769


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 611; 140 S.E.2d 904; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 572


January 11, 1965, Argued  
February 4, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Workmen's compensation; constitutional question. Hall Superior Court. Before Judge Smith.

This case arises from an appeal to Hall Superior Court from an award of the State Board of Workmen's Compensation granting subrogation rights to the insurance carrier against the net proceeds of a settlement obtained by the claimant from third parties for tort liability arising out of the same accident in which compensation was awarded and paid. The grounds of the appeal were that Section 4, Ga. L. 1963, pp. 141, 145, striking Code § 114-403, and substituting therefor a new § 114-403 violates the due process clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions and denies equal protection under the 14th Amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

The exception is to a judgment of the trial court holding that the Act is not violative of the due process or the equal protection clause of either the State or Federal Constitution and denying the appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff claimant sought review of a decision of the Hall Superior Court (Georgia), which, in affirming an award of the State Board of Workmen's Compensation that granted subrogation rights to the compensation carrier, ruled that the Workmen's Compensation Act was not violative of the due process or the equal protection clause of either the State or Federal Constitution.


OVERVIEW: The claimant, having already received worker's compensation benefits, brought a tort claim against a third party for damages arising from the same accident for which he received the benefits. The claimant and third party reached a settlement of that claim. However, the net proceeds of the settlement were subject to the subrogation rights of the compensation carrier under the award of the board, leaving nothing to compensate the claimant for his pain and suffering, excess loss of earnings, and permanent disability. The compensation carrier shared no part of the expense of procuring the settlement. Based on that, the claimant challenged the constitutionality of Ga. Code Ann. § 114-403, which allowed the subrogation of settlement proceeds by a compensation carrier. The court affirmed the judgment and held that the statute did not violate either federal or state constitutional rights because the claimant, by invoking a judgment in his favor for benefits under the Workmen's Compensation Act, waived any privileges he may have had to deny the constitutionality of the act under which the benefits were payable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the compensation carrier.

 

1209 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


United States Steel Corp. v. Undercofler


No. 22724


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 553; 140 S.E.2d 269; 1965 Ga. LEXIS 559


November 10, 1964, Argued  
January 7, 1965, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied February 4, 1965.


PRIOR HISTORY: Income tax refund; constitutional question. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Wood, Emeritus.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer appealed a judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which ruled in favor of defendant, state revenue commissioner, in plaintiff's action that alleged that the amounts of income tax collected from plaintiff for two years were excessive and that a portion of Ga. Code Ann. § 92-3113(4) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff taxpayer filed an action against defendant, the state revenue commissioner, alleging that the amounts of income tax collected from plaintiff for two years were excessive. The trial court ruled against plaintiff and the court affirmed the decision. The court held that the "gross receipts ratio" of Ga. Code Ann. § 92-3113(4)(c), in view of average inventory ratio and the salaries and wages ratio of the Three Factor Ratio, was not unreasonable on its face or in its application to plaintiff so as to be violative of plaintiff's rights under the due process clause of either the federal or the Georgia constitution. The court found that although the sales were negotiated and consummated outside of Georgia and the goods were produced out of the state, the income earned from the products' sale was not at the place where the sale was made, where the goods were manufactured, or the point from which the shipment was made. The court found that the income was earned when the Georgia customers received the products and paid for them. The court found that Georgia provided plaintiff's customers and provided the railroads and highways for shipment of the products to the Georgia customers.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment that ruled in favor of defendant, the state revenue commissioner, in plaintiff taxpayer's action that alleged that the amounts of income tax collected from plaintiff for two years were excessive. The court held that the relevant tax statute did not violate the due process clause or the commerce clause.

 

1210 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Crews v. Cook


No. 22735


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 479; 139 S.E.2d 490; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 588


November 10, 1964, Argued  
December 3, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Probate of will. Lee Superior Court. Before Judge Marshall.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs in error, caveators to a will, appealed from a judgment of the Superior Court of Lee County (Georgia), which overruled their motion for a new trial and their objection to the admission of a will under 1958 Ga. Laws 657, providing for the execution of a will before two attesting witnesses, which the caveators had alleged violated Ga. Const. art. III, § VII, para. VIII.


OVERVIEW: The caveators objected that the Act not only authorized the execution of a will before two attesting witnesses but that it dealt with and legislated upon several other entirely separate, distinct, and wholly unrelated subject matters. The court disagreed. The Act amended several Code sections, all of which dealt with and related directly to the subject of wills and the administration of estates. Because this was true, the Act did not offend Ga. Const. art. III, § VII, para. VIII. "Subject matter" was not synonymous with the word "provision." The phrase was to be given a broad and extended meaning so as to allow the legislature authority to include in one Act all matters having a logical or natural connection.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1211 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Cook v. State


No. 22722


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 463; 139 S.E.2d 383; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 582


November 9, 1964, Submitted  
November 19, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Operating vehicle while under influence of intoxicants; constitutional question. Bartow Superior Court. Before Judge Davis.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision from the Bartow Superior Court (Georgia) that charged him with operating a vehicle while under influence of intoxicants.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with unlawfully operating a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. Defendant challenged his charge alleging that it was too broad, vague, and indefinite. Defendant further alleged that the charge did not provide a standard of measurement or judgment whereby the jury could determine his guilt or innocence. The court affirmed. The court found that Ga. Code Ann. § 68-9927, which made it unlawful to operate or drive a vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor was not unconstitutional or void because of indefiniteness. The lower court also denied defendant's motion to strike the part of his accusation that charged him with driving a vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating beers and wine. The court affirmed finding that the state's modification of laws that removed beer from prohibited alcoholic beverage did not have the effect of declaring beer not to be an intoxicating liquor.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that charged defendant with driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor.

 

1212 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Walker v. State


No. 22656


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 415; 139 S.E.2d 278; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 573


September 16, 1964, Argued  
November 5, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 19, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Trespass; constitutional questions. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Pye.

The defendant was indicted by the grand jury of Fulton County for violation of the anti-trespass law (Ga. L. 1960, p. 142; Code Ann. § 26-3005) making it a misdemeanor for any person who refuses to leave the premises of another, "when requested to do so by the owner or any person in charge of said premises, as the agent or employee of such owner or person in charge," and was found guilty by a jury and duly sentenced by the trial judge. She excepts and assigns error on the overruling of the general demurrer, the denial of the plea in abatement, motion in arrest of judgment, and the motion for new trial, as amended.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a decision from the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which, after a jury trial, found her guilty of violating the anti-trespass law, Ga. Code Ann. § 26-3005. Defendant excepted and assigned error on the overruling of the general demurrer, the denial of the plea in abatement, motion in arrest of judgment, and the motion for new trial, as amended.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, a Caucasian accompanied by Negro friends, was arrested when she sat in a restaurant whose policy was that members of the white race were not served when accompanied by Negroes. Defendant alleged that state action was involved and that her conduct was protected by the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The court affirmed the conviction and held that there was no prohibition against private discrimination; the Fourteenth Amendment reached only state action. There was no state action that denied equal protection in the mere enforcement of trespass laws in relation to private business establishments from which the management, of its own free will, had chosen to exclude persons of the Negro race. A person's right to freedom of expression did not carry with it a right to force a private property owner to furnish his property as a platform to criticize the property owner's use of that property. A private restaurant differed from that of a public innkeeper, and laws applicable to the latter did not apply to the former. Because the trespass was committed in the presence of the police officer, no warrant was required.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for trespass.

 

1213 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Mack v. Connor


Nos. 22694, 22695, 22696, 22697, 22698, 22699, 22700, 22701, 22702, 22703, 22704, 22705, 22706


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 450; 139 S.E.2d 286; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 579


October 13, 1964, Argued  
November 5, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 19, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Habeas corpus. Chatham Superior Court. Before Judge Harrison.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner prisoners appealed from judgments of the Superior Court of Chatham County (Georgia), which dismissed writs of habeas corpus challenging the legality of trespass convictions under O.C.G.A. § 26-3005 (1960).


OVERVIEW: The prisoners alleged that they were requested to leave the premises due to the proprietor's policy of segregation, the attempt by State and local authorities to maintain such policy, the discriminatory enforcement of § 26-3005, and the State's invoking of such statute to effect such discrimination. The court held that the contentions had been decided adversely to the prisoners in prior decisions of the court. The statute's absence of adequate warning that because one was African-American he was brought within its provisions was immaterial because the statute was directed to all persons. The statute recited standards of conduct to guide the owner and the persons on the property as being the owner's request that a person leave and such person's duty to do so. The claim that the statute was applied so as to abridge the prisoners' rights to make and enforce contracts for services and accommodations on the same basis as white citizens, in derogation of 42 U.S.C.S. § 1981, was not sustained by the evidence. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 could not be given retroactive application to violations of O.C.G.A. § 26-3005 (1960) that occurred prior to enactment of such Act.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments.

 

1214 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Evans v. Newton


No. 22534


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 280; 138 S.E.2d 573; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 524


June 8, 1964, Argued  
September 28, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied October 8, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Equitable petition. Bibb Superior Court. Before Judge Long.

The will of A. O. Bacon (which was probated in solemn form) in Item Nine gave in trust described property, to be known as "Baconsfield," to named trustees for the benefit of his wife and two named daughters for their joint use, benefit, and enjoyment during the term of their natural lives. It was provided that upon the death of the last survivor, the property, including all remainders and reversions, "shall thereupon vest in and belong to the Mayor and Council of the City of Macon, and to their successors forever, in trust for the sole, perpetual and unending, use, benefit and enjoyment of the white women, white girls, white boys and white children of the City of Macon to be by them forever used and enjoyed as a park and pleasure ground, subject to the restrictions, government, management, rules and control" of a board of managers consisting of seven persons, not less than four to be white women and all seven to be white persons. In order to provide for the maintenance of the park, income from described real property and bonds was to be expended by the board of managers.

Charles [***2] E. Newton and others, as members of the Board of Managers of Baconsfield, brought an equitable petition against the City of Macon (in its capacity as trustee under Item Nine of the will of A. O. Bacon), and Guyton G. Abney and others, as successor trustees under the will holding assets for the benefit of certain residuary beneficiaries. It was alleged: The city as trustee holds the legal title to a tract of land in Macon, Bibb County, known as Baconsfield, under Item Nine of the will of A. O. Bacon. As directed in the will, the board through the years has confined the exclusive use of Baconsfield to those persons designated in the will. The city is now failing and refusing to enforce the provisions of the will with respect to the exclusive use of Baconsfield. Such conduct on the part of the city constitutes such a violation of trust as to require its removal as trustee. It was prayed that: the city be removed as a trustee under the will; the court enter a decree appointing one of more freeholders, residents of the city, to serve as trustee or trustees under the will; legal title to Baconsfield and any other assets held by the city as trustee be decreed to be in the trustee or [***3] trustees so appointed for the uses originally declared by the testator; and for further relief.

The City of Macon filed its answer asserting that it can not legally enforce racial segregation of the property known as Baconsfield, and therefore it is unable to comply with the specific intention of the testator with regard to maintaining the property for the exclusive use, benefit, and enjoyment of the white women, white girls, white boys, and white children of the city. The city prayed that the court construe the will and enter a decree setting forth the duties and obligations of the city in the premises. The other defendants admitted the allegations of the petition and prayed that the city be removed as a trustee. The petitioners thereafter filed a motion for summary judgment.

Reverend E. S. Evans and others, alleging themselves to be Negro residents of the City of Macon, on behalf of themselves and other Negroes similarly situated, filed an intervention in the cause and asserted: The restriction and limitation reserving the use and enjoyment of Baconsfield Park to "white women, white girls, white boys and white children of the City of Macon," is violative of the public policy [***4] of the United States of America and violative of the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia. The court as an agency of the State of Georgia can not, consistently with the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States and the equivalent provision of the Constitution of the State of Georgia, enter an order appointing private citizens as trustees for the manifest purpose of operating, managing, and regulating public property (which passed to the City of Macon under a charitable trust created by will) in a racially discriminatory manner. Although the charitable devise at the time of its creation was capable of being executed in the exact manner provided by the will, by operation of law it is no longer capable of further execution in the exact manner provided for by the testator. The court should effectuate the general charitable purpose of the testator to establish and endow a public park by refusing to appoint private persons as trustees.

By amendment to the petition it was alleged: By the will of A. O. Bacon a trust was established for his heirs. The trust has been executed as to four of his seven heirs now living, A. O. B. Sparks,  [***5] Willis B. Sparks, Jr., Virginia Lamar Sparks, and M. Garten Sparks. The interests of three remaining heirs, Louise Curry Williams, Shirley Curry Cheatham, and Manley Lamar Curry, are still held under an executed trust by four trustees holding under the authority of the will, these trustees being Guyton Abney, J. D. Crump, T. I. Denmark, and Dr. W. G. Lee. These seven persons have an interest in the litigation since, if the trust purpose expressed in the will with respect to the designation of persons who may use Baconsfield should fail, the property comprising Baconsfield, together with the property providing the upkeep of Baconsfield, will revert to the estate of A. O. Bacon and be distributed to these heirs. The amendment prayed that the Sparks heirs be allowed to intervene and that the trustees be allowed to assert the interests of the other heirs. It was also prayed that the Negro intervenors and other members of the Negro race resident in Macon be permanently enjoined from entering and using the facilities of Baconsfield. The Sparks heirs and the trustees of the other heirs of A. O. Bacon filed an intervention praying that the relief sought by the original petitioners be [***6] granted, but that if such relief not be granted, the property revert to them.

The City of Macon filed an amendment to its answer, alleging that pursuant to resolution adopted by the Mayor and Council of the city at its regular meeting on February 4, 1964, the city has resigned as trustee under the will of A. O. Bacon. It prayed that the resolution be accepted by the court.

The Negro intervenors filed an amendment to their intervention in which they asserted: The equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the court from enjoining Negroes from the use of the park, and from accepting the resignation of the City of Macon as trustee and appointing new trustees for the purpose of enjoining (enforcing?) the racially discriminatory provision in the will of A. O. Bacon. Code § 69-504 prescribes racial discrimination and is therefore violative of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution. Since the racially discriminatory provision in the will was dictated by that unconstitutional statute, enforcement of the racially discriminatory provision is constitutionally prohibited. Code § 108-202,  [***7] properly construed, requires that the racially discriminatory provision in the will be declared null and void. The intervenors prayed that the court withhold approval of the attempted resignation of the city as trustee under the will, direct the city to continue to administer the park on a racially nondiscriminatory basis, and deny the injunction sought by the petitioners to exclude Negroes from the use of the park.

On March 10, 1964, the judge of the superior court entered an order and decree in the case which adjudged as follows: (1) The intervenors named are proper parties in the case and are proper representatives of the class which their intervention states that they represent, the Negro citizens of Bibb County and the City of Macon. (2) The defendants, Guyton G. Abney, J. D. Crump, T. I. Denmark, and Dr. W. G. Lee, as successor trustees under the will of A. O. Bacon, and intervenors A. O. B. Sparks, Willis B. Sparks, Jr., Virginia Lamar Sparks and M. Garten Sparks are also proper parties. (3) The City of Macon having submitted its resignation as the trustee of the property known as Baconsfield, the resignation is accepted by the court. (4) Hugh M. Comer, Lawton Miller, and [***8] B. L. Register are appointed as trustees to serve in lieu of the City of Macon. (5) The court retains jurisdiction for the purpose of appointing other trustees that may be necessary in the future. (6) It is unnecessary to pass upon the secondary contention of the intervenors Guyton G. Abney and others.

Reverend E. S. Evans and others in their writ of error to this court assign error on this order of the trial judge. Their contentions will appear from the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Intervenors, the reverend and the Negro citizens, appealed the decision of the Bibb Superior Court (Georgia), which accepted the resignation of defendant city as trustee of a charitable bequest of property designated for use as a park for white citizens only, and appointed new trustees, in favor of plaintiff board members.


OVERVIEW: The testator's will gave in trust property to the city for use as a park for white citizens, and it would be managed by a designated board. The board members brought an equitable petition against the city and other trustees. The city asserted that it could not legally enforce racial segregation of the property, and therefore it was unable to comply with the specific intention of the testator. The board members thereafter filed a motion for summary judgment. The reverend and Negro citizens of the city filed an intervention. The superior court entered an order and decree, which accepted the city's resignation as trustee, and appointed new trustees. The intervenors appealed. The court affirmed because the testator had the absolute right to give property to a limited class. Also, the cy pres rule was not invoked by the primary parties and thus unavailable, but even if the intervenors had raised the issue, the facts before the trial court were insufficient to invoke a ruling that the charitable bequest was incapable of execution in the exact manner provided by the testator.


OUTCOME: In an equitable petition brought in connection with a charitable trust for the benefit of white citizens only, the court affirmed the decision of the trial court, which allowed the city to resign as trustee and appointed new trustees, in favor of the board members, and against the intentions of intervenors.

 

1215 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Jowers v. Griffin


No. 22513


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 242; 138 S.E.2d 370; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 507


June 8, 1964, Argued  
September 16, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied September 28, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction, etc. Coffee Superior Court. Before Judge Hodges.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a qualified voter, filed an action against defendants, members of the county democratic executive committee. The voter wanted the Act of 1960, 1960 Ga. Laws 2147 declared unconstitutional and the committee enjoined from certifying a candidate as the party's nominee for a district commissioner office. The Coffee Superior Court (Georgia) sustained the committee's general demurrer. The voter appealed.


OVERVIEW: The candidate that the voter voted for received the majority of votes in the district to which he was trying to be elected. However, the candidate that the committee nominated received the majority of votes in the county at large. The voter alleged that the Act of 1960 was unconstitutional because it allowed a candidate who received the majority of votes in the county at large to receive the nomination and not the candidate that received the majority of votes in the district to which he was going to represent. The court held that because it appeared from the petition that no election was held except under the Act of 1960 and that the candidate being nominated and not the one the voter voted for received the majority vote in that election, no duty rested upon the committee to certify the candidate the voter voted for as the successful candidate in that election. The court held that the candidate who was being nominated who had received the majority of the votes and who was the successful candidate in the only election held was not named a party to the case. The court held that he was a necessary and indispensable party. Therefore, the petition set forth no cause of for injunction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1216 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Sheppard v. DeKalb County Board of Education


No. 22546


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 219; 138 S.E.2d 271; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 494


July 13, 1964, Submitted  
September 11, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction, etc. DeKalb Superior Court. Before Judge Guess.

The DeKalb County Board of Education brought condemnation proceedings against certain described land owned by J. R. Sheppard under authority of Georgia Laws 1956, page 100, which authorizes county boards of education to take and damage private property "for public school purposes, either for public school building sites, playgrounds, athletic fields, or other purposes, in connection with the common schools, high schools, or any public educational program which is now or may be hereafter authorized by law." Sheppard filed general and special demurrers to the petition and in his answer seeks a temporary and permanent injunction against the taking of his property. In the answer the defendant attacked the constitutionality of the Act of 1956, supra, and further alleged that the county desired to obtain the property for use as a junior college and that the Act under which the proceedings were brought does not authorize the county to take property for use as a junior college. The trial court overruled the general and special demurrers and denied the temporary injunction. The exception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment  [***2] affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, the DeKalb County Board of Education, brought condemnation proceedings against land owned by plaintiff landowner under the authority of 1956 Ga. Laws 100. The Superior Court of DeKalb County (Georgia) overruled the general and special demurrers filed by the landowner and denied the temporary injunction, and he filed an exception to the judgment.


OVERVIEW: The landowner alleged that 1956 Ga. Laws 100 (the Act) was unconstitutional. The title clearly indicated that the Act authorized county school boards to condemn private property for public school purposes, and a "public educational program" was a public school purpose and sufficiently embraced by the title of the Act. Therefore, the Act did not contain matter not contemplated by the title. Therefore, the Act was not open to the objection of plurality of subject matter within the meaning of Ga. Const. art. III, § VII, para. VIII. The landowner also alleged that the junior college was not a public educational program authorized by law so that condemnation therefore was unauthorized. A junior college that was established, constructed, equipped, maintained, operated, and administered by a county board of education as a "community educational institution" was clearly a public educational program. It was also clearly authorized by law. Therefore, the DeKalb County Board of Education was authorized under the Act to condemn the property.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.

 

1217 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


R. O. A. Motors v. Taylor


No. 22472


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 122; 137 S.E.2d 459; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 466


May 11, 1964, Argued  
June 10, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 6, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Action for damages; constitutional question. Fulton Civil Court. Before Judge Camp.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant lessee challenged an order of the Fulton Civil Court (Georgia), which overruled his plea contesting jurisdiction and his motion to dismiss appellee lessor's action. On a prior appeal, the appellate court had held that the trial court had jurisdiction pursuant to Ga. Code Ann. § 22-1211 and remanded to the trial court. On remand, the lessee renewed his plea to the trial court's jurisdiction and filed a motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: The lessee was a foreign corporation and it had ceased doing business in Georgia. It contended that jurisdiction over it would violate due process and equal protection because at the time of service of process it was not a resident of Georgia, was not doing business in the state and had no office, agent or statutory agent in the state. It also charged that § 22-1211 violated due process and equal protection. The trial court overruled the plea to the jurisdiction and the motion to dismiss. On appeal, the court affirmed. The appellate court's previous holding that jurisdiction was proper was the law of the case. The lessee did not challenge the validity of § 22-1211 before the first appeal in its motion to abate the action and vacate the entry of service. After the appellate court ruled that the motion was not valid, the lessee could not challenge the constitutionality of § 22-1211. The lessee should have asserted the question of the constitutionality of the statute at the outset in its motion to abate the action and traverse the return of service, before the appellate court had ruled against it.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's refusal to dismiss the lessor's action under the lease and the overruling of the lessee's plea to the trial court's jurisdiction.

 

1218 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Carsello v. State


Nos. 22451, 22452


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 90; 137 S.E.2d 305; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 459


April 14, 1964, Argued  
June 8, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Bribery; constitutional question. Dougherty Superior Court. Before Judge Crow.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction for bribery entered in the Dougherty Superior Court (Georgia), based upon a violation of Ga. Code Ann. § 26-5020. Defendant based his appeal upon the contention that § 26-5020 was an unconstitutional law.


OVERVIEW: On appeal from defendant's conviction for bribery based upon his act of bribing a public official, the court found that his conviction could not stand because the statute under which he was convicted was unconstitutional. Accordingly, the court reversed defendant's conviction, finding that § 26-5020 forbade acts that were not described in the title of the act that addressed bribery. The court found that while the title of the act prohibited the offering or accepting of anything of value to influence members of the executive branch of government, the legislative branch of government, or the judicial branch of government, the actual section under which defendant was convicted included not only "members" of the three branches, but also any officers or employees or persons acting for or on behalf of the state or agency thereof. Therefore, the statute contained matter different from that expressed in the title of the act, and violated Ga. Const. art. III, § VII, para. VIII ( Ga. Code Ann. § 2-1908), which prohibited the passage of a law that referred to more than one subject or that contained matter different than that expressed in the title.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction for bribery, finding that the statute under which he was convicted was unconstitutional.

 

1219 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Sims v. Balkcom


No. 22438


Supreme Court of Georgia


220 Ga. 7; 136 S.E.2d 766; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 432


April 13, 1964, Argued  
May 7, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus. Reidsville City Court. Before Judge Carr.

This is a habeas corpus case in which it is alleged that the prisoner is an indigent and illiterate Negro who was not properly represented by counsel at any stage of the case, was not advised of his constitutional rights in violation of the due process and equal protection clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions in that he was not indicted by a grand jury or tried by a petit jury legally composed, that he at no time waived or authorized the waiver of any of his constitutional rights to be tried by a fair and impartial jury, and the verdict and sentence to die by electrocution are in violation of the 14th Amendment and the State Constitution in that it constitutes cruel and inhuman treatment because of the severity of the sentence disproportionate to the offense charged in that life was neither taken nor endangered. By amendment the statute (Code Ann. § 26-1302; Ga. L. 1960, p. 266) under which he was sentenced to death is likewise attacked as being unconstitutional in violation of the "cruel and unusual punishments" clauses of the State Constitution and the 6th, 8th and 14th Amendments of the Constitution of the [***2] United States in that the statute fails to set out any standards by which the jury can be guided in its determination of the sentence to be imposed, alleging that (a) the State of Georgia has executed for rape 58 Negro persons and only 3 White persons since 1930; (b) execution for rape violates evolving standards of decency that mark the progress of a maturing society, which are more or less accepted universally; and (c) in the instant case the imposition of the death penalty is erratic and arbitrary, he being the only known person sentenced to death for rape in this county since 1913, only two other persons having been sentenced to death, both for murder, which sentences were later commuted to life imprisonment. He further alleges that the admission of a confession signed by him violated his right of due process under the 14th Amendment since it was obtained by threats and force at a time when he was unrepresented by counsel, he being illiterate, and after he had been beaten and threatened with death if he denied committing the crime.

Evidence was introduced at the hearing in regard to (1) the selection of the names of jurors from the tax digests of Charlton County; (2) the illiteracy,  [***3] ignorance and indigency of the prisoner; (3) exhibits and documents with reference to capital crimes and punishment which were not allowed in evidence; and (4) testimony and documents submitted to prove the lack of counsel at various stages of the case, including the holding of the first and second committal hearings, the last time the prisoner saw his appointed counsel, the failure by counsel to file a motion for new trial, and the reasons why defense counsel failed to raise certain questions in defense during the trial and prior to trial, and particularly as to whether or not the prisoner had been beaten in a doctor's office, including a review of questions asked of the doctor which included the doctor's testimony in regard to the victim as to bruises on her chest, around her breasts, shoulders, neck and eyes, and the transcript of the committal hearing as to his testimony with reference to his examination of the victim within two hours after the alleged rape showing her hysteria and extreme nervous shock in which she stated she had been raped, the condition in which he found her private parts showing that her hymen had been stretched to allow entrance to the vagina, blood stains [***4] present around the entire area, with tears in the mucuous membranes, and that she had been menstruating and was still menstruating, and the condition of her clothing and body with mud on her legs and thighs.

After the hearing, the court remanded the custody of the prisoner back to the warden, and the exception here is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed with direction.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant prisoner was convicted of rape and sentenced to death. The Reidsville City Court (Georgia) denied the prisoner's action for habeas corpus and remanded the custody of the prisoner back to appellee warden. The prisoner appealed.


OVERVIEW: In his action for habeas corpus, the prisoner alleged that he was indigent and illiterate and that he had received ineffective assistance of counsel. The prisoner alleged that his constitutional rights had been violated and that the sentence of death for the crime of rape constituted cruel and unusual punishment. The court held that a death sentence for rape was constitutional and that the prisoner had received effective assistance of counsel at trial. The court held that the prisoner's constitutional rights were violated by the State's failure to provide counsel for the prisoner's appeal of his sentence. Subsequent to his trial, the prisoner was incarcerated, was without counsel and was ignorant of his right to appeal. The appeal of the death sentence was a critical stage of the proceedings in the prisoner's conviction. The lack of counsel after the death sentence was imposed violated the prisoner's vital constitutional right to counsel and rendered his trial and sentence void.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the prisoner's conviction and sentence to death. The court directed the trial court to conduct another trial and that counsel be appointed to represent the prisoner at all stages of the proceedings.

 

1220 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Durham v. State


Nos. 22398, 22399, 22402


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 830; 136 S.E.2d 322; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 420


March 9, 1964, Argued  
April 9, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied April 21, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Trespass; constitutional questions. Savannah City Court. Before Judge Oliver.

On August 5, 1963, at the August term of the City Court of Savannah there came on for trial the cases of the State of Georgia against James Durham and James Alexander (hereinafter referred to as the Durham case), against William German and Albert Mack (hereinafter referred to as the German case), and against Wallace Lloyd, Billy Simmons, Johnny Hyman, Willie Pickett, Walter Roland Abney, Shirley Miller, Gloria Bartow, William T. Sams and John R. Smith (hereinafter referred to as the Lloyd case), the same being on accusation wherein the defendants were charged with violation of the Act 1960 (Ga. L. 1960, p. 142; embodied in Code Ann. § 26-3005) which reads: "It shall be unlawful for any person, who is on the premises of another, to refuse and fail to leave said premises when requested to do so by the owner or any person in charge of said premises or the agent or employee of such owner or such person in charge. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as for a misdemeanor."

 [***2] Unless otherwise indicated the following recitation is applicable to each of the three cases.

Before arraignment and before pleading to the accusation the defendants filed a general demurrer to the accusation on the following grounds: that the Act of 1960 is unconstitutional on its face because it is so vague, indefinite and uncertain in that it fails to require that the person making the demand to leave the premises present documents or other evidence of possessory right sufficient to apprise defendant of the validity of the demand to leave so as to violate his rights to due process of law under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution; and it is unconstitutionally applied to the defendant in that it makes it a crime to be on property open to the public after being asked to leave, because of race or color, in violation of defendant's rights under the due process and equal protection clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution. The demurrer was overruled by the trial judge.

The defendants then filed their plea in abatement reading: that the Act of 1960 is unconstitutionally vague on its face and as applied to the defendant's conduct which [***3] consisted solely of peacefully protesting against racial segregation in the City of Savannah; that the statute is unconstitutional as applied to the defendant's conduct in that it violates rights of free speech and assembly secured by the First Amendment and the due process clauses of the Georgia and United States Constitutions; that the statute as applied violates the defendant's rights under the equal protection and due process clauses of the United States Constitution in that it is used for the purpose and effect of thwarting the activities of the defendants, who are Negroes, against racial segregation; that the statute and accusation under it are so vague, indefinite and uncertain as not to fairly apprise the defendants of the acts they are charged with committing, thus denying them an opportunity to effectively prepare a defense, in violation of rights secured by the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution. Ruling thereon was reserved until the introduction of evidence was complete.

Upon the trial of the case, the judge of the court presided without the intervention of a jury as trier of the law and facts of the case. Evidence was then [***4] introduced by the State, at the close of which the trial judge overruled the defendants' plea in abatement. Counsel for the defendants then filed a motion to acquit which was likewise overruled.

The evidence adduced was in substance as follows.

In the Durham case (#22398) witnesses for the State testified that the defendants were sitting down in the vestibule and leaning back against the doors, which blocked ingress and egress to Morrison's Cafeteria; that the defendants were on Morrison's property; that the defendants were requested to leave by the assistant manager of the cafeteria, refused, and the police were summoned; that, subsequently, they were again asked to leave in the presence of the police and by the police and upon their continued refusal to comply were arrested.

The defendants testified they were arrested for taking part in a demonstration at Anton's (another restaurant) not at Morrison's. They stated they were arrested by a Negro policeman. The Negro policeman they identified testified he did not make any arrests at Anton's at that time. In rebuttal, a police lieutenant positively identified the two defendants as the ones blocking the door at Morrison's.

In [***5] the German case (#22399) witnesses for the State testified that the defendants were in an alcove or foyer, "just outside the door," on Morrison's property and were either sitting or lying and blocking the doorway; that the defendants refused to leave despite repeated requests that they do so and were finally arrested. The manager of Morrison's and a police officer both testified that some lay down and some stood up but they blocked the door preventing customers from entering or leaving Morrison's.

The defendant German in an unsworn statement denied that the defendants were on Morrison's property or blocked anyone from going into or leaving the cafeteria. He stated they were standing outside the cafeteria and were informed that it was closed.

In the Lloyd case witnesses for the State testified that after closing hours the defendants entered Morrison's in a group of about 25 and sat at tables, on the floor and in the lobby; that they refused to leave after being requested to do so and finally were arrested. The assistant manager of Morrison's testified the defendants came when the cafeteria was not serving after lunch; that there were signs in plain view indicating the cafeteria [***6] was closed; that the entrance door was locked but the defendants entered through the exit door; that a few customers were still eating, who had been served prior to closing time. He further testified: "Morrison's is cafeteria style, you have to go down a line and pick out your food and then waiters carry your tray to the table, the defendants did not get in that line." When asked whether he would have asked a white person acting similarly to leave, the witness stated: "Well, this was after serving hours and under the circumstances I would have probably asked them to leave." Police officers testified that the serving line was closed and the defendants did not attempt to enter such serving line as is customary in a cafeteria but merely said "they wanted to be served" while sitting at the tables.

The defendants introduced no evidence but stood mute.

In none of the cases was there any evidence that the defendants requested of the management or employees of Morrison's that they be served, nor was there any showing made that the defendants proclaimed the purpose of their acts or otherwise espoused their cause while sitting, lying or standing on the premises of the cafeteria.

At the conclusion [***7] of the evidence and after argument of counsel the trial judge entered a judgment finding each of the defendants guilty and sentencing them to "$ 100 or 2 months, 4 months on Public Works probated." Albert Mack received a sentence of "$ 200 or 4 months, 6 months on Public Works probated."

The defendants each filed a motion for new trial on the usual general grounds and the following special grounds: because the verdict results in denying to the defendant the equal protection of the laws secured by the United States Constitution; because the verdict and judgment enforced against the defendant was the result of the unconstitutional application of the statute in such manner as to deny this defendant the equal protection and due process of the laws guaranteed by the Fourteenth and First Amendments to the United States Constitution. The trial judge overruled the motions for new trial.

The cases having been consolidated, the defendants filed a single bill of exceptions and assigned as error the overruling of the demurrers, the plea in abatement, the motion to acquit and the motion for new trial, and the refusal to admit certain evidence.

The case is here for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed [***8] .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought review of their convictions in the City Court of Savannah (Georgia) for trespass in violation of Ga. Code Ann. § 26-3005.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of trespass in violation of Ga. Code Ann. § 26-3005 based on evidence that defendants refused to leave a restaurant after being requested to do so by the management and the police. On appeal, defendants argued that the statute was unconstitutionally vague on its face and as applied to defendants' conduct, which consisted solely of peacefully protesting against the custom of the restaurant of serving only white people and thereby discriminating against members of the Negro race. The court affirmed the convictions and ruled that the restaurant proprietor had a legal right to choose his patrons and no law, state or federal, denied him, the owner of a privately owned establishment operated on private property, from confining the services of the restaurant to members of a particular class or race. The court further ruled that the state's evidence showed that defendants did not assemble peacefully, but intruded upon the property of another, wilfully interfered with the business of the owner, and that this conduct amounted to violence and was the wilful, unlawful invasion of the rights of another.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendants' convictions for trespass.

 

1221 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Jones v. State


No. 22415


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 848; 136 S.E.2d 358; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 423


March 10, 1964, Argued  
April 9, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied April 21, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Interfering with religious worship; constitutional question. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Pye.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which convicted him of interfering with a religious worship in violation of Ga. Code Ann. § 26-6901.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with acting indecently during a church service. The trial court denied several of defendant's motions, and he was ultimately convicted of interfering with a religious worship in violation of § 26-6901. On appeal, the court affirmed holding that the trial court properly denied defendant's motion to recuse the trial judge because the statutory bias required under Ga. Code Ann. § 24-102 was not established. The court further held that defendant's general demurrer to the indictment was properly overruled because Ga. Code Ann. § 26-6901 sufficiently apprised defendant of what conduct it prohibited, so it was not unconstitutionally vague. The court also held that the trial court had sufficiently charged the jury on the offense and had properly allowed plaintiff to cross-examine defendant regarding collateral matters. Finally, the court held that the evidence supported the guilty verdict.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed an order of the trial court, which convicted defendant of interfering with a religious worship.

 

1222 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Grimes v. Lindsey


No. 22414


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 779; 135 S.E.2d 860; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 405


March 10, 1964, Submitted  
March 18, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Pharr.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff sheriff excepted to a ruling of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which sustained the demurrers filed by defendant commissioners to his application for mandamus to compel payment of an increased salary allegedly due to him under 1963 Ga. Laws 2944.


OVERVIEW: The fiscal officers of Fulton County refused to pay the sheriff of that county the increased amount of salary due him under 1963 Ga. Laws 2944 for the period from January 1 to the approval date of the act. He brought mandamus to compel such payment by them. The commissioners demurred to his petition on the ground that the act, insofar as it had retroactive effect, offended O.C.G.A. § 2-302, Ga. Const. of 1945 art. I, § 3, para. 2, which provided that no retroactive law shall be passed. Their demurrer also attacked the validity of the Act insofar as it provided compensation or salary for the sheriffs affected prior to the date of its approval on other enumerated constitutional grounds. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court and noted that where a part of an act is valid and a part unconstitutional, the valid part will be upheld when it is reasonably certain that to do so will correspond with the main purpose which the legislature sought to accomplish by its enactment, if, after the objectionable part is stricken, enough remains to accomplish that purpose.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1223 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Richards v. Johnson


Nos. 22376, 22377


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 771; 135 S.E.2d 881; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 401


February 10, 1964, Argued  
March 6, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 18, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Equitable petition. Glynn Superior Court. Before Judge Flexer.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed from an order of the Glynn Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained plaintiff's oral motions to dismiss the pleas to the jurisdiction and the cross bills seeking to enjoin the proceedings. Defendants contended that the trial court lacked jurisdiction under Georgia Const. art. VI, § XIV, para. IV (1945) ( Ga. Code Ann. § 2-4904) and Ga. Code Ann. § 3-204, and that another trial court was the most convenient forum.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff filed a tort action against defendants. One defendant, a corporation, was considered a resident of the same counties as the two other defendants, as well as of a third county. Defendants objected to the court's jurisdiction and filed cross bills seeking to enjoin the action on the ground of forum non conveniens.
