The trial court dismissed the pleas to the jurisdiction and the cross bills. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that jurisdiction was proper under Georgia Const. art. VI, § 14, para. 4 (1945) ( Ga. Code Ann. § 2-4904) and Ga. Code Ann. § 3-204, which provided that suits against joint tortfeasors who resided in different counties could be tried in any county in which a defendant resided. The court explained that even though the corporate defendant resided in the counties where the other defendants resided, it also resided in a county where the other defendants did not reside, and therefore resided in a "different" county within the meaning of the laws. The court also held that the trial court did not have the power to enjoin another proceeding where jurisdiction was proper under the doctrine of forum non conveniens.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment sustaining plaintiff's motions to dismiss the pleas to the jurisdiction and the cross bills seeking to enjoin the proceedings on the basis of forum non conveniens.

 

1224 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Modern Homes Constr. Co. v. Mack


No. 22367


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 715; 135 S.E.2d 386; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 385


February 10, 1964, Argued  
February 18, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Cancellation. Screven Superior Court. Before Judge Usher.



DISPOSITION: Judgments reversed.

 

1225 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Modern Homes Constr. Co. v. Burke


No. 22286


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 710; 135 S.E.2d 383; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 384


January 13, 1964, Argued  
February 10, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 5, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Equitable petition. Jenkins Superior Court. Before Judge Usher.

Wade Burke filed his equitable petition in the Jenkins Superior Court against Modern Homes Construction Company, in which he sought to enjoin the sale of certain described property that was being advertised for sale under the powers contained in a certain deed to secure debt held by the defendant. The plaintiff sought a temporary injunction and a permanent injunction against the sale, punitive damages and attorney's fees and prayed that the described deed to secure debt be canceled.

The defendant corporation not having an agent, office or place of doing business in Jenkins County, service was perfected upon the defendant at its office and place of business in Valdosta, Lowndes County, Georgia.

The petition alleged in substance that the plaintiff owned a described lot in Millen, Jenkins County, Georgia, in fee simple; that the defendant corporation induced him to enter into an agreement by the terms of which the defendant constructed a dwelling house on the lot for him in consideration of his executing to it a note for $ 4,244.40, the purchase price of the house, payable in [***2] installments of $ 58.95 per month, and a deed to secure the loan; that a part of the agreement between the parties was that the defendant would obtain at the plaintiff's expense what is known as credit life insurance upon the plaintiff's life conditioned that in the event of his death or total and permanent disability the insurance company would pay "all amounts due on the loan"; that the agent represented both the insurance company and the defendant corporation, a fact of which the plaintiff was not aware; that in connection with the application for the insurance policy the plaintiff informed the agent that he could not read or write and did not know his own age, but that according to reports he was "somewhere around the age of 54 or 55," whereupon the agent proposed, and he agreed, to "put his age down at 55"; that the agent promised to send the policy to him but never complied with the promise; that the American Casualty Insurance Company issued the policy, but he did not know and the agent did not advise him of two clauses contained in the policy -- one limiting the age of the insured to 55 years and the other providing the insurance would only remain in force until the insured [***3] attained the age of 60 years, so that in the event the insured was over 55 years old when the policy was written, or after he reached the age of 60 years he would not be within its coverage; that after the policy was issued the plaintiff became totally and permanently disabled; that the American Casualty Insurance Company on numerous occasions made payments to the Modern Homes Construction Company on the loan secured by the deed.

It was further alleged that: "on an unknown date the defendant and plaintiff were informed by American Casualty Insurance Company that they would not pay any further installments due on said note and demanded a refund of all moneys paid under the policy because the plaintiff was alleged to be born in 1900. The truth of this is unknown to plaintiff. The defendant corporation has committed a fraud upon your petitioner, by misleading the plaintiff as to coverage under the insurance policy and failing to advise the plaintiff the exact terms of said contract of the insurance, when in the facts [sic] said information was within the knowledge of said company, that the plaintiff did not know his correct age, and acting upon said advise [sic] erroneously given,  [***4] recklessly given, and in complete disregard of the contractual rights of the party, induced your plaintiff into executing a deed to secure debt over said property which was free and unencumbered at said time. That said act was done with intent to defraud and did defraud your petitioner due to the fact that they well knew that it was a possibility that he might be over fifty five years of age and said acts constitute fraud and did defraud your petitioner out of the fee simple title to property which he owned."

The defendant corporation did not file an answer, but filed a motion to dismiss and strike the plaintiff's petition and thereafter filed an amendment to the motion to dismiss and strike. The court thereafter overruled the defendant's motion to dismiss, as amended, on each and every ground thereof.

The questions of law raised by the motion to dismiss as amended involve the jurisdiction of the Jenkins Superior Court to entertain a suit in equity against a nonresident defendant, having no agent in that county upon whom suit could be served, and against whom cancellation of the deed, permanent injunction, damages and attorney's fees were sought. It is contended that the petition [***5] showed on its face that the Superior Court of Lowndes County had jurisdiction of this cause of action and the same could not be brought in Jenkins County.

The plaintiff contends that Ga. L. 1962, p. 659 (Code Ann. § 3-202), which reads: "All petitions for equitable relief shall be filed in the county of the residence of one of the defendants against whom substantial relief is prayed, except in cases of injunctions to stay pending proceedings, when the petition may be filed in the county where the proceedings shall be pending, provided no relief is prayed as to matters not included in such litigation. For the purposes of this section, foreclosures and sales under power shall be considered pending litigation" authorized the bringing of this suit in Jenkins County despite the fact that the defendant corporation had no office, agent or place of doing business in Jenkins County.

The defendant contends that the petition for affirmative equitable relief, including damages, cancellation of a deed and attorney's fees, took the case out of the narrow class of cases authorized by Code Ann. § 3-202, supra, and that the last sentence of the section is unconstitutional as being in conflict [***6] with Art. VI, Sec. XIV, Par. III of the Constitution of Georgia providing: "Equity cases shall be tried in the county where a defendant resides against whom substantial relief is prayed."

From the overruling of the motion to dismiss as amended, the defendant excepts and brings its writ of error to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant in error construction corporation brought a writ of error from the Jenkins Superior Court (Georgia), after excepting to the overruling of the corporation's motion to dismiss as amended. The equitable petition was brought by plaintiff in error lot owner seeking to enjoin the sale of his dwelling house property that was being advertised for sale under the powers contained in a deed to secure debt held by the corporation.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court was to decide whether the Act of 1962 (Act), Ga. Code Ann. § 3-202 (amended 1962) was in conflict with Ga. Const., art. VI, § XIV, para. III, codified by Ga. Code Ann. § 2-4903, which read that equity cases should have been tried in the county where a defendant resided. Under former Ga. Code Ann. § 3-202, the exercise of a power of sale contained in a security deed was not litigation within former § 3-202. The Act re-enacted former § 3-202 verbatim but added a final sentence stating that for the purposes of § 3-202, foreclosures and sales under power should have been considered pending litigation. The lot owner correctly contended that the portion of the Act providing that "sales under power" constituted litigation was unconstitutional. The provision was a mere attempt by the legislature to construe § 3-202 contrary to prior court holdings. Thus, the separation of powers doctrine set out in the state constitution and in Ga. Code Ann. § 2-123 was violated. The superior court's judgment was reversed and the corporation's motion to dismiss was granted. The superior court could not have entertained a suit in equity against the nonresident corporation.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the superior court, which overruled the corporation's motion to dismiss as amended. The motion was granted from the lot owner's equitable petition brought to enjoin the sale of his property under a security deed.

 

1226 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Adams v. Adams


No. 22282


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 633; 135 S.E.2d 428; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 347


January 15, 1964, Submitted  
February 6, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Custody of child. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Moore.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant mother was awarded custody of the parties' minor child in the divorce decree. Plaintiff father thereafter filed a petition seeking custody of his 14-year-old son, contending that the son desired to live with him. The mother filed a motion to strike and purge, attacking the constitutionality of the Act of 1962, 1962 Ga. Laws 713-715. The Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia) overruled the motion to strike. The mother excepted.


OVERVIEW: The Act conferred upon minor children who reached the age of 14 years the right to select the parent with whom such child desired to reside, provided the trial court in the exercise of its discretion found such parent a fit and proper person to have custody of the child. The mother contended that the Act was unconstitutional. She also contended that the fact that the child had reached his 14th birthday and had expressed a desire to live with his father could not alter the final order of the trial court fixing custody. The court upheld the trial court's judgment. The court held that the welfare of the child was the paramount issue for consideration by the trial court in all contests between parents over custody. Under the Act, no parental right of custody by judgment or decree could defeat the right of a child reaching 14 years of age to select the parent with whom such child desired to live. The court held that the Act was not subject to the attacks made upon it and that the trial court properly overruled the motion to strike.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1227 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


STEPHENSON v. STATE


No. 22344


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 652; 135 S.E.2d 380; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 357


January 14, 1964, Argued  
February 6, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Validation of revenue bonds, etc. Bibb Superior Court. Before Judge Long.

This case is one brought by the Solicitor General of the Macon Judicial Circuit to validate certain revenue bonds issued by the Middle Georgia Coliseum Authority (created by Ga. L. 1963, p. 2250 et seq.) and to adjudicate the validity and binding effect of a lease contract entered into by and between the authority and the City of Macon. The payment of the principal and interest on the bonds was and is to be secured by the rental revenue to the authority arising by virtue of the lease contract with the city. An answer was filed by the city and the authority, and thereafter a citizen and taxpayer filed an intervention, which was thereafter amended, alleging the Act creating the authority and the bonds issued in conformity therewith and the lease are unconstitutional, null and void for the numerous and varied reasons set forth, i. e., in substance, (1) Section 10 of the law, supra, impairs the obligations of contracts (Code § 1-134 and Code Ann. § 2-302); creates a general obligation debt of the city without it being assented to by the majority of the qualified voters (Code Ann. § 2-6001); is special [***2] legislation attempting to do by indirection that which it can not do directly, that is, make the revenue bonds issued by the authority a pecuniary liability of the city (Code Ann. § 2-401); (2) the law is in conflict with the charter of the City of Macon by attempting to usurp the power of the municipal authorities to appropriate revenue and discretion to levy taxes as provided by said charter (Code Ann. §§ 2-1908, 2-1915); (3) the bonds are to be sold with the lease agreement as security, providing the full faith and credit of the city acting as a general obligation of the taxpayers without the vote of the majority (Code Ann. § 2-6001); and (4) the bonds are unconstitutional on their face since they violate the law (Code Ann. § 87-807 and Code Ann. § 2-6001) in that they empower court action for the compelling of the power of taxation by the city. The lease contract is further alleged to be violative of the general law in that it requires the enforcement of nonpayment by the right of taxation in violation of Code § 87-807, supra, and made not only for the benefit of the lessor but for the holder of the authority's bonds, having all the rights of the lessors in violation of the [***3] statute under attack. It also alleges that the facilities proposed are inadequate and it is not feasible to validate the bonds due to the economic position of the city and the proposed reliance upon the County Commissioner of Bibb County to take over certain governmental obligations of the city. The intervenor prayed that the Act and the lease agreement be declared unconstitutional, and the validation of the bonds be denied. General and special demurrers were filed to the intervention, and a motion was made to dismiss it. However, a judgment was granted, in effect, denying the prayers of the intervention and overruling the objections therein, by declaring the authority was legally created and authorized to issue the bonds, to pledge all the revenues from the lease contract to the payment of the principal and interest on the bonds, and to charge and collect rent from the lease of its public coliseum and related facilities, the bonds not to be payable from or a charge upon any funds or property other than the revenue pledged to the payment thereof; the city had full legal authority to enter into the lease contract with the authority, and the terms thereof are valid, legal and binding,  [***4] and the rental revenue to the authority is adjudged to be security for the payment of the principal and interest on the bonds, and the city authorized to covenant therein that it would make available and use for payment any and all money received or entitled to be received by virtue of its power of taxation and within any millage limitation, and the allotment payment of same would constitute a first charge on all the tax revenues of the City of Macon within any millage limitation thereof; the said bonds are not a debt of the city or of the State of Georgia; all other general obligations of the city, being payable from the taxes levied on all the taxable property within the city without limitation as to rate or amount shall in nowise be affected by said lease and no part of said lease contract shall in anywise impair the obligation of any lawfully existing contract of the city; and the said bonds being issued pursuant to the Constitution and laws of the State are therefore confirmed and validated. The exception is to this judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

1228 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Clark v. State


No. 22323


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 680; 135 S.E.2d 270; 1964 Ga. LEXIS 363


January 14, 1964, Argued  
January 30, 1964, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied February 11, 1964.


PRIOR HISTORY: Trespass. Savannah City Court. Before Judge Oliver.

This case involves the anti-trespass law (Ga. L. 1960, p. 142) as shown in Code Ann. § 26-3005, making it a misdemeanor for any person who refuses to leave the premises of another, "when requested to do so by the owner or any person in charge of said premises, or the agent or employee of such owner or person in charge." A general demurrer was filed to the accusation on the grounds (1) it is unconstitutional on its face because it is so vague, indefinite and uncertain in that it fails to require the person making the demand to leave the premises to present documents or other evidence of possessory right sufficient to apprise defendants of the validity of the demand to leave so as to violate their rights to due process of law under the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution; and (2) it is unconstitutionally applied to the defendant in that it makes it a crime to be on the property open to the public after being asked to leave "because of race or color, in violation of defendants rights under the due process and equal protection clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution [***2] of the United States." The demurrer was overruled, and after the presentation of evidence the defendant moved for an acquittal, which was overruled. Thereafter, the defendant was found guilty and sentenced. A motion for new trial was duly filed, heard and overruled. The plaintiff in error assigns error on the judgments and rulings complained of as being contrary to law and to the evidence.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Savannah City Court (Georgia) finding him guilty of trespass under O.C.G.A. § 26-3005 (1960), overruling his demurrer to the State's complaint that was based on the unconstitutionality of the statute, and overruling his motions for acquittal and for a new trial.


OVERVIEW: On appeal as at trial, defendant charged that the accusation was based on § 26-2005, which was unconstitutional on its face because it was vague, indefinite, and uncertain in failing to require the person making the demand to leave the premises to present documents or other evidence of possessory right sufficient to apprise defendant of the validity of the demand and because it was unconstitutional as applied to defendant in basing the crime on the race or color of the person being asked to leave, contrary to the due process and equal protection clauses of U.S. Const. amend. XIV. In affirming the trespass conviction of defendant, the court ruled that the constitutionality of § 26-2005 was manifested in its provision of authority to every owner, manager, or his agents, to request anyone, whomsoever, to leave his private property and the due process protection was limited to the point where it invaded another's life, liberty, or property interest. Further, the failure of defendant's counsel to submit an approved records brief, as required, served to allow affirmance. Declining to guess what the true evidence was, the court also refused to sanction the failure to conform to the rules.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1229 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Cavender v. Evans


No. 22222


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 449; 133 S.E.2d 856; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 479


October 15, 1963, Submitted  
November 12, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Distribution of deceased ward's estate by guardian; constitutional question. Whitfield Superior Court. Before Judge Pope.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant relatives sought review of the decision of the Whitfield Superior Court (Georgia), which granted summary judgment in favor of appellee guardian in an action filed by the relatives challenging the guardian's appointment as administratrix of the ward's estate under Ga. L. 1958, p. 377.


OVERVIEW: After the ward's death, the guardian filed a caveat that alleged that under Ga. L. 1958, p. 377 she was the administratrix of the ward's estate by operation of law. The relatives challenged the caveat, alleging that Ga. L. 1958, p. 377 was unconstitutional. Specifically, the relatives alleged that the automatic appointment of the guardian as administratrix violated the guaranty of due process under Ga. Const. art. I, § I, para. III and the prohibition against amendment or repeal by mere reference to title or section in Ga. Const. art. III, § VII, para. XVI. The superior court later granted summary judgment for the guardian and declared the caveat to be valid. The relatives appealed. The court affirmed, holding that Ga. L. 1958, p. 377 did not violate the constitutional guaranty of due process. The court explained that the guardian had all of the duties and liabilities of any administrator and that the relatives had the same protection against improper administration. The court also concluded that the relative's contention that Ga. L. 1958, p. 377 violated the constitutional prohibition against amendment or repeal by mere reference to title or section was also without merit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the superior court's judgment.

 

1230 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Southern R. Co. v. State Highway Dep't


No. 22195


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 435; 134 S.E.2d 12; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 477


September 10, 1963, Argued  
November 8, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Condemnation of land; equitable cross action. Jackson Superior Court. Before Judge Russell.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part; reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant railroad appealed a judgment from the Jackson Superior Court (Georgia), in favor of plaintiff state highway department in the highway department's action for condemnation of a portion of the railroad's property.


OVERVIEW: The highway department filed a petition for the condemnation of a portion of the railroad's property. The trial court granted the petition and the railroad appealed. On appeal, the court reversed in part and affirmed in part. The court found no merit in the railway's contention that the trial judge erred in overruling its demurrers, which attacked the petition as amended. However, the court found that the highway department's actions were arbitrary, capricious, discriminating, and unwarranted and constituted an unauthorized taking of the railroad's property. Therefore, the court ruled that it was error for the trial judge to sustain the highway department's demurrer and motion to strike the railroad's answer and objections. Moreover, the court determined that the taking was an unauthorized interference with and an undue burden on the interstate commerce business which the railroad conducted on the property.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment overruling the railroad's demurrers to the highway department's petition for condemnation, and reversed the judgment of the trial court granting the petition.

 

1231 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Riley v. Garrett


No. 22186


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 345; 133 S.E.2d 367; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 454


September 11, 1963, Submitted  
October 15, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Whitman.

Error is assigned upon the sustaining of a general demurrer to the amended petition which, with exhibits, shows, in essence, that plaintiff, a male person, was convicted and sentenced on two counts of an indictment charging him with having committed sodomy with a named female person; that the sentences on the two counts run consecutively; that plaintiff filed his application to be considered for parole with the Georgia State Board of Pardons and Paroles alleging that he was eligible to be considered for parole because he had served more than one-third of the minimum sentence imposed on count 1 and the sentence imposed on count 2 was void because the facts alleged in count 2 do not constitute the crime of sodomy under the laws of Georgia; that the board refused to consider the application for parole on the basis upon which it was submitted; that thereafter the present petition for mandamus was filed to compel the board to consider the application for parole. The petition prays for process, mandamus nisi, and mandamus absolute.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error inmate filed a writ of mandamus after the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) denied his petition to compel defendant in error parole board to consider his application for parole because he had served more than one-third of the minimum sentence on the first count, and the sentence imposed on the second count was void.


OVERVIEW: The inmate was convicted of committing two counts of sodomy and was sentenced. The lower court denied his writ of mandamus to compel the parole board to consider his application for parole. The court reversed that decision because it found that the inmate was eligible to be considered for parole and the sentence imposed for the second count was void because the facts alleged did not constitute the crime of sodomy. The court found that sodomy as defined by Ga. Code § 26-5901 must be committed by man with woman in the same unnatural manner as it is by man with man, that is, by use of the male sexual organ either per anum or per os and that the second count of the inmate's conviction was therefore improper. The court found no merit in the argument that the inmate did not pursue the proper remedy because habeas corpus was not available since the inmate was a state prisoner under a valid conviction for the first count. The court found mandamus was the only remedy available by which the inmate could collaterally attack the void judgment of conviction under count two and compel the parole board to consider the application for parole.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the lower court that denied the inmate's petition to compel the parole board to consider his application for parole because he had served more than one-third of the minimum sentence on the first count, and the sentence imposed on the second count was void.

 

1232 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


N. Atlanta v. Cook


No. 22201


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 316; 133 S.E.2d 585; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 449


September 11, 1963, Argued  
October 14, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Declaratory judgment. DeKalb Superior Court. Before Judge Hubert.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, Village of North Atlanta (Village), sought review of the judgment of the DeKalb Superior Court (Georgia), which dismissed the village's petition, as amended, in favor of defendants, the Attorney General and Dekalb legislators. The trial court had previously revoked a restraining order that prevented the Mayor and Council from calling for a vote on a proposed referendum that would have had the effect of dissolving the village.


OVERVIEW: The village requested a declaratory judgment as to the constitutionality of a referendum clause of the charter and that no action be taken with respect to the referendum clause until the constitutionality of it was determined. The trial court entered a restraining order, then revoked the restraining order, and, sustained the general demurrer of the Dekalb County legislative delegation. On the same day the trial court dismissed the village's petition, the village requested that a person, who had previously appeared as amicus curiae be named as a party defendant. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment of the trial court. The court stated that the court would not inquire into the motives of the legislators and there was no evidence that suggested that the legislators exceeded their powers in the matter complained of. The court found that the petition, as originally filed, had no parties against whom any declaration of rights could be asserted. Despite the village's plea, the court determined that the amicus curiae could not be made a party to the action based only on his appearance in the court as amicus curiae.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court against the village in the action by the village for declaratory relief.

 

1233 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Sweeney v. Balkcom


No. 22180


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 292; 133 S.E.2d 10; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 439


September 10, 1963, Submitted  
October 10, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus. Reidsville City Court. Before Judge Carr.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate sought review of the decision of the Reidsville City Court (Georgia), which remanded the inmate to the custody of respondent prison warden following a hearing on the inmate's petition for habeas corpus.


OVERVIEW: The inmate entered a plea of guilty to an indictment charging him with the offense of robbery by the use of an offensive weapon, pursuant to 1957 Ga. Laws 261 (Act), which amended Ga. Crim. Code Ann. § 26-2501 by redefining the offense of robbery. Following the inmate's conviction, the inmate filed a petition for habeas corpus against the prison warden. After a hearing, the inmate was remanded to the custody of the warden. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the inmate's conviction under the Act was not unconstitutional. There was no violation of Ga. Crim. Code Ann. § 26-2501 in the failure of the Act caption to make reference to the punishment for robbery by the use of an offensive weapon while the body of the Act fixed the punishment for such offense. The court concluded that the inmate's complaint under O.C.G.A. §§ 89-9907, 89-9908, as to the functioning of the grand jury that indicted him, did not apply to him.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the denial of the inmate's petition for writ of habeas corpus.

 

1234 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Binford v. Western Electric Co.


No. 22193


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 404; 133 S.E.2d 361; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 466


September 11, 1963, Submitted  
October 10, 1963, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 7, 1963.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction, etc. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Wood, Emeritus.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowners filed an action against defendants, a rezoning applicant and a county and its officials (county), to enjoin the issuance of a building permit and related rezoning actions. A temporary restraining order was granted, and demurrers to the landowners' petition were filed. The landowners appealed a judgment of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which sustained the demurrers and dissolved the restraining order.


OVERVIEW: The applicant sought to rezone certain property from residential use to apartment-office use. The property adjoined the landowners' property. The landowners opposed the rezoning and argued that the issuance of a permit to construct an office building would depreciate the value of their property. The court held that the trial court had properly sustained the demurrers and dismissed the landowners' petition for failure to set forth a cause of action. The landowners' contention, that the applicant had no standing to seek rezoning because it did not own the property at the time it filed the rezoning application, was without merit. 1952 Ga. Laws 2689, § 9 did not restrict the initiation of zoning changes to owners of property but allowed for such initiation by interested parties. Further, the court held that § 9 was constitutional and did not deny due process because it provided for judicial review of rezoning decisions. The fact that the county expressed favoritism toward the rezoning prior to its decision did not deny the landowners a fair and impartial hearing. Finally, the county had the power to grant the rezoning under 1952 Ga. Laws 2689, § 11.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment, which sustained the demurrers. The trial court's order, which had dissolved the restraining order, was not subject to review.

 

1235 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Pitts v. State


No. 22086


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 222; 132 S.E.2d 649; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 410


July 9, 1963, Argued  
September 5, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Robbery by use of an offensive weapon. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Boykin, Emeritus.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which convicted him of robbery by use of an offensive weapon. 1957 Ga. Laws 261-263, O.C.G.A. ch. 26-25 created and defined the offense of robbery by use of an offensive weapon. Defendant argued that the trial court erred by overruling his demurrers to the indictment and by denying his motion for a new trial.


OVERVIEW: Defendant asserted that O.C.G.A. ch. 26-25 contravened Ga. Const. art. III, § 7, para. 8 because it fixed the punishment although the caption only stated that the offense was defined. Defendant contended that the provision was unconstitutional because it contained more than one subject matter by creating a new grade of robbery. The Georgia Constitution prohibited laws that referred to more than one subject matter or contained matter different from what was expressed in the caption. The court held that the fixing of a punishment for robbery by the use of an offensive weapon was germane to the definition of the offense, the law was not unconstitutional because of the failure to refer to the punishment in the caption, and the only matter dealt with was the crime of robbery. The indictment plainly charged robbery by the use of an offensive weapon. The evidence sufficiently showed that the pistol used by defendant was an offensive weapon likely to produce death when used in its usual manner, as charged in the indictment. Defendant's requested instruction regarding robbery by intimidation was properly denied because the issue was not presented and would have confused the jury.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of conviction for robbery by the use of an offensive weapon.

 

1236 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


First Nat'l Bank v. State Highway Dep't


No. 22020


Supreme Court of Georgia


219 Ga. 144; 132 S.E.2d 263; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 383


May 13, 1963, Argued  
May 29, 1963, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 3, 1963.


PRIOR HISTORY: Condemnation of land; constitutional question. Carroll Superior Court. Before Judge Foster from Tallapoosa Circuit.

On May 14, 1959, the State Highway Department filed a proceeding to condemn described lands under the provisions of the Act of the General Assembly of 1957 (Ga. L. 1957, pp. 387-397; Code Ann. Ch. 36-6A). A special master, as provided by that Act, was appointed by the judge of the superior court. After a hearing, the special master, on February 23, 1960, awarded to Mrs. W. J. Stewart, as life tenant, and the First National Bank of Atlanta, as executor and trustee of W. J. Stewart (hereinafter referred to as the condemnee), the sum of $ 48,625. On February 27, 1960, the judge entered a decree condemning the property in fee simple upon payment of the award.

On March 4, 1960, the State Highway Department filed its appeal to a jury in the superior court. On October 9, 1962, the jury returned a verdict for the condemnee in the sum of $ 31,934. On October 11, 1962, the judge entered a judgment reciting that condemnee had received an overpayment of $ 16,691. It was decreed that the condemnor have judgment for this amount, together [***2] with interest at 7% per annum from April 27, 1960, in the sum of $ 2,953.35.

On October 15, 1962, the condemnee filed a motion to strike the item of interest in the sum of $ 2,953.35, and on the same date the judgment was amended striking the item of interest. On October 22, 1962, the condemnor filed a motion to vacate and set aside the order of October 15, 1962, amending the judgment of October 11, 1962, which included interest.

On this motion the court entered a rule nisi requiring the condemnee to show cause why the motion should not be granted. To this motion the condemnee filed a response wherein it was alleged in part: ". . . interest in said judgment is illegal . . . there being no express contract on the part of condemnee to pay interest on any amount, nor is there any basis for holding there is any implied contract . . . to do so." A requirement for "the condemnee, to pay interest on any said amount paid into court under the proceedings under eminent domain, brought by the State of Georgia," and "to accept an involuntary loan forcibly, would be violating the Constitution of the State of Georgia Art. I, Sec. I, Par. II, Code Section 2-102, which provides that: 'protection [***3] to person and property is the paramount duty of the Government and shall be impartial and complete.'" To "charge interest on the amount which condemnor was required to pay into court to take possession of the private property of condemnee under the statute, would be forcing the condemnee to accept a loan from the State of Georgia involuntarily and be charged with interest, thereby depriving the condemnee of equal protection under the aforesaid section of the law . . . and condemnor is undertaking to make a contract by charging interest on an unliquidated demand, when the primary and only purpose of the taking or condemning said land is for the purpose of establishing the value of the property, to be paid to condemnee, and until the same is established by law there could be no interest charged. . . . The Act of 1957, pp. 387-396 . . . which provides 'If the verdict of the jury be less than the award of the special master, the owner shall be bound to refund any excess paid to or received by him and a judgment for such excess shall be rendered against him, plus lawful interest thereon from the date of such payment,' is unconstitutional as herein set out and alleged and void for the reasons [***4] herein set forth . . . requiring your petitioner to involuntarily borrow money and accept a loan from the Government and then being charged with interest against its wishes or consent . . . would violate the due process clause of Georgia . . . Art. I, Sec. I, Par. III, Code Sec. 2-103, 'That no person shall be deprived of life, liberty or property, except by due process of law,' . . . and it would require the condemnee, movant herein, to pay interest on money which is involuntarily forced on it, . . . The law only allows interest because of a contract, express or implied, for its payment, or as damages for the detention of money, or for breach of some contract, or the violation of some duty . . . interest at 7% per annum in the amount of $ 2,953.35 is wholly illegal . . . and would deprive this movant . . . of due process of law . . ."

On January 4, 1963, the judge passed an order reciting that the judgment of October 11, 1962, had been amended on October 15, 1962. It was ordered, "after the consideration of all pleadings and all issues raised therein," that the judgment of October 15, 1962, be vacated and the judgment of October 11, 1962, be reinstated, "except the interest as [***5] specified in said judgment of October 11, 1962, as $ 2,953.35 shall be $ 2,865.75."

The writ of error of the First National Bank of Atlanta, as executor, was directed to the Court of Appeals, and was transferred by that court to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error condemnee sought review of a judgment of the Carroll Superior Court (Georgia), which vacated its decision striking the item of interest from a judgment amount the condemnee was to repay defendant in error condemnor and reinstated the interest in a lesser amount. The proceeding by the condemnor was to condemn lands under the Act of the General Assembly of 1957, 1957 Ga. Laws 387-397; O.C.G.A. ch. 36-6A.


OVERVIEW: In a condemnation action, a special master made an award to the condemnee, which was entered by the trial court. On appeal, the jury returned a verdict for the condemnee in a lesser amount. The condemnee disputed the interest awarded, and the trial court struck the interest and later vacated that order and reinstated a lesser amount of interest. On appeal, the court found that under the general law of Georgia the claim of the condemnor for refund was unliquidated until fixed by the jury. To hold that the condemnee was subject to the payment of interest prior to the verdict of the jury would deny the condemnee equal protection of the law and due process of law. Under the general law of Georgia, the condemnee was denied equal protection and due process in that none of the several procedures for the condemnation of property authorized interest on refunds due the condemnee prior to the time the amount of such refund was fixed by the verdict of the jury. The provision of O.C.G.A. § 36-615a for interest from the date of payment on the excess paid to or received by the condemnee, where the award of the jury was less than the award of the special master, was unconstitutional and void.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1237 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Stewart v. Davidson


No. 21890


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 760; 130 S.E.2d 822; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 326


January 14, 1963, Submitted  
April 4, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Polk Superior Court. Before Judge Foster.

Five named persons in their official capacities as members of the DeKalb County Board of Education and five other named persons in their official capacities as members of the City of Decatur Board of Education brought their petition against named persons in their official capacities as members of the Georgia State Board of Education and against Claude Purcell in his official capacity as Georgia State Superintendent of Schools, praying for mandamus absolute against the defendants requiring them pursuant to the Minimum Foundation Program of Education Act, Ga. L. 1949, pp. 1406-22 (Code Ann. Ch. 32-6), "to calculate the local financial abilities of petitioners and to allot to them their lawful portions of the Minimum Foundation Program of Education funds determined according to the provisions of said act without giving effect to the last quoted sentence of Section 13 (c) of said act reading as follows: 'In determining the local financial ability of the Counties of Fulton and DeKalb the economic index for the two counties shall be combined so long as the boundaries of the independent school system of Atlanta falls in both Fulton [***2] and DeKalb Counties,'" the same being unconstitutional, null and void for stated reasons alleged in the petition.

The prayers were amended to ask that the last sentence of Section 13 (c) "be declared null, void, and of no effect and unconstitutional as contravening and violating" certain provisions of the Constitution of Georgia, to wit: Art. I, Sec. IV, Par. I (Code Ann. § 2-401) (uniformity clause); Art. I, Sec. I, Par. II (Code Ann. § 2-102) (protection to person and property should be impartial and complete); Art. III, Sec. VII, Par. XV (Code Ann. § 2-1915) (special law for which notice must be given.)

To the petition as amended the defendants filed general demurrers on numerous grounds, all of which were overruled. The case was submitted to the trial judge upon the pleadings, the defendants stipulating that demand had been made by plaintiffs upon defendants that the last sentence of Section 13 (c) of the act (Ga. L. 1949, pp. 1406, 1415; Code Ann. § 32-615 (c)) be ignored in determining the amount due them under the act, that the same calculations used as to the other counties and school systems in the State be used as to them, and that they be allotted their lawful portion [***3] of the Minimum Foundation Program of Education funds determined according to the act without giving effect to the last sentence of Section 13 (c) of said act. Defendants admitted that funds disbursed to the DeKalb and Decatur Boards of Education for the 1961-62 school year, and those to be disbursed for the 1962-63 school year, were and would be calculated according to the provisions of Section 13 (c) and that plaintiffs received less than they would have received had the calculations used as to the other 157 counties been used as to them.

The trial judge thereafter entered judgment declaring the last sentence of Section 13 (c) of the act unconstitutional and granting mandamus absolute as prayed. To the sustaining of certain of the demurrers, and to the judgment granting mandamus absolute, the defendants excepted.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state education board appealed the judgment of the Polk Superior Court (Georgia) that granted the demurrers of plaintiff county and city education boards, that held Ga. Code Ann. § 32-615 (1949) of the Minimum Foundation Program of Education Act (Act), unconstitutional, and that issued a mandamus to the state education board to disburse additional funds to plaintiffs without giving effect to § 32-615.


OVERVIEW: Ga. Code Ann. § 32-615 (1949) of the Act provided that the calculation of the county's financial ability occurred in combination with an adjoining county because an independent school system fell within both. That calculation caused a substantial shortfall in funding to the county. The court affirmed the unconstitutionality of § 32-615, and the mandamus that ordered additional funding. Initially, the court rejected standing challenges to the plaintiffs' action because their being subordinate units of government was not relevant to standing, only that they were hurt by § 32-615. In affirming that § 32-615 was not constitutional, the court found that its joining the two counties solely on the basis of a school system being in both was arbitrary and lacked a legal basis for that classification. Further, such classification violated the uniformity clause, Ga. Const. art. I, § IV (1945) because the legislative intent of the Act pursuant to Ga. Code Ann. § 32-601 (1949) established that it was general in nature as to all counties. Finally, since the remainder of the Act fulfilled the legislature's intent striking down only the unconstitutional portion did not void the rest of the Act.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that held a section of the Minimum Foundation Program of Education Act that treated the plaintiffs different from all other counties in the state was unconstitutional, and the court affirmed the mandamus absolute that required the state education board to disburse additional funds to plaintiffs in accordance with the same calculation used to provide funds to the other counties.

 

1238 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Parker v. Davis


No. 21993


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 810; 130 S.E.2d 723; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 336


March 12, 1963, Argued  
April 4, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Quo warranto. Long Superior Court. Before Judge Usher from Ogeechee Circuit.

Herman Parker and four other named persons, as citizens and taxpayers, made application to file an information in the nature of quo warranto to inquire into the right of W. B. Davis and five other named persons to hold office as Jury Commissioners in Long County. The Judge of the Superior Court of Long County, the Honorable Henry H. Durrence, entered an order certifying his disqualification and referring the cause to the Honorable Walton Usher, Judge of the Superior Courts of the Ogeechee Circuit. Judge Usher granted the application, and ordered that the respondents be served and that they show cause at a stated time why the prayers of the relators should not be granted.

The information of the relators asserted that the respondents had been appointed as Jury Commissioners of Long County under authority of an act of the General Assembly approved January 29, 1962 (Ga. L. 1962, pp. 6-8). It was alleged that the act was "in the nature of local or special legislation," and that it was unconstitutional and void for stated reasons.

A copy of the order of the judge of the superior court removing the former [***2] jury commissioners and appointing the respondents as jury commissioners was attached to the petition as an exhibit. In this order the judge first stated that he was naming the respondents as jury commissioners in compliance with the 1962 act (Ga. L. 1962, pp. 6-8). Thereafter, in the same order, the former commissioners were removed and the respondents named as successor commissioners under the provisions of the general law. It was recited that the last revision of the jury list in Long County had caused much criticism, it being contended that the revision was incomplete and biased, and that many qualified persons were left off of the list; and that it was of vital importance that the jury list be revised. It was then ordered that the terms of the Jury Commissioners of Long County be terminated and their offices declared vacant, and that the respondents be designated, appointed, and commissioned as Jury Commissioners for Long County to succeed those whose terms of office had been terminated.

The general demurrers of the respondents were sustained and the proceedings dismissed. The exception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant citizens challenged a judgment from the Superior Court of Long County (Georgia), which sustained general demurrers by respondent jury commissioners to the citizens' action challenging their authority to sit as jury commissioners and which dismissed the citizens' action.


OVERVIEW: The citizens made application to file an information in the nature of quo warranto to inquire into the right of the jury commissioners to hold office. They argued they commissioners were appointed under authority of an act that was in the nature of local or special legislation, rendering it unconstitutional and void. Following the commissioners' general demurrer, the citizens' action was dismissed. The citizens appealed. The court found O.C.G.A. § 59-101 allowed judges wide discretion to remove jury commissioners. Because the judge who appointed the commissioners and dismissed the former commissioners was authorized under § 59-101 to remove jury commissioners and appoint another board, the citizens' action was without merit and was properly dismissed on general demurrer. The provision of the act complained of could not be challenged since the more general statutory provision allowed the action complained of and entitled the jury commissioners to hold their posts.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed dismissal of the citizens' action.

 

1239 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Dixie Fireworks Co. v. McArthur


No. 21915


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 735; 130 S.E.2d 731; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 313


January 15, 1963, Submitted  
March 25, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction, etc. Whitfield Superior Court. Before Judge Davis.

Dixie Fireworks Company, Inc., brought an action for injunction and declaratory judgment against McArthur, Sheriff, and others. The petition attacks the validity of an act approved February 6, 1962, to become effective on July 20, 1962 (Ga. L. 1962, pp. 11-14), restricting the manufacture, sale, and use of fireworks. The plaintiff alleged that: On July 20, 1962, it loaded a motor vehicle with ten cases of fireworks for the purpose of transporting them to Hamer, South Carolina, pursuant to an order. While the fireworks were in transit on U. S. Highway No. 76 in Whitfield County, the motor vehicle was stopped by the sheriff and the fireworks seized as contraband. On the same date the sheriff entered the premises of the plaintiff and seized twenty cases of fireworks which are the property of the plaintiff.

The plaintiff prayed for process; that the court declare the rights of the parties; that the 1962 act (Ga. L. 1962, pp. 11-14) be declared unconstitutional and void; and that the defendants be restrained and enjoined from doing any act or thing relative to the enforcement of the act. The trial judge sustained [***2] a general demurrer to the petition, and the exception is to this judgment.

By brief filed in this court the plaintiff makes four contentions:

(1) The trial judge erred in sustaining the general demurrer and in failing to declare the rights of the plaintiff and the defendants, it being contended that the petition shows that an actual and justiciable controversy existed.

(2) The Fireworks Act of 1962 (Ga. L. 1962, pp. 11-14) is unconstitutional in that it violates the Commerce Clause of the Constitution of the United States and undertakes to legislate in a field which has been pre-empted by the Acts of Congress, as set out in the petition.

(3) The acts of the defendant, Sheriff McArthur, constitute an unreasonable, arbitrary, and extravagant interference with the plaintiff's property rights in violation of the due process clause of the State and Federal Constitutions.

(4) The Fireworks Act of 1962 (Ga. L. 1962, pp. 11-14) is unconstitutional and violative of the due process clause of the State and Federal Constitutions, since the State constitutional and statutory provisions which created the office of each member of the General Assembly who voted for the act are themselves unconstitutional.



DISPOSITION:  [***3] Judgment affirmed.

 

1240 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Harper Motor Lines, Inc. v. Roling


Nos. 21909, 21910


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 812; 130 S.E.2d 817; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 337


January 14, 1963, Argued  
March 25, 1963, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied April 8, 1963.


PRIOR HISTORY: Constitutional attack on Motor Common Carriers Act. Stephens Superior Court. Before Judge Smith.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a motor line, its driver, and its insurer, appealed a judgment from the Superior Court of Stephens County (Georgia) that dismissed defendants' plea in abatement and overruled their demurrers to the petition of plaintiffs, a truck driver and a passenger, who alleged that they were injured in a collision with the motor line's truck that was operated by its driver.


OVERVIEW: Defendants contended that plaintiffs were not entitled to join the insurer as a defendant to their claims and that the Georgia Motor Carriers Act of 1931, 1931 Ga. Laws 199 et seq., upon which plaintiffs relied to make the insurer a party, was unconstitutional. The court determined that contrary to defendants' claim that they were involved in interstate commerce, rather than intrastate commerce, the provisions of §§ 7 and 30 of the Georgia Motor Carriers Act of 1931, 1931 Ga. Laws 199 et seq., applied to the motor line even though it was only operating as a carrier in interstate commerce. The court held that there was a rational basis to require §§ 7 and 30 to be applied to the motor lines and the application of the provisions did not violate Ga. Cons. art. I, § I, paras. II and III (O.C.G.A. §§ 2-102 and 2-103) or U.S. Const. amend. XIV. The court also held that §§ 7 and 30 of the Georgia Motor Carriers Act of 1931, 1931 Ga. Laws 199 et seq., did not constitute a special law in violation of Ga. Cons. art. I, § IV, para. I (O.C.G.A. §§ 2-401).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1241 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Atlanta v. Columbia Pictures Corp.


Nos. 21893, 21894


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 714; 130 S.E.2d 490; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 307


January 16, 1963, Argued  
February 25, 1963, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 12, 1963.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunctions, etc. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Pye.



DISPOSITION: Judgments reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs in error, city and motion picture reviewers, challenged a decision from the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which overruled their general demurrers to the action by appellee motion picture companies and granted an interlocutory injunction restraining the city and motion picture reviewers from attempting to enforce an ordinance that required motion pictures to be classified before release in the city.


OVERVIEW: The city maintained a charter provision that established a board that functioned to classify motion pictures before they could be displayed in the city. The motion picture distributors initiated an action to enjoin the enforcement of the ordinance and the actions of the screening board. The trial court overruled the general demurrers to the petition asserted by the city and the motion picture reviewers and granted an interlocutory injunction restraining the city and motion picture reviewers from attempting to enforce the ordinance because the city did not have authority under its charter to enact the ordinance. The trial court specifically avoided constitutional attacks. The city and motion picture reviewers asserted that the city had the power to enact the ordinance. The court reversed the decision that overruled the demurrers and voided the injunction because it determined that while the city could not censor the release of motion pictures, it was not limited in its power to classify them. The court avoided discussion of constitutional issues because the trial court had not addressed those issues.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision from the trial court.

 

1242 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Waller v. Conner


No. 21874


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 633; 129 S.E.2d 845; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 283


January 16, 1963, Submitted  
February 11, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for injunction. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Dyer.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff driver challenged the judgment of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which sustained the general demurrer of appellee, the Director of the Georgia Department of Public Safety, to the driver's petition seeking to enjoin the Director from suspending the driver's automobile license tag and driver's license. It dismissed the driver's petition.


OVERVIEW: The driver was notified by the Director that a person averred that he had suffered damages from the driver's operation of his automobile and that the driver had to surrender his tag and license unless he posted a sufficient bond. At an administrative hearing, the Director denied the driver's request to keep his tag and driver's license. The driver's petition attacked, as unconstitutional, several portions of the Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act of 1951, O.C.G.A. ch. 92A-6. The court found that the driver's petition did not allege that he had appealed the Director's decision to superior court, as provided in § 5 of the Act. Since the driver had an adequate remedy of appeal, he had not exhausted his statutory remedies, and the court would not entertain his suit in equity for injunctive relief. The court also stated that it would not pass upon the constitutionality of a statute where a determination of the statute's constitutionality was not essential to the disposition of a case. The court found no error the in the trial court's in sustaining of the Director's general demurrer and dismissal of the driver's petition.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

1243 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Davis v. Hunt


No. 21935


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 630; 129 S.E.2d 778; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 281


January 16, 1963, Argued  
February 7, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Murray Superior Court. Before Judge Davis.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent commissioner challenged the judgment of the Superior Court of Murray County (Georgia) declaring that 1962 Ga. Laws 67, §§ 2 and 3, which amended 1952 Ga. Laws 238 to provide a pension to widows or widowers of superior court clerks who died prior to the enactment of the amendment, violated the constitutional restriction against enactment of retroactive laws and laws impairing the obligations of contract.


OVERVIEW: The Superior Court Clerk's Retirement Fund Act of 1952, 1952 Ga. Laws 238, did not provide for a pension payable to the widow or widower of a deceased clerk. The Act was amended by 1962 Ga. Laws 67, §§ 2, 3 to add a new § 9A, which provided for pensions to widows or widowers of superior court clerks who died before or after the amendment, and to modify § 10, pertaining to the withdrawal of funds. The court said that Ga. Const. art. I, § III, para. II, codified as O.C.G.A. § 2-302, prohibited the passage of a retroactive law or a law impairing the obligation of contracts. A statute was retroactive which created a new obligation on transactions or considerations already past. A constitutional act of the legislature was equivalent to a contract which, when performed, was an executed contract, and whatever rights were thereby created could not be impaired by a subsequent legislature. The court held the trial court did not err in ruling the amendments unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

1244 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Williams v. Kaylor


No. 21844


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 576; 129 S.E.2d 791; 1963 Ga. LEXIS 265


November 14, 1962, Argued  
January 16, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Declaratory judgment; constitutional question, etc. Whitfield Superior Court. Before Judge Davis.

An action for declaratory judgment was instituted in Whitfield Superior Court by the ordinary of the county against the commissioner of roads and revenues and members of the advisory board to the commissioner, and was brought to this court by writ of error, the bill of exceptions assigning error on the judgment of the trial court sustaining the defendants' general demurrers. The case arose as the result of an act of the General Assembly enacted into law in the year 1960 (Ga. L. 1960, pp. 2007, 2017). The act contained a provision which read:

"Commencing with the term of office which begins on January 1, 1961, the Sheriff of Whitfield County, the Clerk of Superior Court of Whitfield County, the Ordinary of Whitfield County, the Tax Collector of Whitfield County, and the Tax Receiver of Whitfield County, shall be paid monthly salaries by Whitfield County, and said salaries shall be said Officers' sole compensation for performing the duties of their respective offices."

It further provided that the annual budget of operating expenses for each of the offices would be passed upon [***2] by the commissioner of roads and revenues and the advisory board of the county under a mode of procedure therein prescribed.

The petition, however, alleged that for several reasons the act of 1960 was unconstitutional and based the plaintiff's whole case for declaratory judgment, to adjudicate the plaintiff's rights concerning the issues in controversy, upon the contention that the act was unconstitutional and hence void. In the plaintiff's supplemental brief filed in this court he emphasizes this position: "plaintiff is asking that the act be declared unconstitutional so that he will then have the right to: (1) Employ two full-time clerks to perform the typing and other clerical duties in his office so as to free himself for the performance of his administrative and judicial duties, and (2) The fees and compensations due him at the present and which will be due him in the future . . . Plaintiff had not asked for any inconsistent remedy but has simply asked that the court declare the act unconstitutional so that he might have all of the relief as prayed for in the petition."

The record of the case discloses that there was no prayer for service on the Attorney General of the State;  [***3] that the Attorney General was not served with a copy of the proceedings and made no appearance in the case. In argument before this court, counsel for the plaintiff candidly admitted that, through inadvertence, service upon the Attorney General as required by the declaratory judgments law of force in this State had been omitted.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff county ordinary sought review, by writ of error, of a judgment entered in the Whitfield Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained the general demurrers filed by defendants, a county commissioner of roads and revenues and the members of the advisory board to the commissioner, to the ordinary's declaratory judgment action seeking a determination that a statute limiting the ordinary's compensation to a salary was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The record of the case established that there was no prayer for service on the Attorney General of the State of Georgia, that the attorney general was not served with a copy of the proceedings, and that the attorney general made no appearance in the case. The ordinary admitted that, through inadvertence, service on the attorney general as required by Ga. Code Ann. § 11-1106 had been omitted. On appeal of the trial court's order sustaining defendants' general demurrers, the court affirmed and ruled that the trial court had no jurisdiction over the subject matter of the case. The court determined that service on the attorney general in compliance with § 11-1106 in a case in which the constitutionality of a state statute was attacked was mandatory and jurisdictional and that without such service the trial court could not render a declaratory decree conclusive of the questions presented.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment sustaining defendants' general demurrers.

 

1245 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Hill v. Perkins


No. 21738


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 354; 127 S.E.2d 909; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 499


September 10, 1962, Argued  
October 4, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Cancellation, etc. Dougherty Superior Court. Before Judge Crow.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision from the Dougherty Superior Court (Georgia), which cancelled a security deed from plaintiff pursuant to Ga. Code Ann. § 67-1316 and overruled defendant's demurrer to the complaint.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff brought an action against defendant seeking to cancel a security deed pursuant to Ga. Code Ann. § 67-1316. Defendant filed a demurrer, alleging that the petition failed to set forth a cause of action and that § 67-1316 was unconstitutional. The trial court overruled the demurrer and cancelled the deed. On appeal, the court held that § 67-1316, which provided that in all mortgages or security deeds containing open-end clauses as to future debts, executed after the passage of the act, such future debts would be limited or confined to debts or obligations arising ex contractu between the original parties to the security deed or mortgage, was not invalidated by the fact that its title was broader in scope than the body of the act. The court held that the act did not violate Ga. Const. art. I, § I, para. II, which provided impartial and complete protection to persons and property, because the legal remedies holders of security deeds were subject to legislative control, and that the act did not grant special privileges or immunities.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision to overrule defendant's demurrer in plaintiff's action seeking cancellation of a security deed.

 

1246 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Simpson v. State


No. 21752


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 337; 127 S.E.2d 907; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 492


September 14, 1962, Argued  
October 1, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Sale of obscene literature, etc.; constitutional question. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Moore.

This is a criminal case involving a joint indictment against the accused that they did unlawfully sell and offer to sell and did possess for the purpose of selling at a certain newsstand certain indecent, obscene and immoral pictorial magazines, pamphlets and booklets, tending to debauch the morals, the accused having knowledge of the nature of the contents of said publications; the indictment thereafter setting forth descriptions of said pictures and subject matter contained in the booklets. The indictment is alleged to be an offense of "violating Sec. 26-6301, Supp. Code of Ga." Before pleading to the merits of the indictment, the defendants presented their demurrers and plea in abatement. After a hearing thereon the court overruled the same, and the exception is to this judgment, the pleadings having raised certain constitutional attacks upon the statute and the indictment. In particular, one of the constitutional attacks is that the statute upon which the indictment is based is discriminatory in that it violates Art. I, Sec. I, Par. II of the Constitution of Georgia (Code [***2] Ann. § 2-102; Const. of 1945) providing that "Protection to person and property is a paramount duty of government and shall be impartial and complete."

The case is before this court on review because of the constitutional attacks upon the statute.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed a decision of the Fulton Superior Court (Geiger), which overruled their demurrers and pleas of abatement to an indictment charging them with the sale of obscene literature. Defendants raised certain constitutional attacks upon the statute and the indictment, including that the statute upon which the indictment was based was discriminatory in that it violated Ga. Const. art. I, § I, para. II; Ga. Code Ann. § 2-102.


OVERVIEW: On appeal of the trial court's order overruling defendants' demurrers to the indictment, the court reversed, concluding that the indisputable purpose of the law prohibiting the sale of obscene literature was to prevent injury to the public which would result from the making, importation, possessing, advertising, selling, or giving away any of the obscene materials covered by the law. The court held that no rational distinction could be found between the evils which the law sought to prevent that would flow from the handling in the manners forbidden of the obscene materials by those to whom the law was applicable and the new media, whom the law exempted from its operation. Therefore, the court found that no justification or reason existed for the classification, which it considered the rankest sort of discrimination, and the exemption rendered the law offensive to Ga. Const. art. I, § I, para. II. For that reason the act was unconstitutional and void, and the trial court erred in overruling the demurrer containing that ground of attack and in refusing to dismiss the indictment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and granted defendants' demurrers to the indictment.

 

1247 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Dependable Ins. Co. v. Gibbs


No. 21730


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 305; 127 S.E.2d 454; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 487


July 10, 1962, Argued  
September 18, 1962, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied October 1, 1962.


PRIOR HISTORY: Action on insurance policy; constitutional question. Turner Superior Court. Before Judge Gray.

The insured, a resident of Turner County, filed his petition seeking to recover damages for the alleged breach of an automobile collision insurance contract against the insurer, a Florida corporation with an agent and office in Albany, Dougherty County, in the Superior Court of Turner County, alleging that the insurer was a resident of Turner County within the meaning of Ga. L. 1960, p. 500 (Code § 56-1201(4)). The insurer filed its plea to the jurisdiction of the Superior Court of Turner County on the ground that the act of the General Assembly in question was violative of the Georgia Constitution in several particulars which are hereinafter set out. To the overruling of its plea to the jurisdiction the defendant has excepted and has assigned the same as error. After the overruling of defendant's plea, the case proceeded to verdict and judgment for plaintiff. Defendant moved for a new trial on the general and several special grounds. To the denial of its amended motion for a new trial defendant has excepted and has assigned the same as error.  [***2] All the aforesaid exceptions are presented in the present writ of error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In plaintiff insured's petition seeking to recover damages for the alleged breach of an automobile collision insurance contract, defendant insurer challenged the decision of the Turner Superior Court (Georgia), which denied the insurer's plea to the jurisdiction, which alleged that Ga. Code Ann. § 56-1201(4) was violative of the Georgia Constitution, and denied the insurer's amended motion for a new trial.


OVERVIEW: The court conditionally affirmed, and held that Ga. Code Ann. § 56-1201(4) was not unconstitutional as violative of Ga. Const. art. VI, § XIV, para. VI ( Ga. Code Ann. § 2-4906) because that constitutional provision contained no restriction as to where a defendant had to reside. The act, which permitted an action to be maintained against an insurer in the county of the residence of the holder of the policy, or in the county where the property was located, did not deny due process of law. Ga. Code Ann. § 56-1201(4)) did not violate the equal protection provisions of Ga. Const. art. I, § I, para. II ( Ga. Code Ann. § 2-102) by excepting from its operation insurance companies bound and obligated as surety upon the bond of law enforcement officers. Letters written to the insured's attorney by the insurer's agents were not inadmissible as representing settlement negotiations. The jury was properly charged as to the measure of damages. The insurer's refusal to pay, in the belief that it had completely performed its legal obligation by repairing the automobile, was not an unfounded denial of liability such as to authorize a charge relative to bad faith under Ga. Code Ann. § 56-1206.


OUTCOME: The judgment in favor of the insured was affirmed on condition that the insured write off the amounts awarded as damages and attorney's fees for bad faith within 10 days after receipt by the trial court of the remittitur from the court; otherwise reversed.

 

1248 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Continental Casualty Co. v. Bump


No. 21706


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 187; 126 S.E.2d 783; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 462


June 13, 1962, Argued  
July 2, 1962, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 16, 1962.


PRIOR HISTORY: Workmen's compensation. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Pye.



DISPOSITION: Transferred to the Court of Appeals.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, an employer and an insurer, challenged the constitutionality of O.C.G.A. § 114-733 after the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia) entered judgment in favor of petitioner employee pursuant to a memorandum of agreement between the employee and the employer and its insurer in the employee's action to recover compensation payments.


OVERVIEW: The employee entered into an agreement with the employer and the insurer under O.C.G.A. § 114-705 for compensation for an injury that arose out of and in the course of his employment. The agreement also provided that the payments would continue until terminated under Georgia workmen's compensation law. After the Georgia State Board of Workmen's Compensation approved the agreement, it possessed all of the force of an award of compensation. The employee then filed an application alleging that the insurer and the employer ceased payments under the agreement. The employer and the insurer argued that O.C.G.A. § 114-711 did not give them a right to object to the award if the employee's status changed. On review, the court found that the statute was an elective statute and that the employer and the insurer voluntarily submitted to the terms of § 114-711 when they entered into the agreement. The court noted that the answer by the employer and the insurer did not present a constitutional question. However, the court concluded that the employer and the insurer were concerned about the constitutionality of § 114-711, and that question had to be addressed by the Georgia Court of Appeals.


OUTCOME: The court transferred the case the Court of Appeals because it had jurisdiction of the writ of error.

 

1249 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


L. R. Sams Co. v. Hardy


No. 21640


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 147; 126 S.E.2d 661; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 456


May 14, 1962, Submitted  
June 13, 1962, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 11, 1962.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for injunction. Hall Superior Court. Before Judge Kelley.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owner filed suit against defendants, commissioners of the City of Gainesville (Georgia), asserting the invalidity of a tax fieri facias that was assessed against its property and seeking to enjoin the commissioners from selling the property. The Superior Court of Hall County (Georgia) dismissed the petition upon oral motion and granted a supersedeas. The owner excepted to the judgment.


OVERVIEW: After the tax fieri facias was assessed against its property, the owner tendered to the City the amount that the owner believed was due. The City refused to accept that amount. In its petition for an injunction, the owner alleged, among other things, that the property was situated so as to be easily subdivided and that there was a sufficient vacant parcel on the property, the sale of which would have been ample to bring the amount in question in said fieri facias On appeal from the dismissal of the owner's petition, the court held that the superior court erred in dismissing the petition because it was sufficient as against the commissioners' oral motion to dismiss in the nature of a general demurrer. The petition was sufficient because it alleged that the levy was excessive. Moreover, the owner sufficiently alleged that the fieri facias was levied against property that was valued no lower than $ 25,000, that it was capable of being divided, and that a vacant parcel of the property could have been sold to bring the amount of the fieri facias The owner was not required to allege the illegality of the tax itself in order to obtain an injunction.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

1250 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Vandiver v. Williams


No. 21647


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 60; 126 S.E.2d 210; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 429


May 15, 1962, Argued  
June 12, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Questions certified by the Court of Appeals of Georgia.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court certified two questions after the trial court ruled that plaintiff State, as obligee of a surety bond, had no right to challenge the constitutionality of Ga. Code Ann. § 56-1201 in its suit against defendants, the principal and his surety.
