The questions concerned whether the court had jurisdiction and, if so, whether the State had the right to challenge the constitutionality of an act of the general assembly.


OVERVIEW: The State, as obligee of a surety bond, brought suit against the principal and his surety. The court certified two questions. First, did the ruling of the court that the State had no status or right to challenge the constitutionality of an act of the general assembly, particularly Ga. Code Ann. § 56-1201, raise a question of which only the supreme court had jurisdiction to determine? Second, if the first question was answered in the negative, did the State have the right to attack the constitutionality of the act when the rights of the State could have been affected by the act? The court answered the first question in the negative and the second question in the affirmative. Because the trial court denied a motion for a new trial that challenged the constitutionality of the legislation, the court had jurisdiction to pass on the constitutionality of the act. Because the State was a party litigant, rather than a party sovereign, it was affected by § 56-1201, which purported to fix the venue of the action to enforce the surety bond. Therefore, the State had standing to challenge the validity of the statute and was not estopped and relegated to seeking repeal of the statute.


OUTCOME: The court held that it had the authority to address the constitutionality of the statute and that the State had the status or right to challenge the constitutionality of an act of the general assembly.

 

1251 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Southern R. Co. v. Georgia Public Service Com.


No. 21674


Supreme Court of Georgia


218 Ga. 157; 127 S.E.2d 12; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 458


May 15, 1962, Argued  
June 12, 1962, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 11, 1962.


PRIOR HISTORY: Refusal of interlocutory injunction. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Alverson.

The exception in the present case is to an order of the Superior Court of Fulton County denying an interlocutory injunction sought by the Southern Railway Company against the Georgia Public Service Commission, to restrain the commission from enforcing an order entered on December 11, 1961, as amended on January 31, 1962, granted on the application of Solvay Process Division, Allied Chemical Corporation against Southern Railway Company and Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, with reference to the railroad services and rates charged at Solvay's plant at Brunswick, Georgia.

The proceedings before the commission, including the pleadings, evidence, findings of fact, and order of the commission, are incorporated in the bill of exceptions. In its complaint to the commission against the Southern Railway Company and Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, Solvay asserted that: It is located on the Turtle River spur track of the Southern Railway System, which spur track likewise serves Brunswick Pulp & Paper Company and Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation. Olin Mathieson [***2] Chemical Corporation is a competitor of Solvay for the sale of chemical products to Hercules Powder Company, at Brunswick. Effective June 2, 1958, Southern and A. C. L. canceled a joint operating agreement which had existed since 1902, and entered into a new agreement. Under the new agreement A. C. L. is permitted to serve all shippers on Southern's Turtle River spur track with the single exception of Solvay. Olin Mathieson is listed as being served by both A. C. L. and Southern, and Solvay is listed as being served only by Southern. Prior to the termination of the 1902 agreement, the complainant had been accorded dual services by both railways. By the discontinuance of the services previously afforded from Solvay's plant to the Hercules Powder Company, located on the tracks of A. C. L., it is charged an interterminal switch rate of $ 26.38, rather than the intraterminal rate of $ 19.18, which formerly applied. During 1959, 217 cars were switched between the plants, and this movement cost the complainant $ 1,562 more than it would have under the former services. Due to the denial of the former switching arrangement, the complainant is now compelled to pay a reciprocal switching [***3] charge of $ 6.85 per car when its products are shipped beyond Brunswick. These actions by the respondent carriers were effectuated arbitrarily and without notice to the Public Service Commission. The complainant seeks restoration of the services in existence at the time it located its plant on the Turtle River spur track of the Southern Railway in 1955, which services, complainant contends, were "assured" by both railroads, and it relied upon these assurances at the time it purchased the site and constructed the plant where it is now operating.

A. C. L. filed an answer with the commission in which the material allegations of Solvay's petition were admitted, but it contended that the 1902 operating agreement was canceled by Southern over its protest, that after cancellation Southern refused A. C. L. the use of its track, and that A. C. L. stands ready to resume the former service under the 1902 agreement. At the hearing before the commission, A. C. L. contended that it was not responsible for the change in operations, and was ready to resume former services when authorized by Southern to do so.

In its answer Southern denied that its agent made the "representations" as to service [***4] as alleged by Solvay. It admitted that A. C. L. had access to the plants of the Brunswick Pulp & Paper Company and Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, and asserted that access to these plants by A. C. L. was limited to line haul traffic. It admitted that the former intraterminal switch from complainant's plant was superseded by an interterminal switch. It contended that it was under no obligation to notify the commission of the change, and denied that it had violated any provision of the statute law or any rule of the commission.

After hearing oral testimony and the introduction of documentary evidence, the commission made a finding of fact and entered a judgment which provided in part: "Ordered: That the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company and Southern Railway Company be, and they are hereby, required to remove the unjust discrimination here found to exist against Solvay Process Division, Allied Chemical Corporation, either by broadening, so far as intrastate commerce is concerned, the provisions of the herein discussed 1958 joint operating agreement to permit the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad to serve Solvay Process Division, Allied Chemical Corporation, to the same extent [***5] it is permitted to serve Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation or by making such tariff adjustments on intrastate traffic as will give Solvay Process Division, Allied Chemical Corporation, the same freedom of choice of routes and services available to Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation at the same rates and charges available to that company." (Italics ours.)

After its motion for reconsideration filed with the commission was denied, Southern filed its petition seeking to enjoin the enforcement of the commission's order, and alleged: The commission's findings and order were not supported by the evidence, but were contrary to the evidence. The commission erred in classifying Solvay as a "captive" industry, hence its order is invalid and should be enjoined. The commission's order, if enforced, would constitute a burden on interstate commerce. The commission's order, if enforced, would impair the obligations of a contract in contravention of Art. I, Sec. X, Par. I of the Constitution of the United States (Code § 1-134), which provides that no State shall pass a law impairing the obligations of contracts. The order of the commission was based on the erroneous conclusion that [***6] the cancellation of the 1902 operating agreement and the execution of the 1958 agreement constituted an unjust discrimination against Solvay. The order of the commission deprives the petitioner of its right to exercise cancellation of the 1902 agreement, and is an action by the State impairing the obligations of a contract, which is forbidden by Art. I, Sec. X, Par. I of the Constitution of the United States (Code § 1-134). For the commission to require the petitioner to permit A. C. L. to use its Turtle River spur track is a burden on the regulation of commerce between the States. The commission is without legal authority to compel one railroad to permit another to use its tracks. The order of the commission violates the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States (Code § 1-815) and Art. I, Sec. I, Par. III of the Constitution of Georgia (Code Ann. § 2-103), which provide that no person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property without due process of law. Code § 93-416, providing for a penalty for the violation of the commission's order, is unconstitutional and void in that it would deprive the petitioner of its property without due [***7] process of law, in violation of Art. I, Sec. I, Par. III of the Constitution of Georgia (Code Ann. § 2-103), and of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States (Code § 1-815). Unless the petitioner is afforded the only safe and adequate remedy of injunction to test the validity of the commission's order, the provisions of Code § 93-9901 would deprive the petitioner of its property without due process of law, in violation of State and Federal constitutional provisions previously set forth. The order of the commission is beyond the scope of its jurisdiction. The orders of the commission are unreasonable, arbitrary, and violate the constitutional rights of the petitioner. If the petitioner is compelled to obey the orders of the commission, without opportunity to test their validity, it may lose the only remedy afforded it for judicial review. Unless the enforcement of the order of the commission is restrained and enjoined, the petitioner has no adequate remedy at law.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant railroad challenged an order of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which denied an interlocutory injunction sought by the railroad against appellee Georgia Public Service Commission to restrain the Commission from enforcing an order granted on the application of a company against the railroad with reference to the railroad services and rates charged at the company's plant.


OVERVIEW: The company alleged that due to the denial of a former switching arrangement, it was compelled to pay a reciprocal switching charge. The company alleged that the railroad's actions were arbitrary and effected without notice to the Commission. The company sought restoration of the prior services. The Commission ordered the removal of the unjust discrimination. The railroad sought to enjoin the enforcement of the Commission's order. The trial court denied the railroad relief; the court affirmed that judgment. The evidence, while not without conflict, was ample to support the finding by the Commission that discrimination by the railroad against the company existed. By neither the pleadings nor the evidence was it clearly shown that the Commission's order was unreasonable, arbitrary, or capricious. The statutes creating the Commission were not in violation of either federal or state constitutional provisions, as an unlawful interference with the liberty of contract, or a taking of property without due process of law. The railroad was without authority to suspend the voluntary service provided under the prior contract, until after notice and a hearing by the Commission.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1252 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


K. Gordon Murray Prods. v. Floyd


No. 21584


Supreme Court of Georgia


217 Ga. 784; 125 S.E.2d 207; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 392


March 13, 1962, Argued  
April 7, 1962, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied April 20, 1962.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Pharr.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff production company challenged the judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which dismissed the production company's petition for an injunction and other equitable relief as to defendant city's charter and ordinance which allowed the city to require inspection of protected as well as unprotected motion pictures and to require a city permit before any motion picture was exhibited in the theatre.


OVERVIEW: The production company argued that the city charter and ordinance provisions which required inspection of protected as well as unprotected pictures, and also required a city permit before any picture was exhibited in the theatre violated the Ga. Const. art. 1, § 1, par. 15, Ga. Code Ann. § 2-115 (1945) and was void. The court reversed the finding in favor of the city, agreed with the production company, and held that the city ordinance violated the Ga. Const. under § 2-115. The court found that speech or press that was not an abuse of liberty under the Ga. Const. was protected by § 2-115. The court noted that no interference no matter for how short a time and how small the degree was tolerated under § 2-115. The court further held that the words of the Ga. Const. in § 2-115, providing that no law was permissible "to curtail or restrain" a freedom, were irreconcilable with any law including a city ordinance that curtailed and restrained. However, the court held that the ordinance and charter forbidding the showing of any picture without approval by the censor did not offend the U.S. Const. amend. I and XIV.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in favor of the city in the production company's action for an injunction and other equitable relief as to the city's charter and ordinance which allowed the city to require inspection of protected as well as unprotected motion pictures and to require a city permit before any motion picture was exhibited in a theatre.

 

1253 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Eubanks v. State


No. 21479


Supreme Court of Georgia


217 Ga. 588; 124 S.E.2d 269; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 332


January 8, 1962, Submitted  
February 8, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Burning to defraud insurer; constitutional question. Mitchell Superior Court. Before Judge Crow.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought review of a judgment by the Superior Court of Mitchell County (Georgia), which overruled their demurrer to an indictment charging them with the offense of burning to defraud an insurer pursuant to the Act of 1949, 1949 Ga. Laws 1118-1122, codified at O.C.G.A. § 26-2213.


OVERVIEW: An indictment charged defendants with the crime of burning an automobile to defraud an insurer. Defendants asserted that the indictment failed to charge them with the commission of a crime because the language of the Act was insufficient under Ga. Const. art. III, § VII, par. VIII and was void as a violation of the law. Defendants also argued that the indictment failed to allege who was the owner of the automobile, failed to allege the insurance policy number, failed to allege that the automobile was insured at the time it was destroyed by a fire, and failed to assert that a loss was suffered by the insurer. On appeal, the court overruled defendants' demurrer that the indictment failed to charge them with a violation of a crime because the language of the Act met the constitutional requirement that the general object of the law, arson, be indicated by the title or caption of an act and a synopsis of the law was not required to be in the title. Likewise, the offense charged against defendants was in the language of the statute and the Act provided notice of the legislature's intention to enact other sections relating to the crime of arson not referred to in the title of the Act.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1254 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Chamblee v. North Atlanta


No. 21459


Supreme Court of Georgia


217 Ga. 517; 123 S.E.2d 663; 1962 Ga. LEXIS 311


November 14, 1961, Argued  
January 8, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. DeKalb Superior Court. Before Judge Guess.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city excepted from the judgment of the Superior Court of DeKalb County (Georgia) that was entered in favor of plaintiff village on (a) the village's claim for injunctive relief and a declaration that territory annexed by the city was instead within the village's corporate limits, and (b) the city's cross-claim seeking a declaration that the village had no legal existence whatsoever.


OVERVIEW: The village claimed that 1952 Ga. Laws 2618, which purported to annex the territory to the city was unconstitutional. The city claimed that the village's charter was invalid, arguing that certain requirements were not met and the statutes under which the village was incorporated were unconstitutional. A judgment was rendered that the territory belonged to the village and the city excepted. In affirming, the court ruled that collateral attacks on the village's charter, granted in 1924, could not be considered at that late date and the city lacked standing to challenge the constitutionality of the incorporation statutes. The 1952 annexation statute violated the one subject-matter and title provisions of Ga. Const. art. III, § 7, para. 8 (1945), because it purported amend the city's charter by annexing to it territory that was actually within the corporate limits of the village, even though the village was not expressly mentioned. Finally, the village's suit was not barred by laches or O.C.G.A. § 3-512 (1953), which pertained to involuntary dismissal of actions for want of prosecution after five years. Such a dismissal was not res judicata so as to preclude refiling of the action.


OUTCOME: The judgment for the village was affirmed.

 

1255 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Wright v. State


No. 21430


Supreme Court of Georgia


217 Ga. 453; 122 S.E.2d 737; 1961 Ga. LEXIS 486


October 9, 1961, Submitted  
November 9, 1961, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 21, 1961.


PRIOR HISTORY: Unlawful assembly; constitutional question. Savannah City Court. Before Judge Alexander.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged a judgment from the Savannah City Court (Georgia), which denied their motion for a verdict of acquittal and found them guilty, as charged, of disturbing the public peace in violation of O.C.G.A. § 26-5301.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged and convicted of unlawful assembly. Defendants alleged that O.C.G.A. § 26-5301 was unconstitutional per se and as applied. On review, the court found that the demurrer did not properly attack those defects that appeared on the face of the accusation. The court noted that a demurrer, which sought to add facts, must fail as a speaking demurrer. In addition, the court held that defendants were only charged with disturbing the public peace; therefore, the alleged vagueness of committing an unlawful act did not have to be considered. The court also determined that defendants failed to state what specific part, paragraph, or section was unconstitutional. The court reasoned that when a constitutional question as to a statute was raised, the provision of the constitution alleged to have been violated had to be clearly specified. The court concluded that the language in § 26-5301 was pronounced in terms so lucid and unambiguous that a person of common intelligence could discern its meaning and apprehend with what violation he was charged.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the city court.

 

1256 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Williams v. State


No. 21376


Supreme Court of Georgia


217 Ga. 312; 122 S.E.2d 229; 1961 Ga. LEXIS 436


September 14, 1961, Argued  
October 5, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Possessing indecent and obscene photographs. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Moore.



DISPOSITION: Transferred to the Court of Appeals.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which overruled her general and special demurrers to the indictment charging her with possessing indecent and obscene photographs in violation of O.C.G.A. § 26-6301; 1878-9 Ga. Laws 163, as amended. Excepting to the ruling, defendant invoked the court's jurisdiction because some of her demurrers challenged the constitutionality of the obscenity statute.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted for possessing indecent and obscene photographs. On appeal, the court noted its duty to inquire into its jurisdiction on its own motion. Defendant's first constitutional challenge to the statute was that its exemption of certain broadcast media, theaters, and newspapers violated a provision of the Georgia Constitution requiring general laws to apply uniformly and equally to all citizens. This attack did not clearly designate the constitutional provision claimed to be violated as the cited constitutional section did not exist. Defendant also claimed that the statute violated freedom of the press as guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution. This attack failed to show how the obscenity statute violated the cited constitutional provision. The same demurrer also asserted that the statute was class legislation because some were exempt. Again, the demurrant failed to designate the constitutional provision allegedly violated. She also challenged the entire statute in four particulars, but did not mention how it violated any constitutional provision. The other grounds of demurrer involved no constitutional issue or any other issue over which the court had jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The court transferred the appeal to the Georgia Court of Appeals on jurisdictional grounds.

 

1257 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Porter v. Watkins


No. 21263


Supreme Court of Georgia


217 Ga. 73; 121 S.E.2d 120; 1961 Ga. LEXIS 380


June 12, 1961, Argued  
July 6, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus; custody of children. Butts Superior Court. Before Judge Brown.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff natural mother of minor children appealed an order of the Superior Court of Butts County (Georgia), which entered judgment for defendant legal custodians of the children in the mother's action for a writ of habeas corpus to regain custody.


OVERVIEW: The juvenile court remanded the mother's children to the custodians after findings of neglect and unfitness. The mother sought a writ of habeas corpus to regain custody; the trial court denied the application. On appeal, the court held that relief was properly denied. While the mother argued that she was not advised that her parental rights were severed at one of the hearings, the court found that she not only attended such hearing and made no effort to appeal but that she also had actual knowledge of the juvenile court's custody of the children for over two years and attended various hearings. The court held that based on the record, there was no due process or equal protection violation in the proceedings. Further, the mother's blanket constitutional attack on the Georgia Juvenile Court Act of 1951 (Act), as amended, as violative of the state constitution's uniformity clause, was without merit; because some portions of the Act were clearly constitutional, such fact alone defeated an attack on the entire Act. Also, § 27 the Act, 1951 Ga. Laws 306, 307, was not unconstitutional in denying the mother a jury trial because she had no such right in a juvenile court proceeding.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order denying the mother's application for a writ of habeas corpus to regain custody.

 

1258 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Smith v. State


No. 21293


Supreme Court of Georgia


217 Ga. 94; 121 S.E.2d 113; 1961 Ga. LEXIS 386


June 13, 1961, Argued  
July 6, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Validation of bonds. Ware Superior Court. Before Judge Roddenberry.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Intervenor taxpayers sought review of a judgment of the Ware Superior Court (Georgia), which granted judgment in favor of plaintiffs, the State and the Solicitor-General, in their action against defendants, the Waycross and Ware County Development Authority, the City, and the County, seeking to validate bonds of the Authority.


OVERVIEW: The Authority, the City, and the County executed revenue bonds for the purpose of paying the purchase price on certain land contracted by the parties. The State and the Solicitor-General initiated the action, seeking to validate the bonds. The taxpayers intervened and contended that the bonds were unconstitutional under Ga. Const. art. 7, § 6. The trial court granted judgment in favor of the State and the Solicitor-General, and the taxpayers sought review. Pursuant to Ga. Const. art. 7, § 6, the County and the City were authorized to levy taxes, not to exceed one mill on all taxable property, for the purpose of acquiring and creating a fund to encourage the promotion of new local business. Under an amendment to the provision, the Authority was created to be an instrumentality of the State and was authorized to provide issuing for revenue-anticipation certificates and revenue bonds. The court held that the amendment had been properly ratified and further determined that, because the Authority was a purely public charity, it was exempted from taxation under O.C.G.A. § 2-5404. The court held that the bonds were valid. The court affirmed the judgment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1259 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Trust Inv. & Development Co. v. Marietta


No. 21191


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 788; 119 S.E.2d 568; 1961 Ga. LEXIS 341


March 13, 1961, Submitted  
April 6, 1961, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied April 20, 1961.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Cobb Superior Court. Before Judge Henderson.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error taxpayer sought review of a decision of the Cobb Superior Court (Georgia), which granted a demurrer filed by defendant in error city. The taxpayer had filed a petition to enjoin the collection of taxes and to have the trial court declare void, illegal, and invalid the assessments as reassessed for the year.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer filed its ad valorem tax return for the year with the City. The returns were not accepted, and the board of tax assessors proceeded to assess the property at higher values. Notice of the higher valuation was given to the taxpayer. A demand was made for arbitration, and the taxpayer appointed its arbitrator. The City appointed its arbitrator, but at no time did the taxpayer receive notice that the City had appointed its arbitrator or filed the name therewith with the city clerk. After more than 20 days had passed, the City sent the taxpayer tax bills on the assessed property based on the increased valuation. The taxpayer sought to enjoin the collection of taxes and to have the assessment declared void, illegal, and invalid. The trial court sustained the City's demurrer to the taxpayer's petition. On appeal, the court affirmed and determined that the taxpayer could not obtain equitable relief where it had not offered to pay the amount of taxes admitted to be due. The court found that by submitting the tax return, the taxpayer had admitted that it owed ad valorem taxes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the demurrer to the taxpayer's petition.

 

1260 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


National Linen Service Corp. v. Thompson


No. 21102


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 550; 118 S.E.2d 486; 1961 Ga. LEXIS 275


January 10, 1961, Argued  
January 20, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Affidavit of illegality. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Shaw.



DISPOSITION: Transferred to the Court of Appeals.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error corporate taxpayer appealed an order of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which granted summary judgment to defendant in error Georgia Tax Commissioner in his action on a writ of execution against the taxpayer for payment of personal property taxes. The taxpayer argued that assessment and collection of such taxes on its property was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner issued a fieri facias against the taxpayer for personal property taxes and filed a collection action. The taxpayer filed an affidavit of illegality, arguing that assessment and collection of taxes on specified property violated the Georgia Intangible Act of 1937-38, specifically O.C.G.A. § 92-122, and also violated due process under U.S. Const. amend. XIV and Ga. Const. art. I, § 1, cl. 3. The trial court sustained the Commissioner's traverse to the affidavit on the parties' motions for summary judgment and granted summary judgment to the Commissioner. On appeal, the taxpayer argued that the trial court erred in holding that assessment and collection of such taxes was not unconstitutional. The court found that no attack was made on the constitutionality of any statute; further, the taxpayer did not seek construction of any constitutional provision. Moreover, the trial court did not pass upon the validity of any statute or construe any constitutional provision. Therefore, because the taxpayer's affidavit only drew into question the application of unambiguous constitutional provisions, the appellate court, and not the court, had jurisdiction to hear the appeal.


OUTCOME: The court transferred the taxpayer's appeal to the appellate court.

 

1261 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Jenkins v. Manry


No. 21074


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 538; 118 S.E.2d 91; 1961 Ga. LEXIS 271


November 14, 1960, Argued  
January 6, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Declaratory judgment. Muscogee Superior Court. Before Judge Thompson.

E. J. Jenkins brought a petition for declaratory judgment against James A. Manry and others, as members of the Muscogee County Plumbing and Steam Fitting Board of Examiners, charged with the enforcement and administration of the act of 1937 (Ga. L. 1937, pp. 748-753), as amended (Ga. L. 1939, pp. 355-356; Ga. L. 1952, p. 2383; Ga. L. 1959, pp. 3090-3091). It was alleged: The plaintiff is the owner of Ace Plumbing Company, a sole proprietorship, located in Columbus, Muscogee County, Georgia, and has been engaged in the business of plumbing contracting and repair from January 1959, through the date of filing the petition. The business conducted by the plaintiff is a valuable property, and he has invested considerable money on special machinery and equipment for plumbing installation and repair. The proceeds received from the operation of his business are the only source of income to the plaintiff and his family. After the 1959 amendment, the provisions of the act apply to all areas within Muscogee County, outside the city limits of Columbus, the effective date of the act in Muscogee County being February [***2] 1, 1960. The plaintiff furnished the board of examiners evidence of the fact that he had engaged in the vocation of master plumber for the preceding five consecutive years, but the board required him to take an examination which was purportedly designed to test his knowledge and skill as a master plumber. He failed to pass the examination, which caused the board to refuse to issue him a certificate to engage in the vocation of master plumber. He has secured an order to install a plumbing fixture in a house at a stated address, which is located in Muscogee County, outside the city limits of Columbus. He has applied for and received a plumbing permit to install the fixture, as required by the Plumbing Code of Muscogee County of 1946. He has secured a business license from the Clerk of Muscogee County for the year 1960 to engage in the business of plumbing and heating. The members of the board have informed him that if, as the owner of Ace Plumbing Company, he installs the fixture in the described house, he will be prosecuted for violating the act of 1937 as amended. It is the opinion of the plaintiff that the act in its entirety, and enumerated sections thereof, are repugnant [***3] to stated provisions of the Constitutions of the United States and the State of Georgia, for reasons set forth in the petition. The enforcement of the provisions of the act by the board will cause irreparable injury to him, and his business will be seriously injured unless such enforcement is restrained pending final determination of the issues set forth in the petition. The declaration of rights and legal relations is essential for the guidance of all parties in the controversy.

The prayers were for process; rule nisi; for declaratory judgment declaring that the act of 1937 and specified sections of the act as amended are void, unconstitutional, ineffective, and without force of law, and that the plaintiff is not required to comply with the terms and provisions thereof; that the defendants be restrained from exercising any of the powers, rights, or duties respecting the enforcement of the act against the plaintiff pending final determination of the issues; for costs; and for other and further relief.

The general demurrers of the defendants were sustained, and the exception is to this judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants sought review of a decision by the Muscogee Superior Court (Georgia) that sustained the demurrers of appellees in appellants' suit for a declaratory judgment as to the constitutionality of Ga. L. 1937, pp. 748-753.


OVERVIEW: Appellants contended that the act of 1937, Ga. L. 1937, pp. 748-753, (act) was unconstitutional and sought a declaratory judgment to that effect. Appellees demurred. The court determined that one of the sections alleged to have been unconstitutional provided for impermissible discrimination against individuals who were not connected with a partnership or corporation because the provision created a situation whereby the individual would not be permitted to engage in plumbing or steamfitting without having obtained a certificate as required by the act. However, individuals associated with a partnership or corporation in which one individual had obtained a certificate could engage in such activity even if the individual to whom the certificate was given did not supervise the work. The court found that there was no reasonable basis for the discriminatory conduct because the actions of one class would have the same impact on the public health and safety as the actions of members of the other class. The court found the act unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that sustained the demurrers of appellees, having determined that the act in question contained unconstitutional provisions.

 

1262 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Mitchell v. State Highway Dep't


No. 21065


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 517; 118 S.E.2d 88; 1961 Ga. LEXIS 262; 93 A.L.R.2d 459


November 14, 1960, Submitted  
January 5, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Equitable petition. Marion Superior Court. Before Judge Thompson.

The exception is to the judgment of the Superior Court of Marion County, sustaining the general demurrer to a petition in which the plaintiff sought to enjoin the defendant Highway Department from proceeding with the condemnation of a certain tract of land, and in which he attacked the constitutionality of the condemnation act of 1914 as amended (Code §§ 36-1104 -- 36-1116). The plaintiff maintained that he, as executor of the estate of W. E. Mitchell, should have been served with notice of the condemnation proceeding against land, title to which was in him as executor. He and the seven other devisees of the land were served with notice in the condemnation proceeding as the "owners" thereof. One of the defendant's grounds of demurrer was that the petition showed that the plaintiff had a complete and adequate remedy at law, and was thus not authorized to invoke the aid of a court of equity.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff condemnee sought review of a judgment of the Marion Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained defendant condemnor's general demurrer to the condemnee's petition for an injunction that prohibited the condemnor from proceeding with condemnation of a tract of land. The condemnee claimed that the Condemnation Act , Ga. Code Ann. §§ 36-1104 et seq. (1914), was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The condemnor filed condemnation proceedings with regard to the subject land, which was part of a decedent's estate. The condemnor served notice of the proceedings on the devisees, including the condemnee, who was executor of the estate but was not served notice as executor. The trial court sustained the condemnor's demurrer, which was grounded on the claim that the condemnee had an adequate remedy at law. On appeal, the court affirmed, finding that a separate equitable action did not lie to enjoin condemnation proceedings under §§ 36-1104 et seq., because the condemnee could obtain equitable relief within the condemnation proceedings. The court reasoned that, unlike the former condemnation act, Ga. Code Ann. § 36-1106 (1914) allowed persons interested in the property at issue to assert their claims and other matters material to their rights, and Ga. Code Ann. § 36-1113 (1914) allowed interested parties to file appropriate pleadings in condemnation proceedings. Because the condemnee was entitled to seek an injunction within the condemnation proceedings even on the ground that the statute was unconstitutional, the court held that he could not file a separate equitable action.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that sustained the condemnor's general demurrer to the condemnee's petition for an injunction.

 

1263 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Walker v. State


Nos. 21080, 21081, 21082, 21083, 21084


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 474; 117 S.E.2d 156; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 508


November 14, 1960, Argued  
November 14, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Trespass on private property. Savannah City Court. Before Judge Alexander. August 26, 1960.



DISPOSITION: Transferred to the Court of Appeals.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed consolidated appeals of their convictions for trespass on private property, entered in the Savannah City Court (Georgia). Defendants challenged the trial court's denial of their motions for a new trial.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were each convicted of trespass on private property. They filed consolidated appeals. The court held that because defendants' bill of exceptions appeared to only assign error to denial of defendants' motion for a new trial, no other ruling was before the court. The usual general grounds of a motion for a new trial, found in defendant's bill of exceptions, presented no other question than the sufficiency of the evidence to support the verdict. Further, defendants' assignment of error that the statute under which they were convicted and under which their sentences were imposed was unconstitutional, as violating their due process and equal protection rights, was not sufficiently specific to raise a constitutional question; moreover, even if the challenge was specific enough, it had no place in a motion for a new trial and, because it was not directly assigned as error in the bill of exceptions, presented no question for review by the court. The court concluded that defendants raised no question as to the constitutionality of a statute or any other issue that conferred jurisdiction on the court. Thus, transfer to the appellate court was required.


OUTCOME: The court transferred defendants' appeal to the appellate court.

 

1264 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Milam v. Adams


No. 20997


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 440; 117 S.E.2d 343; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 498


October 10, 1960, Argued  
November 10, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia -- 101 Ga. App. 880 (115 S. E. 2d 252).

This case is here on grant of certiorari to the Court of Appeals in Milam v. Adams, 101 Ga. App. 880 (115 S. E. 2d 252). The Sheriff of Floyd County, Joe Adams, under an execution against the defendant Milam, levied upon certain real estate as the property of Milam, and sold the property at public sale. The plaintiff Todd was the purchaser at the sale, and he paid the amount of his bid, $ 2,025, to the sheriff. The sheriff applied $ 1,210 of the purchase price to the satisfaction of the fi. fa. by paying that amount to the plaintiff in fi. fa., and turned the excess of $ 738.85 over to Milam, the defendant in fi. fa. and the defendant here. The defendant in fi. fa. in 1942 had conveyed the property sold to one Morgan by deed to secure debt. Subsequently to the sheriff's sale, this court ruled that the act providing for reversion of title to the grantor in a deed to secure debt after twenty years (Ga. L. 1941, pp. 487, 488, as amended by Ga. L. 1953, Nov.-Dec. Sess., pp. 313-315; Code Ann. § 67-1308) was unconstitutional when applied to deeds to secure debt executed prior to passage of the [***2] act, and affirmed the judgment of the trial court directing the jury to find a verdict in favor of the grantee in the deed to secure debt, to the effect that the deed from the sheriff to Todd was void and of no force and effect. Todd v. Morgan, 215 Ga. 220 (109 S. E. 2d 803). Todd, the purchaser at the sheriff's sale, and the sheriff brought this action against Milam to recover the $ 738.85 paid by the sheriff to him.

The Court of Appeals held that the doctrine of caveat emptor did not apply to void sales, and that the petition stated a cause of action for recovery of the money paid by the sheriff to Milam.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant property owner appealed an order of the Court of Appeals of Georgia that held that the doctrine of caveat emptor did not apply to void sales, and that the petition of plaintiffs, purchaser and sheriff, stated a cause of action for recovery of the money paid by the sheriff to the property owner.


OVERVIEW: The sheriff, under an execution against the property owner, levied on the property and sold it at public sale. The purchaser paid the amount of his bid to the sheriff. The sheriff applied the purchase price to the satisfaction of the fi. fa. and turned the excess over to the property owner. Subsequent to the sheriff's sale, the Supreme Court of Georgia ruled that the act providing for reversion of title to the grantor in a deed to secure debt after 20 years, Ga. Code Ann. § 67-1308, was unconstitutional when applied to deeds to secure debt executed prior to passage of the act. The deed from the sheriff to the purchaser was therefore void. The purchaser and the sheriff brought an action against the property owner to recover what was paid him. The court reversed and held that the purchaser took with notice that the property owner had no title except by reason of the statute which provided that the title which he had conveyed away under a deed to secure debt would revert to him after 20 years under certain conditions. He necessarily relied upon the statute at his peril, and when the title failed by reason of the unconstitutionality of the statute, the purchaser acquired no title.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and held that there was no cause of action for recovery of the amount paid by the sheriff to the property owner.

 

1265 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Atlanta v. Gower


No. 20988


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 368; 116 S.E.2d 738; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 474


September 15, 1960, Argued  
October 11, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Alverson. June 7, 1960.

William L. Gower and others, as duly admitted and practicing attorneys at law with offices located in the City of Atlanta, (in their own behalf and for others similarly situated as practicing a profession), filed their petition for equitable relief against the city. Constitutional attacks under both the State and Federal Constitutions were made on various sections of the General Tax Ordinance of the city as amended (on March 23, 1960) by the mayor and board of aldermen, which amendment recites that, "pursuant to Georgia laws 1959, page 3251, as amended by act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved March 17th 1960 and known as House Bill 1007, the General Tax Ordinance for 1960," adopted October 5, 1959, is amended, etc. The ordinance as amended levied a tax of $ 50 for the remainder of the year 1960 on the practice of professions licensed by the State. The prayers were that these sections as set forth in stated paragraphs of the petition be declared illegal, null, and void, that the city be enjoined from enforcing the ordinance and the sections thereof, and for other relief.

A temporary restraining [***2] order was granted. On the hearing for an interlocutory injunction, counsel for the city made an oral motion to dismiss the petition in the nature of a general demurrer, which was denied. This judgment is assigned as error, it being contended that such ruling was error and "contrary to law with respect to each and every ground thereof."



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city sought review of a judgment from the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which issued a temporary order restraining the city from enforcing an amendment to its tax ordinance that required plaintiff attorneys to pay $ 50 because they practiced a profession licensed by the State.


OVERVIEW: The city relied upon 1959 Ga. Laws 3252 as amended by 1960 Ga. Laws 2847 as authority for the amendment to its tax ordinance. The act applied to cities with a population of more than 300,000 and allowed the city to exercise its discretion in imposing in an additional tax on all professions licensed and regulated by the State. Upon review, the court found that the Legislature was authorized to make a classification of the cities on the basis of population. It could pass a general law based upon such a classification if the classification had some reasonable relation to the subject matter of the law. The court found that all cities that had the required population under any future census could not come within the terms and provisions of 1959 Ga. Laws 3252. Thus, it was not a general law. The court concluded that the amendment did not add anything of substance to the invalid and unconstitutional act. Further, the State had no reasonable or substantial relation to the classification that granted cities with a population of over 300,00 to require an additional tax for all professions licensed and regulated by the State.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the temporary restraining order that enjoined the city from enforcing an amendment to its tax ordinance.

 

1266 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Wright v. State


No. 20937


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 228; 115 S.E.2d 331; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 434


June 14, 1960, Argued  
July 12, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Conspiracy to defraud State; constitutional question. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Andrews. April 18, 1960.

The grand jury of Fulton County returned an indictment against Frances B. Wright charging her with the offense of conspiracy with others to defraud the State of money. The indictment alleged: "that said accused, in the County of Fulton and State of Georgia, on the 20 day of January, 1958, with force and arms, accused being employees of the State of Georgia, did, with an unlawful and fraudulent intent to cheat and defraud the State of Georgia, conspire and agree with each other and with other parties to the grand-jurors unknown to defraud, cheat and illegally obtain from the State of Georgia money belonging to the State of Georgia, by means of a scheme and artful practice which the accused engaged in, as follows: When a need of articles or material for the use of the Department of State Parks was indicated, accused would cause a requisition to be prepared for such articles or material and transmitted to the Purchasing Department of the State of Georgia together with one or more documents purporting to be 'bids' in which certain firms or persons named in said documents [***2] purported to offer to sell the said desired articles or materials to the State of Georgia at specified prices, said purported 'bids' not being genuine bids and being at prices higher than the articles and materials could be purchased in the open market or through competitive bids and known to accused to be such, and purchase orders would then be issued by the Office of the State Supervisor of Purchases for the said articles or materials, based on the lowest of the said purported 'bids,' authorizing the purchase of the designated articles or materials at the price shown thereon, and accused would then order said articles or material at prices less than the prices authorized by said purchase orders and have the said articles and materials delivered to the State of Georgia and procure money belonging to the State of Georgia from the funds allocated to the said Department of State Parks in payment for said articles and materials at the price authorized by the said 'purchase orders', thereby procuring for accused's benefit the difference between the actual purchase price and the price authorized by said purchase orders."

The indictment further alleged that through various transactions [***3] transpiring one to two years before the date the conspiracy was entered into the defendant pursuant to the conspiracy obtained named sums of money from the State.

The defendant filed a general demurrer to the indictment on the grounds that Code § 26-4201, under which the indictment was drawn, was unconstitutional, and because the indictment charged no violation of any penal statute of Georgia.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which convicted defendant of conspiracy to defraud the State.


OVERVIEW: A grand jury returned an indictment against defendant charging her with the offense of conspiracy with others to defraud the State of Georgia of money. Defendant filed a general demurrer to the indictment on the grounds that Ga. Code Ann. § 26-4201, under which the indictment was drawn, was unconstitutional and because the indictment charged no violation of any penal statute of Georgia. The court affirmed with respect to the first issue and adhered to its prior rulings upholding the constitutionality of the statute. However, the court reversed defendant's conviction because the indictment failed to charged that defendant conspired with others to cheat or defraud the State of any designated funds or any particular amount of money. Hence, it was fatally defective in failing to allege against what money of the State the conspiracy in which defendant was allegedly involved was aimed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment of conviction.

 

1267 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Parker v. Mayor, etc., of Savannah


No. 20933


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 210; 115 S.E.2d 555; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 429


June 13, 1960, Submitted  
July 7, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Chatham Superior Court. Before Judge McWhorter. April 1, 1960.

The appeal is from a judgment of the Superior Court of Chatham County sustaining a motion to dismiss the petition brought by named parties for themselves and others similarly situated, against the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, seeking to declare unconstitutional, upon numerous grounds, House Bill 990, 1960 acts of the General Assembly (Ga. L. 1960, pp. 2213-2220), which purports to incorporate within the City of Savannah certain territory of which petitioners are residents, and to enjoin the City of Savannah from "extending its corporate limits or otherwise availing itself of the powers and authority conferred upon it by said act."



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner citizens sought review of a judgment by the Superior Court of Chatham County (Georgia), which sustained respondents, a city and its mayor's, motion to dismiss the citizens' petition seeking to declare unconstitutional House Bill 990, Acts of the General Assembly (Ga. L. 1960, pp. 2213-2220), that purported to incorporate within the city territory of which the citizens were residents.


OVERVIEW: The citizens argued that House Bill 990 violated Ga. Const. art. 3, § 7, para. 15, Ga. Code Ann. § 2-1915, (1) because the intention to apply for such legislation was not advertised in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements were published once a week for three weeks as required; (2) because the first advertisement was void as it appeared on a legal holiday, January 1, 1960; and (3) because there were only two other such advertisements, which appeared on January 8, and January 15, 1960. The trial court granted respondents' motion to dismiss the citizens' petition. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court ruled that the advertisement appearing on January 1, 1960, a legal holiday, was valid. The court rejected the citizens' argument that §§ 2-4 of the annexation act, providing for credits to citizens who installed sanitary and storm sewer facilities in the annexation area, were not germane to the annexation of the territory. The court reasoned that the citizens could not attack § 6 of the annexation act because that section did not injure them, as they would pay taxes equally with other taxpayers receiving like services.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment, which sustained respondents' motion and dismissed the citizen's petition to enjoin the incorporation of their territory into the city.

 

1268 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Stephens v. Sudderth


No. 20938


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 222; 115 S.E.2d 519; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 432


June 14, 1960, Submitted  
July 7, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Douglas Superior Court. Before Judge Foster. March 21, 1960.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A divorce decree granted defendant father custody of children. Plaintiff mother filed a petition for custody. The father filed a motion to dismiss, which asserted that the mother did not file exceptions to the divorce decree, that the decree was not modifiable, and that the law regarding custody modification was unconstitutional. The Douglas Superior Court (Georgia) granted the motion and dismissed the mother's petition. The mother appealed.


OVERVIEW: The court noted that the law mentioned in the father's motion to dismiss referred to urban renewal powers, which had no bearing on the subject of custody. The court reversed. The court acknowledged that a judgment fixing custody of children in a divorce was conclusive between the parties and that the principle of res judicata was applicable. However, pursuant to Ga. Code Ann. § 74-107, when a petition was brought in the nature of habeas corpus, alleging material changes of circumstances substantially affecting the interest and welfare of the children, the proceeding was an independent one and was not an effort to modify the original decree. Additionally, the trial court erred in dismissing the petition because the attempted constitutional attack did not refer to any modification law but instead referred to the urban renewal law. Thus, the motion to dismiss did not show any grounds for dismissal.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the grant of the father's motion to dismiss and the dismissal of the mother's petition for custody.

 

1269 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Middleton v. Moody


No. 20940


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 237; 115 S.E.2d 567; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 436


June 14, 1960, Argued  
July 7, 1960, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 19, 1960.


PRIOR HISTORY: Mandamus. Brantley Superior Court. Before Judge Roddenberry. April 1, 1960.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant county political party sought review of a judgment from the Brantley Superior Court (Georgia), which granted mandamus to plaintiff candidate and ordered the party to adopt, promulgate, publish, and certify the report of the recount committee, which declared the candidate to be the party's official nominee for the office of superintendent of schools.


OVERVIEW: After the primary elections, another individual was declared the party's official nominee. The candidate demanded a recount of the ballots. The recount committee determined that the candidate won by one vote, and its report declared her the party's nominee. The individual filed a challenge with the executive committee, and the executive committee again named him the party's nominee. Upon review, the court found that the recount committee was authorized to act under § 6 of 1941 Ga. Laws 432. The party argued that the action taken by a majority of its executive committee on the individual's challenge superceded and vacated the prior findings and report of the recount committee. The court found that the findings and report of the recount committee were the final and conclusive to all questions respecting the validity of the primary election under §§ 7 and 12 of 1941 Ga. Laws 432. The executive committee's subsequent action was a nullity because it lacked the authority to undertake the action. Under § 14 of 1941 Ga. Laws 432, mandamus was the remedy available to the candidate to enforce the findings and report of the recount committee.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the writ of mandamus that ordered the party to declare the candidate its official nominee for superintendent.

 

1270 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


United Hosps. Serv. Ass'n v. Fulton County


No. 20847


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 30; 114 S.E.2d 524; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 381


April 12, 1960, Argued  
May 5, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Pharr. January 25, 1960.

United Hospitals Service Association of Atlanta, Georgia, sought to enjoin the taxing authorities of Fulton County from advertising and selling its property under a tax execution for the year 1958, and to have the assessment against its property declared to be void, because the property is used to house the operations of a non-profit hospital-service corporation, created under Code (Ann.) Ch. 99-10 (Ga. L. 1950, pp. 335, 340), and it is constitutionally entitled to tax exemption by the Constitution (Code § 2-5404), which authorizes the General Assembly to confer the exemption granted in Code (Ann.) § 99-1018 (Ga. L. 1950, pp. 335, 340). The county authorities filed a general demurrer to the petition for injunctive relief which was sustained after a hearing, and the exception is to that judgment. The only question for decision is whether or not the petitioner is an institution of "purely public charity" as referred to in the Constitution, thus authorizing the General Assembly to confer upon it the tax exemption. The demurrer made the constitutional attack on the tax exemption contained in Georgia Laws [***2] 1950, pp. 335, 340 (Code, Ann., § 99-1018) as violative of art. 7, sec. 1, par. 4 of the Constitution (Code § 2-5404); and the lower court, in sustaining the general demurrer, in effect held the act to be unconstitutional.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff hospital challenged an order of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) that sustained defendant county's demurrer to the hospital's request for an injunction to prevent the county from selling the hospital's property under a tax execution.


OVERVIEW: The hospital owned property that was used for the operation of the hospital. The county levied a tax execution against the property and sought to sell it. The hospital filed a request for an injunction to prevent the sale of the property, and the county filed a demurrer. The trial court sustained the demurrer, and the hospital sought review. The court affirmed, holding that the hospital was not entitled to a tax exemption as a charitable organization. The hospital's claim that it was a charitable organization did not make it one. The hospital had no requirement that all those needing medical attention were to receive it or that those who could pay were to be excluded. Exempting the hospital would have exempted a competitor of free enterprise, which violated the Georgia Constitution. Ga. Code Ann. § 2-5404.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order sustaining the county's demurrer to the hospital's request for an injunction.

 

1271 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


State Highway Dep't v. McClain


No. 20766


Supreme Court of Georgia


216 Ga. 1; 114 S.E.2d 125; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 373


January 11, 1960, Argued  
April 12, 1960, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied April 27, 1960.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction, etc. Dougherty Superior Court. Before Judge Crow. October 29, 1959.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Georgia State Highway Department filed a bill of exceptions to the judgment of the Superior Court of Dougherty County (Georgia), which dissolved the order restraining plaintiff landowners from prosecuting their suits for damages against the county for takings, sustained their constitutional attacks on Ga. Code § 95-1712, and declared that the Department had a duty to defend the suits and pay damages awarded against the county.


OVERVIEW: The landowners filed petitions in the county court against the county, seeking damages for a barrier constructed that destroyed their only means of ingress and egress to and from an intersection of highways. The Department then filed its action seeking a restraining order, which was denied on appeal. The court held that the landowners' suits against the county did not claim that their property had been taken or physically damaged for a public purpose, but that their suits were based entirely on the proposition that the value of their properties was depreciated solely because of the loss of access from the highways in consequence of the construction of a State-aid road not adjoining their lands, but over which the Department had assumed exclusive jurisdiction. The court held that under the circumstances, Ga. Code § 95-1712 did not offend the Ga. Const. art. 1, § 3, para. 1. The court held that because Ga. Code § 95-1712 was not subject to the constitutional attacks, the county judge erred in holding that the landowners' suits pending in county court had not been prematurely instituted and that the landowners should be permitted to proceed with their prosecution.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in favor of the landowners.

 

1272 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Anthony v. State Highway Dep't


No. 20826


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 853; 113 S.E.2d 768; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 359


March 15, 1960, Argued  
April 7, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Muscogee Superior Court. Before Judge Thompson. December 12, 1959.

The exception is to the judgment of the Superior Court of Muscogee County denying the injunctive relief prayed for and dismissing the petition. The sole relief sought by the petition is to enjoin the defendant, State Highway Department, from removing described improvements from land which the plaintiff alleges the defendant is seeking to condemn under authority of the act of the General Assembly, approved March 13, 1957 (Ga. L. 1957, p. 387 et seq.; Code, Ann., §§ 36-601a -- 36-616a), until a final determination and award have been made in the pending condemnation proceedings, and until the plaintiff has been paid just and adequate compensation. He contends that, although he is permitted an appeal from the award made by the master, to permit removal of the buildings from his land prior to the trial of his case on appeal, will prevent his establishing the value of his property on the jury trial. The petition as amended alleges that section 13 of the 1957 act, supra, denies the plaintiff the right to be first paid just and adequate compensation before the taking of his property, in violation of art.  [***2] 1, sec. 3, par. 1, of the Constitution of Georgia (Code § 2-301).

The trial court in its order denying the relief and dismissing the petition made the following findings of fact: that, at the interlocutory hearing on December 5, 1959, it was established that the special master had made an award on December 3, 1959, in the amount of $ 50,000 to be paid to several persons (one of whom was the plaintiff); that the return of the special master had been filed with the court; that, on December 4, 1959, the $ 50,000 awarded by the special master had been paid into the registry of the court; and that, prior to the interlocutory hearing, the return of the special master had been made the judgment of the court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff condemnee challenged the judgment of the Superior Court of Muscogee County (Georgia), which denied the injunctive relief requested by the condemnee and dismissed his petition. The condemnee had filed an action against defendant condemnor to enjoin it from removing improvements from land that the condemnee alleged that the condemnor was seeking to condemn pursuant to 1957 Ga. Laws 387, § 13, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-601a - 36-616a.


OVERVIEW: The condemnee claimed that the condemnor should have been prevented from removing the improvements until a final determination and award had been made in the pending condemnation proceedings and until the condemnee had been paid just and adequate compensation. The trial court had previously made an award to several persons including the condemnee. On appeal, the court held that deposit of the compensation assessed by the special master into the court as provided by 1957 Ga. Laws 387, § 13, satisfied the constitutional requirement that the condemnee receive adequate compensation. The court found that it could not say that the legislature abused its discretion in providing that upon payment into the court registry the trial court could enter judgment vesting fee-simple title in the condemnor. The court ruled that the taking was complete when the trial court acting under 1957 Ga. Laws 387, § 13, entered judgment condemning the property and vesting title in the condemnor. The court noted that upon trial the issue was the value of the property at the time it was condemned and titled vested in the condemnor.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's denial of the condemnee's request for injunctive relief.

 

1273 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Prince v. Thompson


No. 20835


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 860; 113 S.E.2d 772; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 362


March 15, 1960, Argued  
April 7, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Zoning appeal; constitutional question. Richmond Superior Court. Before Judge Kennedy. November 13, 1959.



DISPOSITION: Dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff sought review of the denial of a motion to dismiss an appeal to the Superior Court of Richmond County (Georgia) from a decision of the City-County Board of Zoning Appeals of the City of Augusta and Richmond County that approved a variance in zoning of certain property.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the court held that the parties did not seek a de novo trial by jury. Rather, the court held that the record failed to specify a zoning act, laws, or authority under which the appeal was sought. Because no legislative act or statute was cited or referred to in the record, and there was no specific act or statute that was claimed to be unconstitutional, the court held that the record failed to present a question for it to decide.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the writ of error.

 

1274 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Crow v. McCallum


No. 20726


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 692; 113 S.E.2d 203; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 308


January 11, 1960, Argued  
February 11, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Habersham Superior Court. Before Judge Brooke from Blue Ridge Circuit. September 30, 1959.

This is a suit for mandamus by certain named persons who, under the allegations of the petition, constitute the Board of Commissioners of the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund of Georgia, against certain named individuals who are alleged to be officials of the City of Cornelia, Georgia, seeking to require the named individuals to pay over to the said Fund amounts due out of the fines and forfeitures collected in said city during the years 1953-1958. To this petition, the defendants filed their plea and answer, in which they raised numerous defenses as will appear in the body of this opinion. The petitioners filed demurrers to every paragraph of the answer except those which simply admitted or denied certain allegations of the petition. All of these demurrers were sustained.

The case was then submitted on a stipulation of facts and the pleadings to the judge without the intervention of a jury for decision of all questions of law and fact. Thereafter, a judgment was entered for the petitioners, requiring the defendants to do all acts necessary to pay over the sums due [***2] to the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund. A motion for new trial on the general grounds was made and denied. The exception here is to this judgment and to the judgment sustaining the demurrers to the various paragraphs of the answer.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner Board of Commissioners of the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund of Georgia sought review by a writ of mandamus of a decision of the trial court (Georgia), which sustained the demurrers of the board to every paragraph of the answer and entered judgment for the board, requiring defendants city officials to do all acts necessary to pay over the sums due to the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund.


OVERVIEW: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court finding for the board, and requiring the city officials to pay over the sum due to the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund. The court found the judgments complained of were not erroneous for any reason assigned. The court held that there was no merit in the city official's contentions that the city should have been made a party to the proceeding. The court held that it was not error to sustain the general denial of the paragraph in which the city officials were to produce certain books and records at the trial, because it was evasive and it had not alleged what documents the city officials did not have and could not produce at the trial. The court found the paragraph uncertain and incomplete. The court found that it was not error to sustain demurrers to each of the paragraphs of the answer that attempted to attack as unconstitutional, by violating stated provisions of the state Constitution, the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund Act, 1950 Ga. Laws para. 50 et seq. The court found the attempts to attack all of the acts in their entirety completely insufficient to draw into question the constitutionality of any act.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court finding for the board, and requiring defendants city officials to do all acts necessary to pay over the sums due to the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund. The court sustained the demurrers of the board to every paragraph of the answer.

 

1275 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


McCallum v. Moore


No. 20753


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 705; 113 S.E.2d 202; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 313


January 11, 1960, Argued  
February 11, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Haralson Superior Court. Before Judge Foster. October 30, 1959.

This petition was brought by certain named persons who are alleged to constitute the Board of Commissioners of the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund of Georgia against certain named persons, who are alleged to be officials of the City of Buchanan, Georgia, seeking mandamus to require the defendants to pay over to the plaintiffs sums alleged to be due the said Fund out of the fines and forfeitures collected in the City of Buchanan. The defendants filed their demurrers to the petition, all of which were sustained. The exception here is to the sustaining of three grounds of the general demurrer.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error police fund commissioners sought review of the decision of the Haralson Superior Court (Georgia) that sustained three grounds of a general demurrer filed by defendant in error city in the police fund commissioners' action for a writ of mandamus to require the city to pay over sums alleged to be due out of the fines and forfeitures collected in the city.


OVERVIEW: The police fund commissioners filed suit against the city and sought a writ of mandamus that required them to pay over to the police fund commissioners sums alleged to be due out of fines and forfeitures collected. The city demurred to the petition and the demurrer was sustained. The police fund commissioners appealed and the court reversed. The court reversed because the city failed to specify which law allegedly violated the provisions of the Constitution of the State of Georgia and it was not stated how and wherein such law violated the Constitution of the State of Georgia. The court found no merit in the city's contention that § 10 of the Peace Officers Annuity and Benefit Fund Act, Ga. L. 1950, p. 50, was unconstitutional because it violated art. 7, § 2, par. 1 of the Constitution of the State of Georgia in that it was an attempt to impose a tax for an unauthorized purpose. The court found that fines and bond forfeitures were property subject-matters of legislation and the act did not violate the constitution.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed.

 

1276 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Oxford v. J. D. Jewell


No. 20690


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 616; 112 S.E.2d 601; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 281


November 9, 1959, Argued  
January 8, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Tax refund. Hall Superior Court. Before Judge Kelley. September 8, 1959.

The exception is to a judgment of the Superior Court of Hall County in favor of the plaintiff, J. D. Jewell, Inc., in an action against Dixon Oxford as State Revenue Commissioner for a refund of sales taxes. The case was tried by the judge upon a stipulation of facts without the intervention of a jury.

The plaintiff was a registered dealer under the Georgia Retailers' and Consumers' Sales and Use Tax Act (Ga. L. 1951, p. 360; Code, Ann., § 92-3401a, et seq.) as amended, engaged in selling food products; and, as such, it made sales of poultry to the United States government, that is, to a military establishment thereof located at Fort Benning, on which it paid sales taxes in the amount of $ 199.56 to the defendant.

The sole question presented for decision is whether, under the act, a retailer is required to pay sales taxes on retail sales made to the United States government.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant State Revenue Commissioner appealed a decision from the Superior Court of Hall County (Georgia) that granted a refund of sales tax to plaintiff taxpayer, a retailer who was a registered dealer under the Georgia Retailers' and Consumers' Sales and Use Tax Act (Act), Ga. Code Ann. § 92-3401a et seq., and made retail sales to the United States government.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer made sales to a military base, on which it paid taxes. The court reversed the sales tax refund granted in favor of the taxpayer. The court reasoned that the tax imposed by the Act was on the retailer for the privilege of engaging in the retail business in the state. The failure of the retailer to collect the tax did not relieve him from paying the tax. The court strictly construed tax exemptions. The Act excluded sales that cannot constitutionally be used as a base of the tax. Since the tax was upon the retailer, a tax was not levied against the sale to the United States, which the state would not have authority to tax. Thus, the Act did not violate the immunity of the United States from state taxation, provided by the U.S. Constitution. There was also no merit to the argument that the Act violated the U.S. Const. art 6, cl. 2. Further, the Act did not violate equal protection because there was no showing that the State Revenue Commissioner could not collect the tax on sales made to the United States. Any discrimination resulted from the federal constitution, which was a superior authority to the Act.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the sales tax refund that was granted to the taxpayer.

 

1277 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Adams v. Ray


No. 20680


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 656; 113 S.E.2d 100; 1960 Ga. LEXIS 295


October 13, 1959, Argued; October 14, 1959, Argued  
January 8, 1960, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied February 11, 1960.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for injunction. Houston Superior Court. Before Judge Anderson. August 31, 1959.

The plaintiffs in error filed their petition for injunction against certain named persons constituting the Structural Pest Control Commission, created by act of the General Assembly under what is known as the "Structural Pest Control Act" (Ga. L. 1955, pp. 564 et seq.). It was alleged that the commission had notified the plaintiffs in error to show cause before them on a named date why their licenses should not be revoked for reasons set out in the letter. The petition attempted to attack the above act as being unconstitutional because violative of stated provisions of the Constitution. A general demurrer to the petition was sustained, and the petition was dismissed. The exception here is to this judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error license holders filed a petition for an injunction against defendant in error Structural Pest Control Commission after the Commission had notified the license holders that they had to show cause as to why their licenses should not be revoked. The Superior Court of Houston County (Georgia) sustained the Commission's general demurrer to the petition and the license holders excepted to that judgment.


OVERVIEW: The license holders' petition attempted to attack the Structural Pest Control Act, 1955 Ga. Laws 564 et seq., as being unconstitutional. The court noted that in order to raise a question as to the constitutionality of a law, the statute which was challenged and the provision of the constitution alleged to have been violated must both be clearly specified. The license holders' petition attacked the statute as amended but did not provide when it was amended, where it was amended, or how it was amended. The court also determined that the petition did not point out definitely the act or portion of the act under attack. The court was not required to take judicial notice of the acts of the legislature. Therefore, the court concluded that the attack upon the Structural Pest Control Act as amended was insufficient to raise any constitutional question as to any act of the legislature. Finally, the court determined that the Commission had the authority to establish regulations and that the regulation in question that applied to the license holders had been validly enacted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1278 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Kellett v. Fulton County


No. 20658


Supreme Court of Georgia
