215 Ga. 551; 111 S.E.2d 364; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 537


October 14, 1959, Argued  
November 4, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Alverson. August 6, 1959.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff sought review of a judgment of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which sustained defendant county's demurrer to plaintiff's petition in his action to challenge the county's condemnation of a parcel of property pursuant to the terms of the Act of 1957.


OVERVIEW: The county sought to condemn property pursuant to the Act for the purpose of constructing a juvenile facility. Plaintiff alleged that the Act was unconstitutional, that the county commissioners' authorization of the institution of the condemnation proceeding constituted an unlawful delegation of legislative power, that the proposed project was unreasonable in its scope, and that the county's desire to condemn property for the construction of a juvenile facility constituted an abuse of discretion. The trial court sustained the county's general demurrers to the petition. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding (1) the Act of 1957 provided an adequate method for determining just and adequate compensation for property sought to be condemned and was not inconsistent with Ga. Const. art. 1, § 3, para. 1, and, therefore, the Act was not unconstitutional, (2) the county commissioners' reliance on various advisory committees in rendering the decision to condemn the property was not illegal and its authorization of the condemnation did not constitute an unlawful delegation of authority, and (3) there was no showing that the county abused its discretion or acted in bad faith.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1279 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Bookholt v. General Motors Corp.


No. 20631


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 391; 110 S.E.2d 642; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 489


September 17, 1959, Argued  
October 9, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Breach of implied warranty; constitutional question. Fulton Civil Court. Before Judge Henson. June 22, 1959.

This suit was brought to recover damages by an ultimate consumer against a manufacturer for breach of implied warranty, under the provisions of Ga. L. 1957, p. 405 (Code, Ann., § 96-307), which provides: "The manufacturer of any personal property sold as new property, either directly or through wholesale or retail dealers, or any other person, shall warrant the following to the ultimate consumer, who, however, must exercise caution when purchasing to detect defects, and provided there is no express covenant of warranty and no agreement to the contrary: 1. The article sold is merchantable and reasonably suited to the use intended. 2. The manufacturer knows of no latent defects undisclosed."

This act of the General Assembly was attacked as unconstitutional as violating the State and Federal Constitutions for stated reasons. The motion to dismiss was sustained, and the exception here is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff consumer brought an action against defendant manufacturer for breach of implied warranty under the provisions of Ga. Code Ann. § 96-307. The Civil Court, Fulton County (Georgia), dismissed the action and the consumer appealed.


OVERVIEW: In a breach of implied warranty action by the consumer against the manufacturer, the manufacturer argued that § 96-307 was unconstitutional as violative of equal protection. The trial court granted the motion to dismiss. On the consumer's appeal, the court reversed, holding that the act applied alike to all manufacturers of personal property and that it was reasonable to classify manufacturers apart from other remote sellers for the purposes of the legislation. The manufacturer had control over the materials and production methods used, labor and workmanship, and quality control procedures. This control would not be present in other remote sellers. The statute also did not interfere with liberty of contract because the act was not contractual. An implied warranty added nothing to the agreement of the parties, but simply stated the legal consequences attached to a described transaction. It was not dependent on any contract either in fact or by implication.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment dismissing the action.

 

1280 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Rollins v. State


No. 20574


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 437; 111 S.E.2d 63; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 506


September 16, 1959, Argued  
October 9, 1959, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 4, 1959.


PRIOR HISTORY: Conspiracy to defraud the State; constitutional question, etc. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Moore. June 8, 1959.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the decision of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which overruled his demurrer and motion to quash the indictment of conspiracy to defraud the state.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with conspiracy to defraud the state. Defendant demurred and filed a motion to quash the indictment on the grounds that Ga. Code Ann. §§ 26-4201-4204 were unconstitutional. The trial court overruled the demurrer and the motion to quash. The court found that there was never a prohibition against the legislature enacting a statute making a conspiracy a penal offense. The court also found that there was no merit to the contention that § 26-4201 was too vague, indefinite, or uncertain in its terms to constitute a crime. The court held that the conspiracy which § 26-4201 prohibited and punished was clearly a substantive penal offense in Georgia, which did not offend the due process clause of the Constitution of the United States or the due-process provision of Georgia's Constitution. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court which overruled defendant's motion to quash the indictment of conspiracy to defraud the state and overruled defendant's demurrer.

 

1281 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


DeKalb County v. Broome


Nos. 20518, 20527


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 203; 109 S.E.2d 769; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 435


June 9, 1959, Submitted  
July 8, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Declaratory judgment; constitutional question. DeKalb Superior Court. Before Judge Brown from Flint Circuit. April 2, 1959.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed on the main bill of exceptions. Cross-bill of exceptions dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant county sought review of an order of the Superior Court of DeKalb County (Georgia), which entered judgment in favor of plaintiff sheriff in his action to claim legal rights on fund collected.


OVERVIEW: The county sheriff collected and remitted to the state revenue commissioner an amount he had accumulated from fees and penalties charged and collected for each indorsement he placed on delinquent applications for motor-vehicle tags under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 68-201. The commissioner repaid the total sum to him, and the county claimed that it was a fund to which it was entitled, and requested that the sheriff pay the money into the county treasury. The sheriff filed an action claiming a legal right to the fund, and by amendment, claiming that the salary act, 1956 Ga. Laws 2915, as amended by 1958 Ga. Laws 2673, was unconstitutional. The county's answer admitted the correctness of the amount in controversy, and claimed a right to the funds. The sheriff's demurrer to the answer was overruled, but the trial court found that the sheriff was entitled to the funds. The court affirmed. The sheriff, in collecting the funds, acted as an agent of the commissioner and was personally paid for the services he rendered. The funds were not compensation earned in the sheriff's capacity of sheriff, but compensation for being an agent of the commissioner.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order from the trial court.

 

1282 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Moore v. Burnett


No. 20486


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 146; 109 S.E.2d 605; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 415


May 11, 1959, Submitted  
June 5, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus. Dougherty Superior Court. Before Judge Lilly. March 19, 1959.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate sought review of a decision by the Superior Court of Dougherty County (Georgia), which denied him a writ of habeas corpus and dismissed his petition.


OVERVIEW: After his conviction for violation of a city ordinance and while his case was pending on certiorari from the convicting court, the inmate voluntarily dismissed his petition for certiorari. Thereafter, after being taken into custody, the inmate filed his petition for a writ of habeas corpus. A general demurrer to the petition and motion to quash the writ were sustained, the writ was dismissed, and the inmate was remanded to the custody of the acting chief of police. The court held that because the inmate attacked the constitutionality of the ordinance in the convicting court, which ruling thereon was adverse to him, and later voluntarily dismissed his petition for certiorari, the question of the constitutionality of the ordinance became res adjudicata and was unreviewable collaterally by habeas corpus.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1283 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Todd v. Morgan


No. 20416


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 220; 109 S.E.2d 803; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 440


April 13, 1959, Argued  
June 5, 1959, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 8, 1959 and July 23, 1959.


PRIOR HISTORY: Cancellation, etc. Floyd Superior Court. Before Judge Hicks. January 30, 1959.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant titleholder sought review of an order of the Superior Court of Floyd County (Georgia), which, on remand, directed a verdict in favor of plaintiff grantee and denied the titleholder's motion for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict in an action seeking a determination of the parties' rights and contesting the constitutionality of § 1 of the Act of 1941, 1941 Ga. Laws 487.


OVERVIEW: The grantee filed an action seeking a determination of the parties' title rights to a deed used as security on a debt and challenging the constitutionality of § 1 of the Act of 1941, 1941 Ga. Laws 487. If constitutional under the petition, the title reverted to the grantor in the deed to secure debt and the title holder's title based upon title in the grantor was good, if unconstitutional, there was no reversion and title was in the grantee. The trial court initially dismissed the action on demurrer, but on remand, directed a verdict in favor of the grantee. On appeal, the court held that it was of the opinion that § 1 of the Act as applied to the deed to secure the debt, which was executed prior to the passage and effective date of the Act, was unconstitutional because it was in violation of U.S. Const. art. I, § 10. The court also found that the Act violated Ga. Const. art. I, § 3, para. 2, which prohibited the state from passing any retroactive law or any law impairing the obligations of contracts.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court.

 

1284 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Murphey v. Murphey


No. 20422


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 19; 108 S.E.2d 872; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 383


April 15, 1959, Argued  
May 8, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Alimony. DeKalb Superior Court. Before Judge Guess. January 21, 1959.

Mrs. Nancy Elizabeth Betts Murphey brought a petition against Candler Ambrose Murphey, Jr., and alleged: The plaintiff is the mother of two minor children, Nancy Ann Murphey and Candler Ambrose Murphey, III, whose custody is now in the plaintiff by virtue of a final decree of the Superior Court of DeKalb County in a habeas corpus proceeding between the parties. A total divorce was granted to both parties by a decree of DeKalb Superior Court on December 22, 1955, in an uncontested action brought by the defendant against the plaintiff; and at the time of the final decree, the custody of the children was awarded to the defendant in the present case, the plaintiff in that case. There is in effect no valid order providing for the payment by the defendant of support for the two minor children. The plaintiff brings her action under and by virtue of an act approved March 21, 1958 (Ga. L. 1958, pp. 204-206), and prays that the court, after hearing evidence as to the needs of the children and the ability of the father to provide therefor, pass an order fixing the amount of support money that he shall provide in order [***2] to fulfill his natural duty to supply the necessaries of life for the children. The plaintiff further prays for a rule nisi requiring the defendant to show cause why such order should not be passed, and for process.

The defendant filed a general demurrer on the following grounds: (1) The petition fails to set forth a cause of action against the defendant. (2) The act approved March 21, 1958 (Ga. L. 1958, pp. 204-206) is unconstitutional and void, being in violation of the Constitution of Georgia, art. I, sec. III, par. II (Code, Ann., § 2-302), if applied to a divorce case or any other case concerning the support of minor children in which a final judgment has been rendered prior to the passage of the act, for the reason that, as so applied, the act would be retroactive. (3) The petition shows that there has been a final decree of divorce between the parties, and subsequently to this decree an order was passed awarding the custody of the minor children to the plaintiff; and for this reason the rights of the parties have been fixed in a solemn judgment, and the petition sets forth no cause of action against the defendant.

All of the grounds of the demurrer were sustained by the [***3] trial judge, and the petition was dismissed. The exception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff mother sought review of an order of the Superior Court of DeKalb County (Georgia), which sustained defendant father's demurrer and dismissed her petition seeking child support.


OVERVIEW: The mother and father were divorced and custody was awarded to the mother. She filed a petition seeking child support under O.C.G.A. § 30-301, which was passed after the final judgment of divorce was entered. The Act allowed for entry of orders fixing amounts for child support. The trial court sustained the father's demurrer and dismissed the mother's petition. On appeal, the court held that the mother's petition alleged sufficient facts to have brought it within the provisions of the Act, as the Act did not require that the children should be in a destitute condition because of the father's failure to provide them with necessaries. The court determined that the Act, when applied to the case, created no new obligation and took away no vested defense, the procedure for enforcing the already existing obligation of the father to take care of his children had changed, but the court held that the General Assembly had the power to change the remedy for enforcing an existing obligation without making the Act retroactive in violation of Ga. Const. art. I, § 3, para. 2. The court found that the trial court erred in sustaining the father's demurrer.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the trial court.

 

1285 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Oxford v. Nehi Corp.


No. 20380


Supreme Court of Georgia


215 Ga. 74; 109 S.E.2d 329; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 398


March 9, 1959, Argued  
April 9, 1959, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Adhered to on Rehearing May 8, 1959. Rehearing Denied June 5, 1959.


PRIOR HISTORY: Certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia -- 98 Ga. App. 779 (106 S. E. 2d 857).



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state tax commissioner sought review of a decision by the Court of Appeals (Georgia) that affirmed the trial court's decision that gross receipts from business done within the state by plaintiff taxpayer included only gross receipts from shipments made from the tax payer's bottling plant to its bottlers located within the state.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer argued that under Ga. Code. Ann. § 92-3113(4)(c), gross receipts for tax purposes included only receipts from shipments made from the tax payer's plant to its bottlers located within the state. The tax commissioner argued that § 92-3113(4)(c), when construed with the remainder of the statute and with Ga. Code. Ann. § 92-3002(n), meant that where products were produced, manufactured or stored within the state and shipped to customers outside the state, the gross receipts derived therefrom were to be included in the tax payer's gross receipts for tax purposes. The court rejected the tax commissioner's argument and affirmed the decisions of the lower court and the trial court. The court pointed out that an amendment to the tax statute eliminated the provision that the sales ratio included all sales made within the state to all sales made everywhere including outside the state and substituted a gross receipts ratio in its place. The court concluded that the legislature intended, by its amendment, to provide that gross receipts be deprived from products shipped or delivered to customers within the state.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court that upheld the trial court's decision that the tax payer's tax liability was based only of gross receipts for products shipped or delivered from its plant to customers within the state.

 

1286 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Bailey v. Housing Authority of Bainbridge


No. 20373


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 790; 107 S.E.2d 812; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 347


February 9, 1959, Argued  
March 6, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Decatur Superior Court. Before Judge Horne. December 15, 1958.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff owner sought review of an order of the Superior Court of Decatur County (Georgia), which sustained the general demurrers of defendants, housing authority and city, in the owner's action seeking an injunction against condemnation proceedings.


OVERVIEW: The owner was given a notice of condemnation by the housing authority. She filed a petition seeking an injunction against the condemnation proceedings, and the trial court sustained the general demurrers of the housing authority and the city. On appeal, the court held that the Urban Redevelopment Law, 1955 Ga. Laws 354, gave the housing authority and the city the authority to proceed with condemnation proceedings. The court determined that the taking of the owner's property was for a public purpose and that powers of taxation and eminent domain might have been exercised. The court held that the Urban Redevelopment Law was expressly authorized by the Georgia Constitution as amended and that the condemnation proceedings were not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court.

 

1287 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Tomlinson v. Sadler


No. 20281


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 671; 107 S.E.2d 215; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 302


January 12, 1959, Argued  
February 6, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for damages. Grady Superior Court. Before Judge Lilly. September 4, 1958.



DISPOSITION: Transferred to the Court of Appeals.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, by next friend, sought review of a decision by the Superior Court of Grady County (Georgia), which overruled defendant's traverse of service, the plea to the jurisdiction, and the general demurrers in plaintiff's action for damages. Defendant argued that O.C.G.A. § 68-808 denied defendant due process of law and was therefore in violation of Ga. Const. art. I, § I, para. III and also in violation of U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OVERVIEW: Defendant claimed that the Act of 1957, amending the Act of 1937, being the Non-resident Motorist Act and of which O.C.G.A. § 68-808 was a part, was in violation of Ga. Const. art. III, para. VIII. Defendant maintained that because O.C.G.A. § 68-808 was unconstitutional, he had never been legally served, had never waived service, had designated nor appointed no one as agent to accept service for him, and had never appeared or pleaded. The court was of the opinion that the court of appeals had jurisdiction to review the writ of error. Under Ga. Const. art. 6, § 2, para. 4, (O.C.G.A. § 2-3704), the question of jurisdiction depended upon whether the constitutionality of any law of Georgia was in question. In order to raise a question as to the constitutionality of a law, the statute that defendant asserted to contravene the Constitution and the provisions of the constitution alleged to have been violated had to be clearly identified, and it had to be shown wherein the statute violated such constitutional provisions. Defendant's claims were too vague and general to identify the "law" claimed to be invalid or to show wherein and how the same violated the constitution.


OUTCOME: The court transferred the case to the court of appeals.

 

1288 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Irwin County Electric Membership Corp. v. Haddock


No. 20297


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 682; 107 S.E.2d 195; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 307


January 12, 1959, Argued  
February 6, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Ben Hill Superior Court. Before Judge Horne. December 30, 1958.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error electric membership corporation sought review of a judgment of the Ben Hill County Superior Court (Georgia), which overruled the corporation's general demurrers in defendant in error property owners' injunction action regarding the constitutionality of § 3 of the Act of 1939, 1939 Ga. Laws 312, 315; O.C.G.A. § 34A-137, amending the Electric Membership Corporation Act of 1937, 1937 Ga. Laws 644; O.C.G.A. § 34A.


OVERVIEW: The owners claimed that § 3 of the Act of 1939, regarding limitations periods for rights-of-way by corporations, was unconstitutional as being in violation of the Due Process Clause in that it would allow the corporation to take property of the owners other than by due process of law. They also asserted that § 3 was a special act seeking to vary a general law in violation of Ga. Const. art. I, § IV, para. I, without the free consent of the owners who were incapable of consent. The court found that the contention that the Act was unconstitutional in violation of the Due Process Clause was insufficient to invoke any court ruling. Further, the 1939 amendment was an amendment of a general law. The contention that the 1939 amendment was unconstitutional and void, as a special act varying the rights under a general law without the owners' consent, could not be sustained. The fixing of periods of limitation to operate in futuro was peculiarly a matter of legislative control. Moreover, § 3 conformed to the title of the Act and was not subject to the objection that the amendatory act referred to more than one subject matter and contained matter different from that expressed in the title.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1289 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Hortman v. Yarbrough


No. 20315


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 693; 107 S.E.2d 202; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 312


January 12, 1959, Submitted  
February 6, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Pulaski Superior Court. Before Judge Whaley. September 18, 1958.

Certain named persons, who are alleged to constitute the Georgia Board of Dental Examiners, brought a petition in their official capacities against Thomas Hortman, in which they alleged that Hortman was engaged in making impressions for dentures, in making dentures, and in repairing dentures which were not ordered by and returned to a licensed dentist; that such work and services constituted the practice of dentistry as defined in Ga. L. 1949, p. 1161, 1162, codified as Code (Ann.) § 84-701. It was further alleged that the defendant was not licensed or registered to perform such work and services, and does not possess a license to practice dentistry in Georgia. The petitioners sought to enjoin the defendant from the further practice of dentistry under the provisions of Ga. L. 1956, p. 25, codified as Code (Ann.) § 84-702.

The defendant filed a general demurrer, later amended or amplified, in which he attacked the act of 1956, supra, in whole and also certain specified portions as unconstitutional for various reasons. The general demurrer was overruled. The exception here is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION:  [***2] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged the order of the Superior Court of Pulaski County (Georgia) overruling his general demurrer to a complaint brought by appellee, the Board of Dental Examiners of Georgia, seeking an order enjoining him from the unlicensed practice of dentistry. The Board's action was brought under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 84-702 (as amended by 1956 Ga. Laws 25), which appellant claimed was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Appellant contended that O.C.G.A. § 84-702 (as amended by 1956 Ga. Laws 25), which allowed the Board to pursue injunctive relief without a showing that its remedies at law were inadequate, violated O.C.G.A. § 2-401, Ga. Const. art. I, § 4, para. 1, which prohibited special laws when a general law already existed. The court affirmed the lower court's judgment. The court noted that the practice of dentistry was a profession imbued with public interest and, therefore, was subject to reasonable regulation. The court concluded that § 2-401 only required a law to apply, uniformly, to all persons, matters, or things which it was intended to affect. The court found that O.C.G.A. § 84-702 (as amended by 1956 Ga. Laws 25) met this standard since any person, firm, or corporation who undertook to practice dentistry without a license could be enjoined upon a petition brought by the Board. This statute, enacted by the general assembly as a means to regulate the dental profession, had uniform application and was reasonably calculated to obtain the desired regulation. Thus, § 84-702 was a general and not a special law, and the trial court properly overruled appellant's demurrer.


OUTCOME: The trial court's denial of appellant's demurrer to the Board's complaint, seeking an injunction against appellant's practice of dentistry without a license, was affirmed.

 

1290 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Frankel v. Cone


No. 20309


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 733; 107 S.E.2d 819; 1959 Ga. LEXIS 327


January 15, 1959, Argued  
February 6, 1959, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 6, 1959.


PRIOR HISTORY: Action for damages; constitutional question. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Wood. October 14, 1958.

This is a review of a judgment of the Superior Court of Fulton County, overruling general and special demurrers of the plaintiff in error, Mrs. Pearl K. Frankel, one of the defendants below, to the petition seeking recovery of damages for personal injuries.

The issue presented is whether this defendant, the owner of an automobile involved in an accident, is deprived of her property without due process of law in contravention of section 1 of the fourteenth amendment of the Constitution of the United States (Code § 1-815), and art. 1, sec. 1, par. 3, of the Constitution of Georgia of 1945 (Code, Ann., § 2-103), and of equal protection of the law guaranteed to her by section 1 of the fourteenth amendment, supra, by the following act of the General Assembly approved March 4, 1955: "Every owner of a motor vehicle operated upon the public highways, roads or streets of this State shall be liable and responsible for the death, or injuries to person or property resulting from negligence in the operation of such motor vehicle, if said motor vehicle [***2] is being used in the prosecution of the business of such owner or if said motor vehicle is being operated for the benefit of such owner." Ga. L. 1955, pp. 454, 455 (Code, Ann., § 68-301).



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant automobile owner challenged the judgment of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which overruled her general and special demurrers to the petition of plaintiff pedestrian seeking recovery of damages for personal injuries from the owner and defendant driver.


OVERVIEW: The pedestrian brought a personal injury action against the owner and the driver. The court observed that if the pedestrian was entitled to recovery from the owner, it was by reason of Ga. Code Ann. § 68-301 because the petition clearly sought recovery from the owner on the basis that the driver was driving the car with her consent and for her benefit. The petition did not seek recovery from the owner on the basis of principal and agent, nor did it allege facts showing that the driver was her agent acting within the scope of his employment. The court held that § 68-301 violated the due process clause of both the United States and the Georgia Constitution because it made a vehicle owner liable if the vehicle was being used in the prosecution of the business of or for the benefit of the owner, even though operated without notice to her or without her knowledge or consent. To allow any recovery on the basis of § 68-301 would deprive a defendant of property without due process of law, would authorize a recovery without liability, and would compel payment without fault. The owner was in a position to challenge the constitutionality of § 68-301 because she was adversely affected by it.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment, which overruled the owner's general and special demurrers to the pedestrian's petition.

 

1291 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Stark v. Waters


Nos. 20260, 20262


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 597; 106 S.E.2d 401; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 504


November 10, 1958, Argued  
November 19, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Jackson Superior Court. Before Judge Clinkscales. September 2, 1958.

In case number 20262, Herbert P. Womack, Jr., alleging the pendency in the City Court of Jefferson of a criminal case against him, sought an injunction against the judge, solicitor, clerk, and sheriff of that court, together with the three county commissioners of Jackson County, alleging that the act (Ga. L. 1903, p. 138) creating the City Court of Jefferson is unconstitutional and void, because sec. 31 thereof provides for the judge of the superior court to send down from the superior court to the city court for trial all misdemeanor presentments and indictments which may not be disposed of at the end of the term of the superior court by pleas, and sec. 32 provides that all justices of the peace and notaries public of the county shall bind over to the city court all misdemeanor cases. The petition alleges that these sections offend the provisions of the Constitution (Code, Ann., § 2-401) requiring uniformity. The prayer is for injunction prohibiting each defendant from operating the City Court of Jefferson, and a decree declaring the entire city court act unconstitutional and void.

In case [***2] number 20260, Charles Waters alleges that there is pending in the City Court of Jefferson a criminal case against him. He names the judge, solicitor, and the sheriff of that court as defendants and attacks the city court act above in its entirety upon the same alleged unconstitutional provisions as in the above case, and seeks the same relief by injunction and decree that the city court act is unconstitutional and void. Two persons, alleging themselves to be citizens and taxpayers, were by an ex parte order allowed to intervene, and that order, issued at chambers, is excepted to here.

Upon presentation of the petition in the latter case on July 3, 1958, a rule nisi issued setting an interlocutory hearing on September 5, 1958, and in the meantime the defendants were restrained as prayed. In the first case the rule nisi issued on August 5, 1958, setting an interlocutory hearing on September 5, 1958, and in the meantime restrained the defendants as prayed. On August 7, 1958, the intervention was allowed subject to objection.

On September 2, 1958, an ex parte order was issued by the judge, reciting that the plaintiff Womack was seriously ill and unable to appear at court for several [***3] months, and counsel for the plaintiffs are engaged in other courts, and ordered that the above-stated cases -- there being above the order an entry stating the parties in both cases -- "be removed from the trial calendar of Sept. 5, 1958, and that the same be reset by further order of the court. In the meantime, the restraining orders heretofore issued in said cases shall remain in full force and effect. Let the clerk notify all parties of interest in said cases of this order. Maylon B. Clinkscales, Judge, Superior Courts Piedmont Circuit."

The defendants in each case tendered to the judge on September 9, 1958, bills of exceptions and each was approved by the judge on September 16, 1958. Errors are assigned on the ex parte order of September 2, 1958, on the ex parte orders of July 3, 1958, and August 5, 1958, restraining the defendants, and the order of August 7, 1958, allowing the intervention. The defendants in error in each case have moved to dismiss the writs of error upon the grounds that they are premature and except to no reviewable judgments.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellees, city court officials and county commissioners, challenged the issuance of temporary restraining orders by the Superior Court of Jackson County (Georgia) in two suits brought by appellee defendants contending that the act creating the city court in which they were facing criminal charges was unconstitutional. Appellees also challenged an order allowing two citizens to intervene in the defendants' action.


OVERVIEW: Two defendants, facing criminal charges in a city court, sought an injunction prohibiting the city court's officials from operating that court and a declaration that the act creating the court was unconstitutional. The trial court issued a temporary restraining order preventing the prosecution of defendants and allowed two citizens to intervene in the case. The court reversed. The court observed that the constitutionality of the act creating the court in question was settled law and could not be seriously questioned. Even were the constitutional questions valid, the court noted that, under O.C.G.A. § 55-102, equity could take no part in the administration of criminal law and could neither aid, restrain, nor obstruct criminal courts in the exercise of their jurisdiction. Violation of this statute could not be justified by allegations that the entire law creating the city court was unconstitutional. Since there were no allegations showing invalidity of the act creating the city court, an injunction could not prevent the performance of the duties imposed upon the city court's officials by that act.


OUTCOME: The trial court's orders were reversed.

 

1292 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Cravey v. Southeastern Underwriters Asso


Nos. 20188, 20189, 20190


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 450; 105 S.E.2d 497; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 457


September 10, 1958, Argued  
October 10, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Whitman. May 29, 1958.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent commissioner sought review of the judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) that granted petitioner associations' prayer to restrain the commissioner from suspending new rate adjustments that had previously been approved, and for which the associations went to considerable expense to prepare and print in order to put the new rates into effect on the date designated by the commissioner.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner challenged the trial court's judgment that granted the associations' motion for an injunction to prevent the commissioner from suspension of insurance rates that had already been put in effect. The court affirmed and rejected the commissioner's assertion that the associations' lack standing to bring suit because they were unincorporated, and, therefore, were not legal entities. The court held that an express statutory provision was not indispensable to the associations' capacity to sue and be sued. The court noted that the associations were licensed as rating organizations under the provisions of Ga. Code Ann. §§ 56-20, 56-21. The court found that under Ga. Code Ann. §§ 56-2004(b), 56-2104(b), insurers had to be a member of, or subscribe to a licensed rating organization. The court held that the statutes recognized the associations as legal entities regarding rating issues. The court rejected the commissioner's assertion that he had the authority to make orders and decisions without prior notice and hearing, and was required to give the associations prior notice of the suspension of rates, and afford the associations an opportunity to be heard.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed because the commissioner did not have the authority to suspend existing rates without prior notice and an opportunity for a hearing on the matter.

 

1293 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Sharpe v. Lowe


No. 20201


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 513; 106 S.E.2d 28; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 476


September 9, 1958, Argued  
October 10, 1958, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 7, 1958.


PRIOR HISTORY: Action for damages; constitutional question. Toombs Superior Court. Before Judge Whaley from Oconee Circuit. June 23, 1958.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, an arresting officer and related parties, challenged a judgment from the Toombs Superior Court (Georgia), which overruled the general demurrers to the amended petition, held that the 1958 amendment of Ga. Code Ann. § 56-601 was not applicable to plaintiff arrestee's action instituted in 1957, and held that even if it was applicable, it was unconstitutional and void as applied to this action for damages arising from an illegal arrest.


OVERVIEW: The arresting officer arrested the arrestee without a warrant. The court held that the 1958 amendment of Ga. Code Ann. § 56-601 was not applicable to the arrestee's action, which was instituted in 1957 and was pending at the time of its passage. The amendment had only a prospective application. Defendants asserted that the amended petition failed to set forth a cause of action for illegal arrest because it contained no allegations that, at the time of the arrest, the arrestee was not endeavoring to escape and there was not likely to be a failure of justice for want of an officer to issue a warrant. The arrestee alleged that he had not committed any act in violation of any law, had committed no act or crime in the presence of the officer who had no warrant for his arrest, and that his arrest was wrongful, illegal, malicious, and without probable cause. Whether grounds for a warrantless arrest existed was a matter of defense and defendants had the burden of proof on that issue. There was no merit to that ground of the demurrer. The trial court properly overruled the special demurrer, as the arrestee could recover both smart money and attorney's fees under Ga. Code Ann. § 89-421.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1294 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Hill v. Johnson


No. 20153


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 417; 105 S.E.2d 309; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 444


July 15, 1958, Argued  
September 5, 1958, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied October 10, 1958.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Coffee Superior Court. Before Judge Roddenberry. May 20, 1958.

The petition for injunction in the present case is brought by the Mayor of the City of Nicholls against the aldermen and marshal of that city. It is asserted: The petitioner is the duly elected mayor of the city for the year 1958. The aldermen have conspired together to divest the petitioner of his right and authority as the supreme executive officer of the city, and they have delivered to him a notice that a hearing will be had in the city hall at 7:30 o'clock p. m. on May 5, 1958, to hear evidence on the question of impeachment of the petitioner under section 16 of the city charter. (This notice, attached as an exhibit to the petition, listed six specific charges against the petitioner of crimes and misconduct). The notice was maliciously published, and the statements contained therein are false, defamatory, and libelous. "There has been no enabling ordinance adopted by the legislative department of the City of Nicholls rendering operative the provisions of said section 16, without which its provisions are impotent and without effect. By itself considered,  [***2] nor when considered with the remaining sections, said section 16 of the charter act of the City of Nicholls is not susceptible of being rendered retroactively enforceable by enabling ordinance. Any effort so to do would be violative of article I, section I, paragraph II, of the Constitution of Georgia, which is: 'Protection to person and property is a [the] paramount duty of government, and shall be impartial and complete;' and article I, section I, paragraph III, of the Constitution of Georgia, which is: 'No person shall be deprived of life, liberty, and [or] property except by due process of law;' article V [Amendments] of the Constitution of the United States of America, which in part is: 'No person shall . . . be deprived of life, liberty or property, without due process of law.'" The defendants have "arrogated unto themselves the right to accuse, to constitute the personnel of the forum of trial, to become and be the triors of this petitioner, and to execute judgment based upon triors' findings, all of which is contrary to every recognized principle of justice and jurisprudence obtaining in these United States of America."

The petition prayed: that the hearing provided [***3] for in the notice be enjoined; that the defendants be restrained from doing any act involving his tenure of office, and from uttering or circulating by utterance matters derogatory of the petitioner as it involves his office; and for other and further relief.

The trial judge granted an order temporarily restraining the impeachment hearing. The defendants filed a general demurrer, to the petition, which was sustained. The exception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mayor sought to enjoin and restrain respondents, a city alderman and a city marshal, from doing any act involving his tenure of office and from uttering or circulating matters that were derogatory to the mayor in his official capacity. The Superior Court of Coffee County (Georgia) granted an order temporarily restraining an impeachment hearing and sustained defendants' general demurrer. The mayor took exception to that judgment.


OVERVIEW: The mayor contended that no enabling ordinance adopted by the legislative department of the city rendered operative the provisions of a city charter authorizing impeachment proceedings, and he sought to enjoin an impeachment hearing. The court held that the trial court did not err when it denied the injunction because a court of equity could not interfere in cases involving merely the question of title to an office. The mayor did not attack the constitutionality of the charter provisions authorizing impeachment proceedings, and he was given notice of the impeachment hearing, so his due process argument was without merit. The legislature had designated members of a board of aldermen as the proper forum for hearing impeachment proceedings, so the mayor was not denied due process of law by reason that the aldermen were prejudiced against him.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was affirmed.

 

1295 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Sigman v. Brunswick Port Authority


No. 20119


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 332; 104 S.E.2d 467; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 417


June 10, 1958, Argued  
July 11, 1958, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 22, 1958.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Glynn Superior Court. Before Judge Thomas. May 3, 1958.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a group of citizens and taxpayers, sought review of an order from the Glynn Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained the general demurrer that was filed by appellees, a port authority (the authority) and its members. Appellants sought to enjoin appellees from issuing and selling revenue bonds, from incurring any further expense in connection therewith, and from demolishing certain buildings owned by the authority.


OVERVIEW: The authority agreed to lease its facilities to a company. The authority proposed the issuance of revenue bonds to pay for the construction of the facilities, but appellants challenged the constitutionality of the act creating the authority and the proposed issuance of the bonds. The trial court sustained appellees' demurrer to appellants' petition to enjoin appellees from issuing and selling the bonds, from incurring any further expense in connection therewith, and from demolishing certain buildings owned by the authority. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court holding that the issuance of the bonds did not unconstitutionally pledge the credit of the state. The court further held that the tax-exempt status that had been given to the authority's property and revenue bonds was not unconstitutional because the public used the property. Finally, the court held that appellants sufficiently published the notice of the authority's intention to enter into the contract with the company and to issue the bonds.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed an order of the trial court, which sustained appellees' general demurrer that to appellants' petition to enjoin appellees from issuing and selling revenue bonds, from incurring any further expense in connection therewith, and from demolishing certain buildings owned by the authority.

 

1296 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Complete Auto Transit v. Floyd


No. 20054


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 232; 104 S.E.2d 208; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 381


May 12, 1958, Argued  
June 5, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for damages; constitutional question. Jeff Davis Superior Court. Before Judge Thomas. February 8, 1958.

On June 17, 1957, Deroy Floyd, as administrator of the estate of his deceased wife, Mamie M. Floyd, filed his petition against Complete Auto Transit, Inc., in which he sought recovery of damages of $ 50,000 for pain and suffering of his deceased wife, and medical, hospital and funeral expenses in the sum of $ 972. He alleged that the deceased was injured on July 27, 1955, when the tractor on which she was riding was struck from the rear by a transport unit of the defendant; that she suffered excruciating pain from the date of her injury until her death on August 7, 1955, and incurred medical, hospital and funeral expenses; and that her injury and death were the result of the defendant's negligence. On July 11, 1957, the defendant filed a plea in bar in which it was alleged that prior to her death the deceased had not filed suit for pain and suffering and therefore any action she might have had therefor did not survive to her administrator; that the husband and ten children of the deceased had previously filed suit in the Federal court for the full value of the deceased's [***2] life in which case judgment was rendered in their favor for $ 107,500; and that that suit was a bar to the present action for pain and suffering. On July 11, 1957, the defendant also filed an answer generally denying the allegations of the petition and, in the "fifth defense" thereof, making the same contentions as made in the plea in bar. Likewise, on the same date, the defendant demurred generally on the ground that the petition stated no cause of action and demurred specially on the ground of a misjoinder of causes of action. In its demurrers the defendant demurred generally to paragraphs 13 and 15 of the petition, which contained allegations as to the cause of action for pain and suffering, and also to paragraph 14, which set forth the cause of action for medical, hospital and funeral expenses. On July 15, 1957, the plaintiff filed a demurrer to and motion to strike the defendant's plea in bar on the ground that it did not set out any defense either in law or in equity and on the same date demurred to and moved to strike the "fifth defense" of the answer. On February 8, 1958, the defendant filed a defensive pleading denominated "Elaboration of an Amendment to the Original [***3] Demurrers," which attacked paragraphs 13 and 15 of the petition on certain constitutional grounds and prayed that said paragraphs be stricken, and which also attacked paragraph 14 on constitutional grounds and prayed that it be stricken. On February 8, the plaintiff amended his petition striking therefrom paragraph 14 (the allegations which sought recovery for medical, hospital and funeral expenses) and adding count 2 in which he sought recovery for these items. Thereafter, on the same date, the defendant filed a renewal of its demurrers. At a hearing on February 8, 1958, the trial court sustained the plaintiff's demurrers and motions to strike the plea in bar and the "fifth defense" of the answer and overruled all the defendant's demurrers to the amended petition. To these rulings adverse to it the defendant excepts.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant vehicle owner sought review of the judgment of the Superior Court of Jeff Davis County (Georgia), which sustained the demurrer and motions to strike of appellee, the administrator of decedent's estate.


OVERVIEW: The administrator filed a petition against the vehicle owner, which sought recovery of damages for pain and suffering, and medical, hospital, and funeral expenses. The vehicle owner filed a plea in abatement that the administrator had not filed the petition before the decedent's death and that the claim did not survive her death. The trial court denied the demurrers and the plea in abatement. The court affirmed in part and reversed in part, holding that recovery on behalf of the father and children of decedent against the vehicle owner did not constitute a bar to the administrator's action. The court held that an amendment to Ga. Code Ann. § 3-505 was not unconstitutional and did not violate Ga. Const., art. 3, § 7, para.8. The court ruled, however, that the administrator did not have a cause of action for negligent homicide because an act of the general assembly that conferred upon the wife's administrator the right to recover for medical, hospital, and funeral expenses deprived a defendant of his property without due process of law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part and reversed in part the trial court's judgment.

 

1297 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


South Georgia Natural Gas Co. v. Georgia Public Service Com.


No. 20024


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 174; 104 S.E.2d 97; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 363


April 15, 1958, Argued  
May 7, 1958, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied June 4, 1958.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Alverson. January 10, 1958.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a natural gas company, appealed a decision of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which denied its motion for a new trial following a judgment in favor of defendants, the Georgia Public Service Commission, its five members, and a competitor that was granted a certificate of public convenience and necessity, on its action seeking to enjoin and set aside the Commission's order granting the certificate.


OVERVIEW: Following the enactment of 1956 Ga. Laws 104, the competitor filed an application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity to construct and operate a gas pipeline system. The natural gas company objected, asserting that the act under which the application was made is was invalid and unconstitutional. The Commission granted the certificate and retained jurisdiction. The trial court denied the natural gas company's request to enjoin the order of the Commission, and on appeal, the court affirmed. The record affirmatively showed that the natural gas company, as an interstate distributor, did not serve the area served by the competitor and had no application for a certificate which would authorize it to do so. It was not adversely affected by the provisions of 1956 Ga. Laws 104, which related only to an intrastate gas business, nor was it injured in any way by the certificate of public convenience and necessity which the Commission granted to the competitor. Consequently, it was in no position to attack the constitutionality of the act. Because it was not adversely affected by the Commission's order, it also could not question the sufficiency of the evidence.


OUTCOME: The judgment denying the natural gas company's challenge to the certificate of public convenience and need granted to a competitor was affirmed.

 

1298 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Gunby v. Yates


No. 19992


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 17; 102 S.E.2d 548; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 325


February 10, 1958, Argued  
March 7, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Catoosa Superior Court. Before Judge Davis. December 17, 1957.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners in error, Commissioners of the Ordinaries Retirement Fund of Georgia (Commissioners), challenged a decision of the Catoosa Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained the general demurrers of defendant in error ordinary and dismissed their petition to collect from the ordinary the sum of $ 1 for every marriage license sold. The ordinary claimed that collection and payment of the $ 1 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The commissioners brought suit against the ordinary claiming he failed to remit the sum of $ 1 for each marriage license he sold. Defendant demurred, claiming that the statute requiring the collection and payment of $ 1 from each license sold to be paid into the ordinaries' retirement system was unconstitutional as it imposed a tax only upon persons seeking marriage licenses for the benefit of a particular and limited class of citizens. The trial court sustained the ordinary's demurrer and the court affirmed, finding that the statute requiring collection of the $ 1was unconstitutional. The fees allowed to be charged for the issuance of a marriage license were fixed by law and no part of that statutory fee was to be paid into the retirement fund. Instead, on the issuance of the license, the ordinary was required to charge an additional dollar, which would be paid into the retirement fund. Such being the case, the collection of this extra dollar was not for the purpose of compensating the ordinary for a service rendered, but was for the purpose of raising revenue for the expenses of operating the retirement board and paying benefits to retired ordinaries, and was a tax, not a fee.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order, which sustained the ordinary's demurrer to the commissioners' petition seeking mandamus to compel the ordinary to remit the sum of $ 1 for each marriage license he sold.

 

1299 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Woodside v. City of Atlanta


No. 19906


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 75; 103 S.E.2d 108; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 338


November 13, 1957, Argued  
March 7, 1958, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 21, 1958.


PRIOR HISTORY: Condemnation; constitutional question. Fulton Superior Court. Before Judge Pye. September 10, 1957.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowner sought review of a decision of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which refused to dismiss appellee condemnor's appeal to a jury of its condemnation rights.


OVERVIEW: The condemnor brought an action to condemn the landowner's property for public use. A board of assessors determined the property's value. The condemnor refused to pay that amount to the landowner or into the court registry. Instead, the condemnor filed an appeal to a jury. The landowner filed a motion to dismiss the appeal, which the trial court denied. The landowner then sought a writ of error, which the court granted. The court held that the condemnor's filing of the appeal without having paid the assessment amounted to a taking of the property without just and adequate compensation. The court stated that Ga. Const. art. 1, § 3, para. 1, Ga. Code Ann. § 2-301, declared that private property could not be taken for public purposes until just and adequate compensation for it was first paid to the owner. The court construed that provision as prohibiting the taking of any substantial right that the owner held in the land. The court said that the provision did not apply solely to the taking of private property from the owner in toto. The court held that the condemnor, when it filed the appeal, took a substantial right that the landowner held in the property without having paid for it.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the failure to dismiss the condemnor's appeal to a jury of its right of condemnation with respect to the landowner's property.

 

1300 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Comm'rs of Rds. & Revenues v. Davis


No. 19927


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 792; 102 S.E.2d 180; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 284


January 15, 1958, Submitted  
February 7, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Workmen's compensation; constitutional question. Before Judge Alverson. Fulton Superior Court. September 24, 1957.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a county board of commissioners of roads and revenues, appealed a decision of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which affirmed an award made to plaintiff employee by the Workmen's Compensation Board and dismissed the board's appeal.


OVERVIEW: The board of commissioners asserted that 1950 Ga. Laws 324 § 2 re-enacted that portion of the original Workmen's Compensation Act that attempted to bring counties under the Act. On appeal from the order in favor of the employee, the court affirmed, holding that the constitutional amendment of 1945 and the enabling act of 1946 had the effect of reinstating that portion of the original Workmen's Compensation Act which had placed counties under the act and which had previously been declared unconstitutional. That portion of the original Workmen's Compensation Act purporting to bring counties of this State under the act was null and void unless it has been re-enacted. The court held that it had not been re-enacted.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court, affirming the award of the board and dismissing the appeal of the county was found not to be erroneous.

 

1301 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Laurens County v. Keen


Nos. 19944, 19964


Supreme Court of Georgia


214 Ga. 32; 102 S.E.2d 697; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 330


January 14, 1958, Argued  
February 7, 1958, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 7, 1958 and March 10, 1958.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for injunction. Laurens Superior Court. Before Judge Stephens. September 19, 1957.

T. C. Keen, Sr., filed his petition for injunction and other relief against the Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues and the Sheriff of Laurens County, and against the county. It was alleged that an execution issued by the Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for the collection of certain commissions retained by him as Tax Commissioner, was issued illegally.

The defendants' general and special demurrers to the original petition, and to the third amendment, were overruled, and the defendants, Laurens County and the county commissioners, except to this judgment. The defendants' general demurrers to the first and second amendments to the petition, attacking the constitutionality of the act creating the office of Tax Commissioner of Laurens County, and especially section 7 of that act, providing that fees formerly received by the Tax Receiver and Tax Collector of Laurens County should be paid into the treasury of the county, were sustained, and by cross-bill of exceptions the plaintiff excepts to this judgment.

The [***2] issues made by the petition and demurrers will appear in the opinion. The parties will be referred to as they appeared in the trial court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed on the main bill and cross-bill of exceptions.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff tax commissioner excepted to an order of the Superior Court of Laurens County (Georgia), which sustained the general demurrers of defendants, board of commissioners and county sheriff, to the commissioner's first and second amended petition for injunctive relief to stop enforcement of 1952 Ga. Laws pp. 2327-2334. Defendants excepted to the overruling of the general and special demurrers to the original petition and third amendment.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner contended that § 7 of 1952 Ga. Laws 2327-2334, which created the office of the county tax commissioner, was unconstitutional. The commissioner filed a petition for injunctive and other relief against defendants after the board issued an execution for the collection of certain commissions that were retained by the commissioner. Defendants' demurrers to the first and second amendments to the petition were sustained, but their general and special demurrers to the original petition and the third amendment were overruled. Both parties excepted. On review, the court affirmed the judgments. The court held that § 7 did not violate Ga. Const. art. XI, § I, para. VI, O.C.G.A. § 2-7806 or Ga. Const. art. XI, § II, para. II, O.C.G.A. § 2-7902 because the offices of tax receiver and tax collector in any county of Georgia could be consolidated, and the compensation could be fixed in any manner perceived by the legislature. The court held that the execution that issued by the board was in an amount that was in excess of that which was lawfully due.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1302 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Martin v. Fulton County


No. 19905


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 761; 101 S.E.2d 716; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 274


November 13, 1957, Argued  
January 14, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Before Judge Alverson. Fulton Superior Court. September 18, 1957.

Fulton County brought a petition for the condemnation in rem of described land, pursuant to the provision of Chapter 36-11 of the Code. The persons named whose property rights were sought to be taken, or otherwise affected, were Mrs. Esther Ann Lyon Martin and the Clerk of the Superior Court, the Tax Commissioner, and the Tax Collector, of Fulton County.

The trial judge passed an order requiring the defendants to appear before him on a given date. Mrs. Martin filed general and special demurrers to the petition for condemnation. She also filed a pleading, designated as an answer, which consisted of three parts: "(a) answer by way of cross-bill, and prayer for injunction, (b) answer to the petition by paragraphs, and (c) response to the rule nisi."

The pleading designated as a cross-bill alleged: Fulton County is proceeding illegally to condemn the property described in the petition, which belongs to Mrs. Martin, for the reasons that Fulton County has no legal authority to condemn and take the land described, no sufficient reason is given in the petition for such condemnation, and the property is [***2] held by Mrs. Martin under a constitutional homestead which prevents it from being condemned. The placing of the property under the constitutional homestead was authorized by an order of Fulton Superior Court September 5, 1905 (recorded in a designated book), upon the application of Mrs. Octavia N. Nealy to reinvest homestead funds, and the consummation of the reinvestment is recorded (in a designated book). The granting of the homestead has never been revoked or annulled. Mrs. Octavia N. Nealy died in 1921 and the property passed by will to her son, Claude Nealy, who had married Mrs. Martin's sister. In 1936 Mrs. Martin and her son moved into the home and became a part of the family enjoying the homestead property. Mrs. Martin is now the sole owner of the homestead property, being the property sought to be condemned. The condemnation case, being a proceeding in rem against the property, is in violation of Code § 51-101, prohibiting any judgment, execution, or decree against homestead property, except for the purposes named in the section. The condemnation case is also proceeding illegally because the property sought to be condemned is within the City of Atlanta, a municipality,  [***3] and yet the condemnation is not being instituted by the City of Atlanta, and no concurrence or consent of the city for the condemnation of the land is shown. Fulton County is not constructing or planning to construct a highway at the place where the property sought to be condemned is located.

The prayers of the cross-bill were that Fulton County be temporarily and permanently enjoined from condemning the property sought to be condemned.

The trial judge entered an order in which he overruled the general and special demurrers of Mrs. Martin to the condemnation petition, except for two special demurrers. In the same order he sustained the written motion of Fulton County to strike the cross-bill and prayers for injunction of Mrs. Martin. In her bill of exceptions Mrs. Martin excepts to all of the rulings adverse to her in the order.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowner sought review of a decision from the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which overruled her general and special demurrers to appellee county's condemnation petition and struck the landowner's cross-bill and prayers for injunctive relief.


OVERVIEW: The county instituted a condemnation proceeding against the landowner's property under Ga. Code Ann. § 36-11. The landowner filed general and special demurrers and sought to enjoin the county from condemning her property, alleging that she held the property under a constitutional homestead. The property had been placed under homestead and passed by will to the son of the original owner, who had married the landowner's sister. The landowner and her son then moved into the home and also enjoyed the homestead property. At the time of the suit, the landowner was the sole owner. The trial court overruled her demurrers and struck her cross-bill alleging a homestead and her motion for injunctive relief. On appeal, the court reversed cases holding that a condemnee could not file a bill of exceptions to a decision overruling demurrers to a condemnation petition and held that Ga. Code Ann. § 95-17A authorized the state and its subdivisions to acquire property for limited access roads, and that Ga. Code Ann. § 95-1721 imposed a duty on the county to acquire the necessary rights-of-way. The court held that under the circumstances, the landowner did not hold a constitutional homestead.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision to overrule the landowner's demurrers to the county's condemnation petition and to strike her cross-bill and motion for injunctive relief.

 

1303 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Atlanta v. Southern R. Co.


Nos. 19891, 19892


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 736; 101 S.E.2d 707; 1958 Ga. LEXIS 262


November 12, 1957, Submitted  
January 10, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for injunction. Before Judge Moore. Fulton Superior Court. July 31, 1957.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed on main bill of exceptions. Cross-bill of exceptions dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city appealed and plaintiff landowners cross-appealed a judgment from the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) sustaining in part and overruling in part the city's demurrers to the landowners' complaint to enjoin the city from paving the relevant property and assessing any part of the costs therefore against them.


OVERVIEW: The landowners brought an action against the city to enjoin the city from paving certain property and assessing any part of the cost therefor against them. The court affirmed as to the city's appeal from the trial court's judgment sustaining in part and overruling in part the city's demurrers to the landowners' complaint. The landowners' cross-appeal was dismissed. 1951 Ga. Laws p. 3074, which purported to amend the city's charter was too vague, indefinite, and uncertain in meaning to be enforced by the courts and was therefore void. Accordingly, the paving and curbing ordinances which the city adopted pursuant to 1951 Ga. Laws p. 3074 were unenforceable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed as to the city's appeal from the trial court's judgment sustaining in part and overruling in part the city's demurrers to the landowners' complaint to enjoin the city from paving certain property and assessing costs against them. The landowners' cross-appeal was dismissed.

 

1304 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


O. K. v. State Highway Dep't


No. 19908


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 666; 100 S.E.2d 906; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 482


October 15, 1957, Argued  
November 8, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for injunction. Before Judge Alverson. Fulton Superior Court. September 12, 1957.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error corporation sought review of the judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) that dismissed its petition challenging the condemnation by defendant in error State Highway Department of Georgia of property owned by the corporation.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the corporation challenged the constitutionality of the Act of 1957, by which the corporation's property was taken by the Department. The statute provided for a condemnation proceeding wherein notice and an opportunity to be heard was afforded. The statute also provided for a hearing wherein a determination of the value of the condemned property was made. The court ruled that the enactment of the Act of 1957 did not represent an abuse of legislative discretion. In reaching this conclusion, the court noted that the statute fairly and adequately protected the constitutional rights of the owner of property condemned for public purposes by providing for just and adequate compensation to be first paid before the property was taken. In so ruling, the court observed that the method of ascertaining what just and adequate compensation was left to legislative discretion.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment dismissing the petition.

 

1305 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Stockham Valves & Fittings v. Williams


No. 19838


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 713; 101 S.E.2d 197; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 496


September 12, 1957, Argued  
November 8, 1957, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 26, 1957.


PRIOR HISTORY: Action for tax refund. Before Judge Shaw. Fulton Superior Court. July 19, 1957.

This was an action brought by Stockham Valves & Fittings, Inc., (hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff) against T. V. Williams as Revenue Commissioner of the State of Georgia, to recover income taxes paid by the plaintiff under protest to the State for the calendar years 1952, 1954, and 1955, assessed against the plaintiff under the following Georgia Income Tax Statutes: Code (Ann.) § 92-3102, which provides that "Every domestic corporation and every foreign corporation shall pay annually an income tax equivalent to four per cent. of the net income from property owned or from business done in Georgia, as defined in section 92-3113"; and Code (Ann.) § 92-3113, which provides that "The tax imposed by this law shall apply to the entire net income, as herein defined, received by every corporation, foreign or domestic, owning property or doing business in this State. Every such corporation shall be deemed to be doing business within this State if it engages within this State in any activities or transactions for the purpose of financial profit or gain, whether [***2] or not such corporation qualifies to do business in this State, and whether or not it maintains an office or place of doing business within this State, and whether or not any such activity or transaction is connected with interstate or foreign commerce." Claims for a refund of the taxes paid having been denied by the defendant, the present suit was brought.

The plaintiff contends that all of its activities within the State of Georgia are a part of and inseparable from interstate commerce, and that any income tax assessed against the plaintiff is a direct burden on such commerce and violates the commerce clause of the Federal Constitution (Code § 1-125 (3)); that the fact that the plaintiff maintains one sales-service office in Georgia and one of its sales representatives spends one-third of his time in Georgia does not make the plaintiff present in the State in any substantial sense, and an attempt to subject it to an income tax violates the due-process clause of the Federal Constitution (Code § 1-815). No question is raised by the plaintiff as to the reasonableness of the apportionment of its net income to Georgia under the prescribed statutory apportionment formula or to the [***3] amount of taxes, if liable; but the plaintiff contends that the State is without jurisdiction to impose a net income tax upon a foreign corporation engaged within Georgia in exclusively interstate commerce.

The facts were stipulated, and the issue was submitted to the trial judge without a jury; and to the judgment upholding the validity of the statute and the tax the plaintiff excepts.

From the stipulation of facts it appears that the plaintiff is a corporation organized under the laws of Delaware with its principal or home office and its manufacturing plant located in Birmingham, Alabama. Since 1905, and including the tax years in question, it has been engaged in the business of manufacturing and selling valves and pipe fittings and in promoting the sale and use of valves and pipe fittings which it manufactured. For the tax years in question, it maintained inventories of its products in established warehouses at Birmingham, Ala., Philadelphia, Pa., Chicago, Ill., Houston, Tex., and Vernon, Calif. It maintained established sales-service offices at the foregoing locations and also at Cambridge, Mass., New York, N. Y., Atlanta, Ga., Pittsburgh, Pa., San Francisco, Calif., Washington,  [***4] D. C., Dallas, Tex., and St. Louis, Mo. Purchasers of plaintiff's valves and pipe fittings were located in all the United States.

As a matter of policy and practice, during the tax years in question, the plaintiff made sales only to established local wholesalers and jobbers and (except for sales to makers of automatic-sprinkler systems) made no sales directly to users and installers of valves and pipe fittings. The local wholesalers and jobbers who handled the plaintiff's products, however, were in no way tied in or committed by any type of license, franchise, or other authorized or exclusive dealership arrangement, to the distribution of the plaintiff's products. Any established local wholesaler or jobber, having established credit, was considered as a prospective customer and could buy from the plaintiff. Established local wholesalers and jobbers who did buy from the plaintiff were entirely free to discontinue buying from it at any time and for any reason; they were also free to deal in competitive products and usually did handle one or more lines of competing products.

The plaintiff, during the years in question, made no sales on a consignment basis and maintained no inventories [***5] of its own at any place except at the aforesaid warehouses, none of which were located in Georgia. Through its sales representative, it encouraged every local wholesaler and jobber who handled its products to carry a local inventory, and to those local wholesalers and jobbers who did maintain a local inventory of valves, it gave a price concession, which was not available to wholesalers and jobbers who did not. Pipe fittings were, however, sold at uniform prices whether or not carried in inventory.

All orders for the plaintiff's products were contractually accepted or rejected at the home office of the plaintiff in Birmingham, Alabama. No representative of the company at any sales-service office had any authority to, or did, contractually accept or reject any order under any circumstances. Contractual authority was vested exclusively in the home office in Birmingham, Alabama. For the most part, orders were received by mail at the company's home office in Birmingham directly from wholesalers and jobbers. Such orders as were received at sales-service offices, or by the solicitation of sales representatives working out of sales-service offices, were relayed by mail, telephone or [***6] teletype to the home office at Birmingham for contractual acceptance or rejection. Some such orders were rejected by the home office for credit or other reasons.

The plaintiff had no plant or warehouse in Georgia. All sales were made on an "f.o.b. warehouse" basis, and were completed at the plant or warehouse by deliveries to customers or to common carriers consigned to customers.

Since 1950, and during the tax years in question, the plaintiff maintained a sales-service office in Atlanta. One of its sales representatives used this office as his headquarters. He worked in a territory which included Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina, and parts of Tennessee and Virginia. Part of Florida was also included in his territory until 1954. This representative spent approximately one-third of his time at the Atlanta sales office or traveling in the State of Georgia. The other two-thirds of his time was spent traveling outside of Georgia. He was paid a salary plus a commission on the amount of business derived from the territory served by the Atlanta office.

The plaintiff also employed at its sales-service office in Atlanta a full-time woman secretary. She functioned on the basis [***7] of her own knowledge and experience and literature furnished by the company as a source of information concerning the plaintiff's products. She performed stenographic and clerical duties and facilitated communications between the plaintiff's home office in Birmingham, the plaintiff's sales representative when he was out in the territory, and customers, prospective customers, contractors, and users of the plaintiff's products. She operated the teletype machine and sometimes obtained information from Birmingham to give to architects, engineers, or other people interested in the plaintiff's products.

The Atlanta sales-service office was listed in the Atlanta telephone directories in the plaintiff's name in both the alphabetical and classified business listings. The office was listed in the plaintiff's name in the Atlanta city directories. The company, on its sales-service office letterheads, in its catalogues and discount sheets, and on some promotional material, listed the fact that it maintained a sales-service office in Atlanta. A small amount of office furniture was maintained there of the approximate value of $ 1,000. The representative carried on the ordinary duties of a [***8] salesman in Georgia.
