No orders were, however, accepted within the State of Georgia. All sales were completed at warehouses outside of the State by deliveries to customers or to common carriers consigned to customers. All such sales took place outside of Georgia.

At no time during the tax years in question did the plaintiff qualify to do business within the State of Georgia; no officer or director of the plaintiff was a resident of Georgia; the Atlanta sales representative was a resident of the State. During the tax years in question, rent, salaries, and all other expenses of the Atlanta office were paid by check drawn by officers located at the home office on bank accounts of the company in banks outside the State of Georgia. No employee of the plaintiff in Georgia had authority, either alone or with any other person, to draw checks upon or make withdrawals from any bank account of the company. Expense accounts of employees at the Atlanta office were forwarded to the home office, where they were reviewed and paid by checks. The plaintiff kept no bank account in the State of Georgia. All credit matters were handled at the plaintiff's Alabama office, where credit information [***9] was obtained and all credit questions were passed on. All invoices were prepared and mailed from and all collections were made by the plaintiff's office in Alabama. No employee of the plaintiff in Georgia had authority to accept nor did any employee accept any order, bind plaintiff to furnish goods, arrange credit terms, or make collections.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer sought review of a judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which held that Ga. Code Ann. § 92-3102 was not unconstitutional and required the taxpayer to pay taxes to defendant commissioner for business conducted within the state.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was a corporation organized under the laws of Delaware with its principal office located in Alabama and was engaged in the business of manufacturing and selling valves and pipe fittings and promoting the sale and use of valves and pipe fittings. The taxpayer filed an action to recover income taxes paid under protest to the commissioner, which were assessed under Ga. Code Ann. § 92-3102, alleging that the statute was unconstitutional. For the tax years in question, the corporation maintained inventories and sales-service offices in several states and purchasers of the valves and pipe fittings were located in all of the states. The trial court upheld the validity of Ga. Code Ann. § 92-3102. The taxpayer appealed. On appeal, the taxpayer argued that its activities within the state were a part of and inseparable from interstate commerce, and that any income tax assessed against it was a direct burden on interstate commerce. The court held that the taxpayer's business was exclusively interstate in character. Accordingly, the court held that as applied to the corporation, Ga. Code Ann. § 92-3102 violated both the commerce and due process clauses of the federal constitution.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court requiring the taxpayer to pay taxes to the commissioner for business conducted within the state was reversed.

 

1306 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Ledger-Enquirer Co. v. Brown


No. 19824


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 538; 100 S.E.2d 166; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 436


September 10, 1957, Argued  
October 11, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Libel; constitutional question. Before Judge Rees. Stewart Superior Court. June 11, 1957.

Carlton Brown brought suit in Stewart County Superior Court against The Ledger-Enquirer Company, a newspaper publishing corporation which has its principal office in Columbus, Muscogee County, Georgia, alleging that said corporation in its newspaper, the Columbus Enquirer, had published false and libelous matter of and concerning the plaintiff, for which he sought damages.

The petition as amended alleged as follows: "The Ledger-Enquirer Company is a corporation engaged in publishing newspapers in the State of Georgia and said corporation has circulation of its newspaper, the Columbus Enquirer, in more than one county of said State. The said newspaper is circulated in Stewart County, Georgia, by being regularly delivered to more than fifty (50) subscribers therein. The named corporation has no agent or place of business in Stewart County, Georgia but has its principal office in this State located at Columbus, Muscogee County, Georgia."

The defendant corporation filed its general demurrer to the original petition and renewed its demurrers to the petition as amended, in which, among other [***2] things, it attacked the jurisdiction of the Superior Court of Stewart County. The trial judge ruled only on the demurrers attacking the jurisdiction of the court. These demurrers were overruled and the motion to dismiss the petition was denied. The exception here is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error newspaper excepted to a judgment of the Superior Court of Stewart County (Georgia), which overruled the newspaper's demurrers to the jurisdiction in defendant in error's libel action.


OVERVIEW: Defendant in error alleged that the newspaper published false and libelous matter concerning him. On appeal of the overruling of the newspaper's demurrers to the jurisdiction, the court noted that 1956 Ga. Laws 4-6 was to establish venue in actions for damages against certain corporations and to fix the residences of such corporations. The classification was corporations, publishing newspapers, magazines, and periodicals having a circulation in more than one county in Georgia. The court found no reasonable relation of the classification made to the purpose of the act. There was no legitimate ground of differentiation between a corporation that published a newspaper and regularly delivered it to more than 50 subscribers in a county and such corporation which regularly sold its publication to more than 50 persons in a county by methods other than subscription. The harm done to the person libeled was just as great either way. The act was unconstitutional and void, and the trial court had no jurisdiction over the newspaper.


OUTCOME: The court reversed.

 

1307 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Gay v. Laurens County


Nos. 19763, 19777


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 518; 100 S.E.2d 271; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 428


July 8, 1957, Argued  
September 12, 1957, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied October 11, 1957.


PRIOR HISTORY: Action against sheriff for fines, etc.; constitutional question. Before Judge Stephens. Laurens Superior Court. April 1, 1957.



DISPOSITION: Reversed on main bill of exceptions. Cross-bill of exceptions dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sheriff challenged a judgment of the Superior Court of Laurens County (Georgia), which found in favor of defendant county. The county filed the litigation against the sheriff for the return of money collected by the sheriff as fines, forfeitures, and costs, which were not paid over to the officers of the county as required by a Georgia local salary act approved on February 12, 1952.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the sheriff argued that the county's petition as amended failed to state a cause of action because the Act, which placed the office of sheriff on a salary basis, was unconstitutional. The Act was a local or special one and its constitutionality was attacked on the ground that notice of the authors' intention to introduce it in the General Assembly was not published as required by O.C.G.A. § 2-7902; Ga. Const. of 1945, art. XII, § 2, para. 2. The court held that the Act was unconstitutional. Reversing the judgment, the court found that it was necessary to publish the notice once a week for three weeks during a period of 60 days immediately preceding the date of its introduction in the General Assembly. In order to have complied with the provision of the Constitution requiring such publication, it was necessary that each publication of it be a legal one. The Act showed that the first publication of the notice was on "Saturday, December 9, 1951," but that day was a Sunday. The court held that where the law required publication of a notice as a condition precedent to the doing of some act, its publication on a Sunday was not legal and amounted to no publication at all.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment, and dismissed the county's cross-bill of exceptions.

 

1308 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Du Pre v. Marietta


No. 19741


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 403; 99 S.E.2d 156; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 399


June 10, 1957, Submitted  
July 3, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for injunction. Before Judge Manning. Cobb Superior Court. April 2, 1957.

This is an action to enjoin the City of Marietta, a political subdivision of the State of Georgia, from condemning the petitioner's property for street purposes under the authority of the in rem provisions of Code Ch. 36-11 (Ga. L. 1937-38, Ex. Sess., pp. 251-255). Petitioner alleges in substance: that the defendant is proceeding illegally under an illegal resolution which authorizes its attorney to exercise the city's power of eminent domain, has failed to pass necessary ordinances and resolutions specifying the manner in which petitioner's property could be condemned, and no appropriate method of condemnation has been adopted, is proceeding illegally contrary to the due process clause of the Constitution of Georgia, is not entitled to proceed under the in rem petition because petitioner's title to the property is not in doubt, and a judgment ascertaining such question is unnecessary; that the assessor for the city was appointed prematurely; that existing ordinances require all streets to be 50 feet wide, and the land to be condemned for street purposes is only 40 feet wide; that there is no [***2] necessity to acquire petitioner's property, and the city acted arbitrarily, capriciously, and unnecessarily, and has failed to comply with the provisions of its charter; that the condemnation is a subterfuge and a conspiracy to enable the owners of the adjoining property to obtain necessary connections to utilities installed by the petitioner after having contracted with him to pay $ 7,500 and other consideration for such purposes; that the said property lies without the legal corporate limits, and the city has no power under its charter to acquire or condemn property for street purposes which lies without the corporate limits, and the condemnation is unnecessary since the adjoining property also lies without the corporate limits; and that the provisions of Code (Ann. Supp.) § 69-901 (Ga. L. 1946, p. 130) and the ordinance by which the lands were taken into the city are violative of the Constitution (Code, Ann., § 2-1301).

A demurrer was filed to the petition, and after a hearing was sustained and the petition dismissed. The exception here is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowner sought review from a decision of the Cobb Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained appellee city's demurrer and dismissed the landowner's petition to enjoin the city, a political subdivision of the state, from condemning the landowner's property for street purposes under the authority of the in rem provisions of 1937-38 Ga. Laws 36-11.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment. The court did agree with the landowner that the procedure by which the city sought to condemn the landowner' property was void because the law itself was void in that it violated the constitutional inhibition against delegating legislative powers under Ga. Code Ann. § 2-1301. The court held that the matter of fixing municipal corporate limits was strictly legislative, and it was beyond the power of the city's general assembly to delegate its exclusive power to alter the corporate limits of the city. However, the court noted that in 1953 the charter of the city was amended. This amendment ratified all previous incorporations of territory into the city, or attempts to do so and expressly included all such lands within the city. The court noted that no attack was made in the trial court upon the validity of the 1953 charter amendment and therefore, any arguments that it was invalid were to be disregarded and the law accepted as being valid. The court concluded that being a part of the city, the landowner's property was subject to the proper exercise by the mayor and council of charter powers to condemn for street purposes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court holding that it properly sustained the city's demurrer.

 

1309 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Holcomb v. Johnston


No. 19663


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 249; 98 S.E.2d 561; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 351


April 9, 1957, Argued  
May 14, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Before Judge Frankum. Stephens Superior Court. February 8, 1957.

This case is one to enjoin the defendant from practicing dentistry and is brought in two counts, i. e., (1) for illegally practicing dentistry without a license, and (2) for unauthorized practice of dentistry constituting a public nuisance. The answer of the defendant, as amended, admits that he is not a licensed dentist, but is a dental laboratory technician having his own laboratory, but he alleges that the portion of Code (Ann.) § 84-701 (Ga. L. 1949, pp. 1161, 1162) defining the practice of dentistry as "All persons who shall charge a fee . . . who shall . . . take an impression thereof for the purpose of treating or operating upon the same [human tooth, teeth, gums or jaws], or who shall make or repair appliances usable on teeth or as teeth, unless said appliances are ordered by and returned to a licensed dentist," is violative of the due-process clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions and is void, since the defendant has the right to carry on his vocation of dental technician, and since under the law the licensed dentists taking impressions and ordering dentures or appliances usable [***2] as teeth send the prescriptions or orders therefor direct to the laboratory or technician of their choice, and the patients for whom such are prescribed do not have the free choice to select a laboratory or technician of their own, and the defendant would not be afforded the opportunity to conduct his business or vocation except upon the whim of licensed dentists.

The case came on for trial after the defendant was restrained, and it was stipulated: (1) the plaintiffs are licensed dentists, authorized to practice dentistry in this State; and (2) the defendant has prepared impressions for the purpose of making and repairing appliances usable as teeth, and he has made appliances usable as teeth which were not ordered or returned to a licensed dentist, and that he has charged and received a fee for such service. In addition, the evidence in substance showed the education of the defendant, his practical and theoretical training, and his qualifications as a dental laboratory technician; testimony by expert witnesses as to the science of dentures, the training required of student dentists on this subject, the education and training necessary for students to qualify to take the examination [***3] of the Georgia State Board of Dental Examiners for a license to practice dentistry, the importance of centric occlusion or "taking the bite" upon the general health of a person, the importance of the oral examination made by dentists in taking impressions and in fitting appliances to diagnose disease, discover pathological conditions, and prevent rough spots which would cause irritation, the need for correct adjustments to avoid irritation, prevent sore spots, impairment of speech, and change in the facial contours of the patients, especially in women; and that dental laboratory technicians are mere mechanics who know the fundamentals of the materials with which they work, but who confine their work to fabrication of the denture or appliance according to prescription or instructions of the dentist, having nothing whatever to do with the patient, usually never seeing the patient. The defendant admitted that he had made no oral examination of the patients' mouths, merely asking them if their gums were sore; that he would make an impression, and after making the denture would insert the appliance in their mouths, instructing them to return to the laboratory on a future day for adjustments [***4] if the denture did not fit or "bothered" the patient. Other testimony disclosed that some dentists make the dentures or appliances themselves, but the prescription or order for dentures or appliances is normally sent by the dentist to a dental laboratory or technician, the choice being made by the dentist and not the patient. The defendant further testified that he had no other way of making a living; that, since the restraining order he has received hardly any orders for dentures, appliances, or repairs from practicing dentists in the area from which he had previously received such orders.

After the evidence was in, counsel for the plaintiffs moved the court to direct the jury to return a verdict for them, and after argument thereon the court sustained the motion and directed a verdict in favor of the plaintiffs. A motion for new trial was duly made, which was later amended to add one special ground complaining of the direction of the verdict against the defendant, and after a hearing and argument thereon, the motion as amended was denied. The exception here is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant dental technician sought review of a judgment of the Superior Court of Stephens County (Georgia), which, following a trial to a jury, sustained plaintiff dentists' motion for a directed verdict in their favor and denied the technician's motion for a new trial. The dentists had filed suit seeking an injunction to prevent the technician from taking impressions and fitting dental prosthetics without supervision of a licensed dentist.


OVERVIEW: The technician argued that the statute requiring the supervision of a licensed dentist for the making of impressions and the creation of dentures therefrom violated constitutional provisions allowing individuals the right to work. The court disagreed and affirmed the judgment in favor of the dentists. The court stated that the mere fact that the making and manufacture of these appliances were purely mechanical did not mean that the taking of the impression and the fitting of such prosthetics, as shown by the evidence, did not require the scientific knowledge of the professionally trained medical man in performing this function. The court found that the regulations were not unreasonable. The court held that the operations performed by the technician in taking impressions and fitting dental prosthetics for a fee were clearly acts required to be performed by a licensed dentist, and the mere fact that the legislature held these professional men accountable and responsible for such acts as a part of their profession in no way violated due process when others were only allowed to make or repair the appliances when ordered a licensed dentist.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1310 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Hansell v. Citizens & S. Nat'l Bank


No. 19635


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 205; 98 S.E.2d 622; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 341


March 11, 1957, Argued  
May 13, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for declaratory judgment, injunction, etc. Before Judge McWhorter. Chatham Superior Court. January 8, 1957.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff stockholder filed exceptions to the judgment of the Chatham Superior Court (Georgia) sustaining defendant bank's general demurrers and dismissing plaintiff's declaratory judgment action alleging the unconstitutionality of 1956 Ga. Laws 309, a state banking law.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff stockholder brought a declaratory judgment action alleging the unconstitutionality of 1956 Ga. Laws 309, a state banking law that allowed defendant bank to open branch offices in other cities. Defendant filed general demurrers. The trial court dismissed plaintiff's action and sustained defendant's demurrers. On appeal, the court reversed, holding that the state statute was unconstitutional, since it provided for the establishment of branch offices only by banks that existed at the time of the statute's passage. Since the statute failed to provide for future banks, the statute failed to apply uniformly across the state. The court determined that the statute was a special law in violation of Ga. Const. art. I, § 4, para. 1, which prohibited the enactment of a special law for which provision had been made by an existing general law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment sustaining the general demurrers and dismissing the petition, since the state banking law violated the state constitution.

 

1311 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


International Business Machines Corp. v. Evans


No. 19657


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 333; 99 S.E.2d 220; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 375


April 8, 1957, Argued  
May 13, 1957, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied June 12, 1957.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for injunction. Before Judge Anderson. Houston Superior Court. January 31, 1957.

This is an action for an injunction to restrain the collection of State and County ad valorem taxes against the property of the plaintiff for the tax year 1956 and subsequent years, brought against the taxing authorities of Houston County, Georgia, by the International Business Machines Corporation, which has a considerable number of its business machines located on a rental basis at the Robins Air Force Base, a United States government installation, located at Warner Robins, Houston County, Georgia. The petitioner relies upon Code (Ann.) §§ 15-301, 15-302, 15-303, Code § 1-125 (17), and Title 40 U. S. C. A. § 255, that the United States having accepted exclusive jurisdiction granted by the General Assembly of Georgia of approximately 6,600 acres in Houston County in connection with the Air Base, the Houston County taxing authorities are without authority to tax any private property located exclusively on said government installation. The petition in substance alleges: that the defendants are insisting that said private property is subject to tax,  [***2] and that such taxation would be illegal, null, void, and unconstitutional in violation of the statutes and constitutional provisions above set forth, and the petitioner has refused to pay any tax on said machines so located; that the defendants have levied such tax, issued a bill for the collection of same, which the petitioner refuses to pay, and shortly will issue fi. fa. and levy on the petitioner's property being used for vital defense purposes by the United States; that the petitioner has no adequate remedy at law; and it prays that the defendants be temporarily and permanently restrained and enjoined from attempting to collect such tax, the same being illegal, void, and unconstitutional.

General demurrers alleged Code (Ann.) §§ 15-301, 15-302, and 15-303, upon which the petitioner relies, to be unconstitutional to the extent that (a) they grant an exemption from property taxation in violation of the State Constitution, Code (Ann.) § 2-5404, which specifies the property within the State which may be exempt from property taxation by the General Assembly, and does not include privately owned property such as here; and (b) that said statutes, together or singly, irrevocably alienate,  [***3] give, grant, limit or restrain, or have alienated, given, granted, limited, or restrained, in favor of the United States, the power of taxation of Georgia and its subdivisions, in violation of Code (Ann.) § 2-5401, such that the State of Georgia or its subdivisions are precluded from the exercise of its sovereign right of taxation over the petitioner's privately owned property located in Houston County. The demurrers were sustained as to (b) above. The order of the court held that the Code sections violated Code (Ann.) § 2-5401, and that the petitioner failed to show that the proposed taxation of the privately owned property of the petitioner, leased to the Department of Defense, would constitute an unconstitutional or unlawful interference with the operations or activities of the United States. The exception here by the petitioner is to that judgment.

By brief, counsel for the defendants in error abandoned their ground of demurrer alleging the Code sections involved to be an exemption from property taxation in violation of Code (Ann.) § 2-5404, and asked that the judgment be affirmed on the basis of the attempted waiver of the State's sovereign right of taxation in violation [***4] of the Constitution, Code (Ann.) § 2-5401, which is the basis of the judgment by the lower court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner corporation excepted to a judgment by the Superior Court of Houston County (Georgia), which held that the corporation was liable to defendant State of Georgia for taxes. The corporation failed to show that the proposed taxation of its privately owned property, which had been leased to the U.S. Department of Defense, was an unconstitutional or unlawful interference with the operations or activities of the United States.


OVERVIEW: The corporation had a considerable number of its machines located on a rental basis at an Air Force Base located in Georgia. The corporation argued that the taxing authorities were without authority to tax any private property located exclusively on a government installation. On appeal, the State argued that the judgment was to be affirmed on the basis of the attempted waiver of the State's sovereign right of taxation in violation of the Georgia Constitution, O.C.G.A. § 2-5401, which was the basis of the judgment by the trial court. The court noted that the legislature could not have surrendered the State sovereignty to tax without express constitutional power, which was not shown. The court noted that any attempt to surrender it was effective only to the extent of allowing the United States to own and use the land free from State interference by taxes or otherwise. Individuals, including the corporation could not have been given such privileges. The United States was immune from property taxes under O.C.G.A. §§ 15-301, 15-302, and 15-303. The United States had no right to prevent such taxation so long as the taxation in no way interfered with the business of the United States.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1312 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Spence v. Rowell


No. 19622


Supreme Court of Georgia


213 Ga. 145; 97 S.E.2d 350; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 325


February 11, 1957, Submitted  
March 11, 1957, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 25, 1957 and March 29, 1957.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Before Judge Clinkscales. Gwinnett Superior Court. November 21, 1956.

DeWitt T. Spence and two others, alleging themselves to be residents and taxpayers of the Town of Lilburn, filed a suit in the Superior Court of Gwinnett County against O. B. Rowell, R. P. Pickens, H. C. Peevy, N. J. Nash, Hoyt E. Gresham, and E. W. Bramblett. The petition alleges: By an act which was approved on July 27, 1910, the legislature incorporated the Town of Lilburn in Gwinnett County and fixed its corporate limits at three-eighths of a mile in every direction from the courthouse in Berkshire Militia District. The act named a mayor and four councilmen as the governing body of the town and provided for the election of their successors. In 1933 or 1934, the officers of the town ceased to function as such, and in 1939 the legislature expressly repealed the incorporating act of 1910. The Town of Lilburn has never had a population of 1,000 inhabitants. In 1955, the legislature incorporated the City of Lilburn and fixed its corporate limits at one and one-fourth of a mile in every direction from the intersection of Main and Lula [***2] Streets in the newly incorporated area. The act included all of the area incorporated in 1910 as the Town of Lilburn and other contiguous territory. It named the defendants, other than Bramblett, as mayor and councilmen respectively of the city, and provided for the election of their successors in office. The defendants, other than Bramblett, were re-elected to their respective offices, and pursuant to authority contained in section 11 of the act they, as mayor and councilmen, elected the defendant Bramblett as the city's chief of police. Neither the repealing act of 1939 nor the incorporating act of 1955 became effective, since no election for that purpose was called and held as required by Code §§ 69-101 and 69-102. The defendants, without any legal right so to do, are performing and exercising over the petitioners and the other residents of the area embraced in the act of 1955 all of the powers conferred upon such officers by the incorporating act of 1955; and to prevent such unauthorized action, the petitioners have no adequate remedy at law. Besides for process, rule nisi and service, the prayers are: (1) that the defendants be enjoined, temporarily and permanently, from [***3] performing any of the powers enumerated in the act of 1955 and from exercising any municipal control over the petitioners and the other residents of the area embraced in the act; that the act of 1955 be declared of no force and effect; and that the petitioners be granted such other relief as they may be entitled to under the allegations of their petition and the evidence. There was no demurrer to the petition; but, by their answer, the defendants averred that the City of Lilburn was legally incorporated by the act of 1955; that they had been elected to and were rightfully holding their respective offices, and that they were exercising no municipal control over the petitioners and the other residents of the city other than that authorized by the act of 1955.

At an interlocutory hearing, the plaintiffs introduced in evidence their verified petition, and the defendants likewise introduced in evidence their verified answer. It was stipulated that the population of the Town of Lilburn and the City of Lilburn had at all times been far less than 50,000. The evidence shows, without dispute, that the mayor and councilmen of the Town of Lilburn ceased to function in 1933 or 1934; that no [***4] corporate acts were thereafter performed by them or any successors in office; and that no election, as provided for by Code §§ 69-101 and 69-102, was called and held for the purpose of determining whether or not the act of 1939 or the act of 1955 should become effective. The judge refused to grant the temporary injunction prayed for, and the exception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff residents sought review of a judgment by the Superior Court of Gwinnett County (Georgia), which found in favor of defendant public officials and refused to grant the residents a temporary injunction to prevent the public officials from performing their official duties.


OVERVIEW: The legislature incorporated the Town of Lilburn in 1910. The act of 1939 purported to repeal the incorporating act of 1910. The legislature then incorporated the City of Lilburn by the act of 19955. The residents filed a petition alleging that the public officials were unlawfully performing their duties because neither the act of 1939 nor the act of 1955 were valid. The petition alleged that no election for that purpose was called and held as required by O.C.G.A. §§ 69-101, 69-102. The trial judge refused to grant injunctive relief, and the residents sought review. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that §§ 69-101, 69-102 did not apply to the repeal of a charter granted to a town having a population of less than 50,000. Further, §§ 69-101, 69-102 applied only to cities of less than 50,000 inhabitants and not to incorporated towns having such a population. The court noted that the parties stipulated that the population of the town had at all times been far less than 50,000. Therefore, the court concluded that the act of 1939 legally repealed the act of 1910, and the legislature was entitled to incorporate the City of Lilburn in 1955.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1313 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Pate v. Brock


No. 19591


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 812; 96 S.E.2d 253; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 265


January 15, 1957, Argued  
January 15, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for damages. Before Judge Foster. Polk Superior Court. August 20, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Returned to the Court of Appeals.

 

1314 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Wofford v. Gainesville


No. 19511


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 818; 96 S.E.2d 490; 1957 Ga. LEXIS 270


November 13, 1956, Argued  
January 15, 1957, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied February 13, 1957.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for mandamus. Before Judge Kelley. Hall Superior Court. August 31, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owner appealed a judgment from the Hall Superior Court (Georgia) that dismissed the owner's petition for a writ of mandamus against defendants, the City of Gainesville, Georgia, and various officials, to compel the issuance to him of a building permit to construct a church, pursuant to Gainesville, Ga., Ordinance § 61. The trial court sustained defendants' general demurrer to the petition.


OVERVIEW: The owner's petition attacked the constitutionality of the Act of 1965, 1965 Ga. Laws 2163, which permitted the City to adopt zoning ordinances, and alleged that the only basis of refusal of the permit was Gainesville, Ga., Ordinance § 61, which permitted the construction of churches in a specific zoning classification. On appeal, the court ruled that the owner's petition did not state a cause of action that warranted mandamus relief. The court noted that the petition did not allege that the owner proposed to build a church that did not comply with the regulations, or that his property was within a district that was zoned to prohibit churches. The ordinance did not deny him the right to build a church, but expressly permitted the building of churches in a particular zone. There being no facts alleged that showed that the owner had been injuriously affected by the ordinance or the Act, he was not in a position to attack as unconstitutional the ordinance or the Act. The owner had, but did not pursue, an adequate legal remedy by appealing the denial of the permit, and thus he was not entitled to a writ of mandamus.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1315 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Richmond Concrete Products Co. v. Ward


Nos. 19547, 19548


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 773; 95 S.E.2d 677; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 527


November 14, 1956, Argued  
December 5, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for damages. Before Judge Perryman. McDuffie Superior Court. June 22, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Returned to the Court of Appeals.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a corporation and its principal, appealed an order of the McDuffie Superior Court (Georgia), which denied their motion for a new trial following a judgment in favor of plaintiff in her negligence action against defendants for personal injuries. Plaintiff cross-appealed the trial court's order rejecting the interrogatories she propounded to the president of the corporation.


OVERVIEW: Upon plaintiff's propounding 18 interrogatories to have been answered by the president of the corporation, the corporation made a motion to reject them. The trial court granted the motion on the grounds that they were propounded under a chapter of the 1933 Code of the State of Georgia which was unconstitutional because it attempted to penalize corporations for a failure of its officers to answer interrogatories, depriving the corporation of property without due process of law. The trial court also held that plaintiff failed to comply with the laws in regard to interrogatories. The court held that it had no jurisdiction over the appeal because defendants' attack on the constitutionality of the Georgia Code was insufficient. No particular part of the attacked chapter was specifically pointed out by defendants, requiring the court to examine the entire chapter to find an unconstitutional provision. Because defendants failed to make a clear, definite, and specific attack on a portion of the chapter, the court had no jurisdiction over the attack and the appeal.


OUTCOME: The court returned the matter to the court of appeals.

 

1316 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Atterberry v. State


No. 19517


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 778; 95 S.E.2d 787; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 530


November 13, 1956, Submitted  
December 5, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied December 18, 1956.


PRIOR HISTORY: Usury; constitutional question. Before Judge Heery. Savannah City Court. April 19, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Savannah City Court (Georgia) that convicted him of usury. The trial court overruled defendant's demurrer that the accusation against him violated equal protection guarantees of Ga. Const. art. 1, § 1, para. 25 and U.S. Const. amend. XIV, and denied his motion to suppress. Defendant's motion for a new trial was denied.


OVERVIEW: Defendant charged the victim $ 5 for the use of $ 50 for one week, which amounted to an interest rate of 43 percent per month. While defendant was under investigation for the shooting death of another person, officers entered his car with his permission so as to retrieve a gun. While in the car, the officers seized evidence of other loan transactions, which was introduced at trial after defendant's motion to suppress was denied. On appeal, the court ruled that the accusation against defendant clearly charged an offense under O.C.G.A. § 57-117, and the demurrers that challenged the sufficiency of the accusation were meritless. Defendant's claim that the accusation or § 57-117 were unconstitutional was meritless. Defendant's motion to suppress was properly denied because, inter alia: (1) U.S. Const. amends. IV, V applied only to proceedings in federal courts and had no application to trials in state courts; and (2) the admission in evidence in a state-court trial of articles taken from defendant and car by state officers without a search warrant did not violate Ga. Const. art. 1, § 1, paras. 6, 16, which prohibited unreasonable searches and seizures and compulsory self-incrimination.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1317 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Fulton Bag & Cotton Mills v. Williams


No. 19535


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 783; 95 S.E.2d 848; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 533


November 15, 1956, Argued  
December 5, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied December 18, 1956.


PRIOR HISTORY: Tax refund; constitutional question. Before Judge Pye. Fulton Superior Court. September 7, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer appealed the ruling of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia) that affirmed defendant Revenue Commissioner's denial of the taxpayer's petition for an income tax refund that had been based on sections of a statute that had been stricken when the refund petition was ruled upon.


OVERVIEW: Alleging a net operating loss and claiming a deduction for federal income taxes for prior fiscal years that were paid in 1952, the taxpayer sought a refund. The taxpayer claimed that under Georgia income tax law, it was entitled to carry back as a deduction for its November 1951 fiscal year its net operating loss for the succeeding year, resulting in a reduction in its income tax for 1951. Based on the addition of O.C.G.A. § 92-32109(m)(3)(F), disallowing income taxes as a deduction in computing a net operating loss for all tax years after February 15, 1952, the taxpayer's petition was denied. On appeal, the taxpayer argued that it had an absolute vested right in the income tax law in effect prior to the amendment to § 92-3109 and that such amendment was void and unconstitutional under Ga. Const. art. 1, § 3, para. 2. In rejecting the taxpayer's arguments, the court held that the taxpayer had no vested right in the state's statutory provision of deductions for payment of federal taxes, as such allowance was a privilege. Further, the repeal of the statutory allowance of such a deduction required the Commissioner to apply the law as it existed when he considered the petition.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1318 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Brown v. Newport


No. 19469


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 715; 95 S.E.2d 16; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 507


September 11, 1956, Argued  
October 10, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 15, 1956.


PRIOR HISTORY: Mandamus. Before Judge Moore. Fulton Superior Court. July 3, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, the trustees of a police officers' pension fund of a city, appealed the judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which granted the petition of plaintiff, a retired police officer, that sought a writ of mandamus requiring the trustees to pay the officer the amount of a monthly pension as provided under the Act of 1925, 1925 Ga. Laws 234 and which denied the trustee's motion for a new trial.


OVERVIEW: The officer petitioned for a writ of mandamus requiring the trustees to issue to him a voucher for the balance allegedly due to him as a retired officer and to issue to him future vouchers. The trustees filed a response. The trial court sustained the officer's demurrers to the response and granted mandamus. The trial court denied the trustees' motion for a new trial. On appeal, the court held that the trial court erred in striking from the trustees' response the reasons why the trustees had denied the officer's demand. The court noted that the trustees' response had alleged that the Act of 1925 was repealed by the Act of 1933 and that the pension fund in existence under the 1925 act, at the time of its repeal, had been wholly exhausted. The court also noted that the trustees' response had alleged that the officer was not entitled to payment at a rate of pension as provided under the Act of 1925 out of a fund raised under the Act of 1933. The court ruled that the trial court erred in striking the parts of the trustees' answer setting up that they had no funds out of which to pay the officer's pension under the Act of 1925 and that all subsequent proceedings were therefore nugatory.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1319 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Williams v. Lawler Hosiery Mills, Inc.


No. 19451


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 617; 94 S.E.2d 699; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 467


September 10, 1956, Argued  
October 9, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Constitutional question. Before Judge Smith, pro hac vice. Carroll Superior Court. March 7, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State Revenue Commissioner sought review of a judgment of the Superior Court of Carroll County (Georgia), which denied his motion in arrest, filed in response to the trial court's judgment entered for appellee taxpayer. The Commissioner had proposed an assessment for sales and use tax against the taxpayer. The taxpayer's protest had been overruled in an earlier action.


OVERVIEW: In an earlier proceeding, the taxpayer appealed from the Commissioner's ruling to the trial court. The trial court denied the taxpayer's protest and certain special demurrers were filed. A new Commissioner succeeded to the office. The original trial judge disqualified himself and another was appointed. The new trial judge directed the verdict for the taxpayer. The court held that it was error to direct a verdict in favor of the taxpayer and reversed the judgment. The superior court had power during the same term at which an order or judgment was rendered, to revoke or vacate it for meritorious cause. Such power was not lost during the term merely because the time for excepting to the judgment directly by writ of error had expired. Further, there being no contention that the judge of the superior court was not disqualified to preside in the case, it was not essential to the validity of the appointment by the clerk of a judge pro hac vice to try the case that an effort should have been made by the judge to procure the services of another judge.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

1320 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Bedingfield v. Parkerson


No. 19375


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 654; 94 S.E.2d 714; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 484


June 12, 1956, Argued  
October 8, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied October 22, 1956.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Before Judge Horne. Laurens Superior Court. February 17, 1956.

This is the second appearance of this case in this court, it having been held in the first appearance ( Bedingfield v. Parkerson, 211 Ga. 386, 86 S. E. 2d 215) that the writ of error was prematurely brought to this court, the petitioners having sought to review as a final judgment the overruling of demurrers to the defendants' answer, which raised certain constitutional questions and attacked as unconstitutional the School Reorganization Act of 1953 (Ga. L. 1953, Nov.-Dec. Sess., p. 282). The petitioners, who were the plaintiffs in error in the first appearance and are the plaintiffs in error here, brought an equitable petition to enjoin the enforcement of alleged "consolidation" orders and resolutions of the Laurens County Board of Education, in which petition it is alleged that the orders were adopted in 1951, 1952, and 1953, which was before the passage of the act of 1953. By amendments it is alleged that the board has "grossly abused the discretion vested" therein by consolidation of the schools, disregarding and violating the plain provisions of Code (Ann.)  [***2] § 32-915 (Ga. L. 1919, p. 326; 1946, pp. 206, 207), requiring a consolidated school to be located as near the center of the school district or districts as possible; that the high school here proposed to be established and maintained is not the type of high school authorized by Code § 32-933, since it is to be built entirely from State funds furnished by the State School Building Authority, employ teachers to be paid entirely from State funds, and not from funds raised or made possible through local taxation funds; and that it will be a new, distinct, and independent high school or educational unit; and that it is not as a result of the reorganization or fixing of grades to be taught in or at existing schools or educational units. Demurrers were sustained to these amendments. The answer of the defendants being, in substance, that they were reorganizing and rearranging the schools of the county in a lawful manner in conformity with a resolution adopted January 28, 1954, under the authority of an act of the General Assembly approved December 18, 1953 (Ga. L. 1953, Nov.-Dec. Sess., p. 282), there was an issue of fact to be decided. The case proceeded to trial, and after hearing evidence [***3] -- which was in the main excerpts from the minutes and resolutions of the Laurens County Board of Education for the years 1951, 1952, 1953, and 1954, and the reorganization resolution of January 28, 1954, adopted under the authority of the School Reorganization Act of 1953, whereby the various schools of the county were reorganized and the number of grades fixed at each school in the respective system in accordance with the present plan now under attack -- the court directed a verdict for the defendants and entered judgment and a decree based on said verdict. A motion for new trial and an amendment thereto were subsequently filed, heard, and overruled, and the exceptions here are to all the adverse rulings of the court against the petitioners.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error citizens filed exceptions from a judgment of the Laurens Superior Court (Georgia) which directed a verdict for defendant in error board of education against the citizens' equitable petition. The judgment overruled the citizens' amended motion for new trial on their petition requesting injunctive relief from the board's orders and resolutions regarding a consolidation of schools.


OVERVIEW: The citizens' petition alleged that the board's orders were adopted before passage of the School Reorganization Act of 1953 (Act), 1953 Ga. Laws 282, 283. The citizens' amendments claimed that the board grossly abused its discretion by consolidating the schools, in disregard of and violation of Ga. Code Ann. § 32-915. The contested judgment was affirmed. The court found that the board's resolution passed in 1954 was authorized by the Act because the fact that the same reorganization had occurred before passage of the Act did not prevent an adoption of the resolution. The court held that what the 1954 resolution attempted to accomplish was readily within the board's authority conferred by the Act. The court found that the board's answer was not subject to the citizens' demurrers. The court held that the construction of a new building in order to transfer grades fell within the definition of reorganization. The court correctly overruled the citizens' demurrers because none of their constitutional grounds possessed merit. The court decided that the proposed "new school" was a type provided by Ga. Code Ann. § 32-933, which was the only method provided by law to create high schools.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment challenged by the citizens and entered for the board against the citizen's equitable petition. The judgment overruling the citizens' amended motion for new trial on their petition was affirmed.

 

1321 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Hobbs v. New Eng. Ins. Co.


No. 19337


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 513; 93 S.E.2d 653; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 432


May 15, 1956, Submitted  
July 12, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action on insurance policy; constitutional question. Before Judge Perryman. McDuffie Superior Court. January 14, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After the McDuffie Superior Court (Georgia) denied plaintiff insured a new trial, he filed a bill of exceptions assigning error to the denial of a new trial and to a ruling that Ga. Code Ann. ch. 38-12 (1933) violated the Constitution of Georgia.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff sued defendant to recover on a policy. The trial court directed a verdict for defendant. Plaintiff filed a bill of exceptions assigning error to the denial of a new trial and to a ruling that Ga. Code Ann. ch. 38-12 (1933) violated the Constitution of Georgia. The appellate court transferred the bill of exceptions to the supreme court, which reversed the trial court's judgment. The court held that the trial court erred in directing the verdict for defendant due to the testimony of defendant's agent, who indicated that plaintiff told him that the house covered by the policy had been unoccupied for more than 60 consecutive days prior to the loss. The court determined that the issue of whether plaintiff made the statement and whether plaintiff had full possession of his mental facilities at the time of alleged admission were issues of fact for the jury to determine.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

1322 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


First Fed. Sav. & Loan Asso v. Norwood Realty Co.


No. 19327


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 524; 93 S.E.2d 763; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 434


May 16, 1956, Argued  
July 9, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 24, 1956.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for injunction. Before Judge Whitman. Fulton Superior Court. March 1, 1956.

The plaintiff, a corporation organized and existing under the laws of Georgia, brought a suit against First Federal Savings & Loan Association of Atlanta, a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the United States, and prayed that it be enjoined from exercising a power of sale contained in a security deed which it executed and delivered to the defendant on May 6, 1953. In substance and so far as need be stated, the petition as five times amended, alleges: The defendant agreed to make the plaintiff a construction loan not to exceed $ 6,840,000 for the development of a subdivision known as "Drew Valley." From May 6, 1953, to July 29, 1955, it gave the defendant seven notes aggregating $ 4,329,000, all so connected one with the other as to make a continuous course of dealing. Its first note was for $ 3,420,000, dated May 6, 1953, due May 6, 1954, with interest at 5% per annum on the average daily balance of advances as calculated by the defendant and payable by the plaintiff monthly. From the proceeds of this note and on the day it was given,  [***2] the defendant charged the plaintiff a service charge of $ 85,500. On July 9, 1954, the defendant reduced the face amount of this note $ 921,000. The second note was for $ 79,000 dated January 25, 1954, due May 6, 1954, with interest at 5% per annum on the average daily balance of advances as calculated by the defendant and payable monthly. No payments were made on this note, and it was canceled by the defendant on July 9, 1954. The third note was for $ 300,000, dated September 20, 1954, due December 20, 1955, and from the proceeds thereof the defendant charged the plaintiff a service charge of $ 1,500. The fourth note was for $ 75,000, dated May 6, 1955, due May 6, 1956, and from the proceeds thereof the defendant charged the plaintiff a service charge of $ 375. The fifth note was for $ 85,000, dated June 14, 1955, due May 6, 1956, and from the proceeds thereof the defendant charged the plaintiff a service charge of $ 425. The sixth note was for $ 50,000, dated July 29, 1955, due May 6, 1956, and from the proceeds thereof the defendant charged the plaintiff a service charge of $ 250. The seventh note was for $ 320,000, dated July 29, 1955, due May 6, 1956, and from the proceeds [***3] thereof the defendant charged the plaintiff a service charge of $ 1,600. The last five notes provide for the payment of interest as calculated by the defendant at the rate of 8% per annum on the average daily balance of advances, and payable monthly. The service charge of $ 89,650 was in addition to the amounts paid by the plaintiff for its loan application, for an appraisal of its property, a survey of it, record of the loan deed, inspection of the property, insurance on the property, fees of $ 21,300 paid to the defendant's attorney for his examination of the plaintiff's title and preparation of instruments incident to the loan, and a charge of $ 10 for each check the defendant wrote in disbursement of the loan. The service charge on the first note was reduced $ 25,000 by the defendant on July 9, 1954, by a credit of that amount on the plaintiff's loan account. On July 13, 1954, the plaintiff's account was also credited with $ 4,605 as a refund on fees paid to the defendant's attorney. For the so-called "service charge" the defendant was to render and rendered no service to the plaintiff, and such charge was only a device and contrivance on the defendant's part to charge usury [***4] on the loan. On December 20, 1954, the interest rate on the plaintiff's note for $ 3,420,000 was, pursuant to provisions therefor contained in the note and the loan deed, changed from 5% to 8% per annum, and thereafter interest was calculated on it by the defendant and paid by the plaintiff monthly at the rate of 8% per annum on the average daily balance of advances made. The total amount which the defendant advanced to the plaintiff on the seven notes was $ 3,018,847.68 or $ 1,310,152.32 less than the face amount of them, and the plaintiff never understood why he was required to give the last six notes. The highest daily balance of advances which the plaintiff had at any one time was $ 1,549,642.68. On the amount so advanced, the defendant calculated and charged to the plaintiff's loan account the sum of $ 140,848.33 as interest. This amount when added to the so-called "service charge" of $ 63,050, which is disguised interest, makes the amount which the defendant charged the plaintiff for the use of its money $ 203,898.33 or interest at the rate of 9.29% per annum. During August, after its note for $ 320,000 was given on July 29, 1955, while the defendant was actively proceeding [***5] with the construction of its subdivision and when several of its houses were unfinished, the defendant notified the plaintiff that no further advances would be made on the notes, and thereafter wrongfully refused to advance any further amount. Of the $ 3,018,847.68 which the defendant advanced the plaintiff on the seven notes, the plaintiff has from February 8, 1954, to October 3, 1955, repaid on principal advanced $ 2,336,955 leaving a balance due on principal of $ 681,892.68. By monthly payments beginning June 5, 1953, and ending July 29, 1955, the plaintiff paid the defendant $ 123,770.10 as interest, and this amount together with the so-called "service charge" of $ 63,050, which is in fact disguised interest taken by the defendant, should, because of the defendant's usurious charge for the use of its money, be credited on the principal amount advanced the plaintiff; and with these amounts ($ 186,820.10) so credited, as they should be, the plaintiff is due the defendant only $ 495,072.58. On October 6, 1955, the defendant started a foreclosure sale of the property conveyed by the loan deed. On October 27, 1955, the plaintiff made an actual unconditional tender to the defendant [***6] of $ 495,072.58 -- the full amount it was then due the defendant with all interest including service charges as disguised interest forfeited. The tender was refused. The amended petition was demurred to generally on the ground that it failed to state a cause of action either at law or in equity and specially on several grounds. The general demurrer was overruled, but the grounds of special demurrer were not passed on. The defendant excepted.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff debtor brought an action in a Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia) to restrain defendant creditor from exercising a power of sale contained in a security deed that was executed and delivered to it by the debtor. The creditor appealed from the judgment that overruled its general demurrer to the debtor's petition.


OVERVIEW: The creditor was a savings and loan association that provided a construction loan to the debtor and charged a $ 63,050 service charge for the loan application. The debtor argued that the service charge was a device and contrivance to charge usury on the loan. The court held that the judgment complained of was not erroneous. The court first determined that as a federal savings and loan association doing business in the State of Georgia, the creditor was subject to the operation of and was required to comply with the State's usury laws and with those of 12 U.S.C.S. § 1425 in making loans. The court also determined that the allegations in the debtor's petition were sufficient to show that no service was in fact rendered by the creditor to the debtor in exchange for the service charge. The court accordingly reasoned that the so-called service charge was taken by the creditor only for the use of the debtor's money and was therefore a device and contrivance on the creditor's part to exact usury. The court concluded that the debtor was entitled to an injunction to prevent a sale of his property because he had made a valid continuing tender of the amount due under the loan.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that overruled the creditor's general demurrer to the debtor's petition.

 

1323 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Parks v. State


No. 19280


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 433; 93 S.E.2d 663; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 400


March 12, 1956, Argued  
May 14, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied June 14, 1956.


PRIOR HISTORY: Robbery by force. Before Judge Hicks. Floyd Superior Court. January 4, 1956.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Floyd Superior Court (Georgia) that, following his conviction for an unspecified crime, denied his motion for a new trial.


OVERVIEW: Defendant raised a special ground for the motion for a new trial in which he excepted to the charge of the trial court on his statement, upon the ground that he made no statement not under oath. The court rejected the claim as meritless, noting that while a defendant was prohibited under the law from making a statement under oath and it appeared that he was first sworn as a witness and then made what appeared in the record a "statement," the record did not show that the law was violated in this respect. The court then ruled that reversal was warranted because the State failed to prove venue, proof of which was part of the State's case, under Ga. Const. art. 6, § 14, para. 6, Ga. Code Ann. § 2-4906, and the court's precedent. The court ruled that 1911 Ga. Laws 149, Ga. Code Ann. § 6-1609, which prohibited court's from reversing convictions for lack of proof of venue or of the time of the commission of the offense, except where the issue had been raised specifically by a ground of a motion for a new trial, was an unconstitutional invasion by the legislature into the judiciary's function. Section 6-1609 was not binding upon the court, the court ruled.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that denied defendant's motion for a new trial.

 

1324 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Patterson v. Florida Realty & Finance Corp.


No. 19294


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 440; 93 S.E.2d 571; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 403


April 9, 1956, Argued  
May 14, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied June 14, 1956.


PRIOR HISTORY: Land registration. Before Judge Moore. Fulton Superior Court. January 26, 1956.

Florida Realty & Finance Corporation and C. J. Camp brought their petition to register title to certain described land. They set out their chain of title under which they claimed the land, which was, in so far as is material here, a tax deed to a remote grantor, which was executed on October 5, 1943, under an execution and sale in the name of Mrs. Lillian Worsham against the property as the property of Mrs. Lillian Worsham, to satisfy the claim of the City of Atlanta for municipal taxes for the year 1936.

On September 9, 1954, M. L. Patterson filed his plea and answer to the petition for registration and set up his claim to the land in question. The claim of M. L. Patterson was based upon a tax deed executed to the City of Atlanta on August 5, 1947, under an execution and sale in the name of Mrs. Lillian Worsham against the property as the property of Mrs. Lillian Worsham, to satisfy the claim of the City of Atlanta for municipal taxes for the years 1940-1946; a quitclaim deed from the Mayor of the City of Atlanta to M. L. Patterson, dated December 8, 1948;  [***2] a quitclaim deed from Mrs. Lillian Worsham to M. L. Patterson dated August 26, 1954; and a so-called Resolution of Ratification dated September 22, 1954, by the Mayor and Council of the City of Atlanta confirming the quitclaim deed executed in 1948, above referred to.

Upon the hearing, during which the only evidence submitted was the documentary evidence, the petitioners contended that they had good title to the property by virtue of their deeds under the act of the General Assembly enacted in 1949 (Ga. L. 1949, p. 1132 et seq.; Code, Ann. Supp., §§ 92-8315 and 92-8316), which reads in part as follows: "Nothing contained in sections 92-8301, 92-8306 to 92-8314, inclusive, shall prevent a title under a tax deed from ripening by prescription after a period of seven years from the date of the execution of the tax deed. Any tax deed regularly executed at a valid and legal sale held by the State or any subdivision thereof, including counties and municipalities, when the defendant in fi. fa. is sui juris, shall after the expiration of seven years from the date of said tax deed convey fee simple title and title to the property described in said tax deed shall vest absolutely in the grantee [***3] therein or his heirs or assigns."

The defendant contended that the petitioners had no interest in the land because the sale for 1940-1946 taxes in 1947, which was subsequent to the execution of the tax deed to petitioners' remote grantor, divested them of their interest, and that the defendant by virtue of the deeds from the City of Atlanta and Mrs. Lillian Worsham was entitled to have the land registered in his name. There was no evidence that either party had ever been in possession of the land.

Upon the completion of the hearing, the examiner found that the petitioners had good title to the land and were entitled to have title registered as prayed. The defendant filed his exceptions to the report of the examiner, which were duly overruled by the superior court. The exception here is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent buyer appealed a judgment of the Fulton County Superior Court (Georgia), which accepted the findings of an examiner and entered a judgment in favor of petitioner buyers in the buyers' action to register land. The superior court overruled respondent's exceptions to the examiner's finding that petitioners had good title to the land in question and were entitled to have the land registered as prayed.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners received title to the property in 1943 from a remote grantor, who held a tax deed for the property. Respondent claimed to have received title to the land from the city in 1948 and from the former owner in 1954. Petitioners contended that they had good title under the Act of 1949, Ga. Code Ann. § 92-8315-6, which provided that a tax deed ripened by prescription after seven years. Respondent argued that the city's tax sale of the property in 1947 divested them of their interest. Respondent filed an answer to the petition in 1954. On appeal from a judgment in favor of petitioners, the court affirmed, finding that the city had no interest in the property at the time it executed the deed to respondent and that petitioners interest had vested. The court found that the city had no right to sell the property under a tax execution because the former owner, against whom it was levied had no title or possession. The sale was void as to the true owners, petitioners, and petitioners were not divested in their interest by the city's attempted tax sale. The court found that respondent had no interest in the property because neither the city or the former owner had title to pass.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the superior court's judgment.

 

1325 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Anthony v. Penn


No. 19253


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 292; 92 S.E.2d 14; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 345


February 14, 1956, Submitted  
March 12, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Alimony. Before Judge Fort. Muscogee Superior Court. December 2, 1955.

The plaintiff filed an action against her former husband to modify an alimony decree. It was alleged that, in May, 1942, a final verdict and decree were entered in the superior court, wherein the defendant was required to pay $ 10 per month for the support of each child of the parties until 18 years of age, and that two of the children for whom such allowance was made are now 16 and 14 years of age, respectively. At the time the original decree was entered, the defendant owned property of an approximate value of $ 6,500. At the time of the filing of the application to modify, the defendant is worth approximately $ 200,000. The plaintiff prayed for process and for revision of the alimony decree.

The defendant demurred to the petition on the ground that it failed to set forth a cause of action against him, and on the further ground that the act approved March 9, 1955, entitled, "Modification of Permanent Alimony Judgments," (Ga. L. 1955, p. 630), is unconstitutional and void, being in violation of the Constitution, art. I, sec. III, par. II (Code, Ann., § 2-302), if applied to an alimony judgment rendered [***2] prior to the passage of the act.

The demurrers were overruled, and the exeception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.

 

1326 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Kryder v. State


No. 19186


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 272; 91 S.E.2d 612; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 336


January 11, 1956, Argued  
February 14, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 1, 1956.


PRIOR HISTORY: Burglary; constitutional question. Before Judge Shaw. Fulton Superior Court. September 15, 1955.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) convicted defendant of burglary. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended in his motion to quash that the allegations in the indictment as to previous convictions were prejudicial as tending to place his character in issue. The court held that such contention was without merit. The defendant also contended that the act of 1953, 1953 Ga. Laws 289 was unconstitutional. The act of 1953 provided that that a person who commits a felony after having been three times convicted must upon conviction of the fourth offense, server the maximum time provided in the sentence and was not eligible for parole until the maximum had been served. The court held that the act of 1953 did not in any wise affect the question of the guilt or innocence of defendant that was under review. The court held that only in the event that conviction was upheld, and when the time arrived when he might claim the right to a parole and the act was asserted as a bar to such alleged right, could defendant claim the right to attack the validity of the act. The court held that the evidence fully supported the verdict and there was no error in denying the motion for new trial.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1327 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Lanier v. Suttles


No. 19151


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 154; 91 S.E.2d 21; 1956 Ga. LEXIS 286


November 15, 1955, Argued  
January 10, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Before Judge Hicks, presiding. Fulton Superior Court. September 9, 1955.

J. Sidney Lanier and E. B. Lanier filed in Fulton Superior Court, against T. E. Suttles, Tax Collector, and the Joint Board of City and County Tax Assessors, a petition, which as amended alleged substantially the following: The petitioners are the owners of designated lots in the cities of East Point, Hapeville, and Atlanta. The over-all increase in assessments made by the Joint Board of City and County Tax Assessors over the amounts assessed by the Tax Assessors of the City of East Point, is $ 2,720. Neither the Joint Board of City and County Tax Assessors, nor any member thereof, has been by, on, through, in, or near any of the properties herein named for appraisal for tax purposes, nor was any notice of change in tax assessments for said properties given petitioners, as required by law. Since no incorporated city in Fulton County is represented on the Joint Board of City and County Tax Assessors, with the exception of the City of Atlanta, said board is unconstitutional, and tax assessments by said board are inequitable, unfair, and unjust; the cities have duly appointed or legally elected [***2] tax assessors of their own, and assessments made by such assessors are binding on all parties, including Fulton County; the assessments of taxes by two different agencies on the same realty in different amounts, without representation, is illegal, unconstitutional, unfair, and unjust to the property owner, and amounts to taxation without representation. Petitioners have no adequate remedy at law, for the reason that the Fulton County Board of Appeals is unconstitutional for the same reason that the Joint Board of City and County Tax Assessors is unconstitutional, having been created by the same act of the legislature. The petitioners prayed: that process and a rule nisi issue; that the tax collector be enjoined from collecting taxes from the petitioners, on any assessments made by the Joint Board of City and County Tax Assessors, in excess of the taxes on assesments made by the Tax Assessors of the City of East Point; that the Joint Board of City and County Tax Assessors be enjoined from making any tax assessments on the petitioners' property without representation on said board from the incorporated cities in which the petitioners' properties are located.

General and special grounds [***3] of demurrer were interposed by the defendants to the petition as amended. The trial court sustained the defendants' general demurrer and dismissed the action, to which ruling the petitioners excepted.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayers sought review of a decision of the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which sustained the demurrer of defendants, a tax collector and the Joint Board of City and County Tax Assessors, in the taxpayers' action to enjoin defendants from making any tax assessments on their property without representation before the Board from the cities in which the property was located.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers asserted that there had been over-all increase in assessments made by the Board over the amounts assessed by city assessors despite the fact that no member of the Board had been by, on, through, in, or near any of the properties at issue, and no notice of change in tax assessments was given to them, as required by law. The taxpayers sought an injunction from the trial court on the basis that the Board and the Fulton County Board of Appeals was unconstitutional. The court determined that defendants' demurrer was properly sustained. First, the allegations in the taxpayers' petition did not state what provisions of the Georgia or United States Constitution were alleged to be violated. Additionally, an injunction could not have been properly issued because the only reason given by the taxpayers for their not having an adequate remedy at law was that the County Board of Appeals was unconstitutional. As no constitutional question was properly raised, the allegation as to no adequate remedy at law failed, because where all the relief sought by a party could be obtained in a manner provided by law, a suit in equity for injunction was without merit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the trial court.

 

1328 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Humthlett v. Reeves


Nos. 19042, 19043


Supreme Court of Georgia


212 Ga. 8; 90 S.E.2d 14; 1955 Ga. LEXIS 524


September 12, 1955, Argued  
October 13, 1955, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 16, 1955.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Before Judge Manning. Cobb Superior Court. May 13, 1955.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed on the main bill of exceptions; cross-bill of exceptions dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs appealed from a decree of the Cobb Superior Court (Georgia) that denied their prayer for a permanent injunction after a nonjury trial in plaintiffs' action challenging the zoning of defendant landowners' property for cemetery purposes by the Cobb County Planning Commission pursuant to 1943 Ga. Laws 892 as amended in 1949 (1943 act). The landowners cross-appealed from some of the trial court's findings of fact and conclusions of law.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs alleged that the 1943 act, which established the commission and empowered it to enact zoning laws, violated the Georgia Constitution, and that the landowners' property was limited to residential and agricultural uses by a 1939 zoning ordinance. The court affirmed the judgment and dismissed the cross-appeal. The court held that, by delegating the authority to enact zoning and planning laws to the commission, the 1943 act violated Ga. Const. art. III, § 7, para. 23 (1945), Ga. Code Ann. § 2-1923. The county commissioner of roads and revenues, not the commission, was the county's governing authority with the authority to enact zoning laws. The court determined, however, that the 1939 ordinance was arbitrary and capricious as applied to the disputed property. An air base, an airplane factory, and several commercial enterprises had been built nearby, and an easement had been created over part of the property that limited the height of trees and structures to the glide angle plane of airplanes landing and taking off. The property was therefore unsuitable for residential or agricultural use and the ordinance was unreasonable as applied to the landowners' property.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decree that denied plaintiffs' prayer for a permanent injunction against the zoning of the landowners' property for cemetery purposes and dismissed the land-owners' cross-appeal.

 

1329 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Moultrie v. Colquitt County Rural Elec. Co.


No. 18976


Supreme Court of Georgia


211 Ga. 842; 89 S.E.2d 657; 1955 Ga. LEXIS 486


June 13, 1955, Argued  
September 16, 1955, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied October 13, 1955.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Before Judge Lilly. Colquitt Superior Court.

Colquitt County Rural Electric Company filed a petition for equitable relief against City of Moultrie, its chief of police, and city manager, and in substance alleged: (4) About 1947, a residential subdivision east of the City of Moultrie, known as East Moultrie Heights, was created and homes were constructed therein. Prior to the creation of the subdivision, and during its development, the petitioner has served the subdivision with electrical energy. (5) There are three blocks in section 2, known as 6, 7, and 8, through which the petitioner has had distribution lines for a number of years. (6) On or about October 23, 1954, the owner of East Moultrie Heights Subdivision made application to the petitioner for service to houses that were to be constructed in blocks 6, 7, and 8, and on or about October 26, 1954, the petitioner began running service lines for dwellings under construction, "petitioner now serving about 10 houses under construction." (7) On or about November 15, 1954, the city advised the petitioner that it was annexing blocks 6, 7, and 8, and requested the petitioner [***2] to remove its lines therefrom. (8) On February 14, 1955, while the petitioner's employees were installing service to houses therein, police officers of the city arrested the employees. (9) There is an ordinance appearing on the ordinance book of the city, which appears to have been read the first and second times on January 4, 1955, and the third time on January 18, 1955, a copy being attached and marked Exhibit "A." (10) Blocks 6, 7, and 8 in the subdivision are not within the corporate limits of the City of Moultrie, but if in such area, the petitioner would be entitled to continue furnishing electrical energy to its customers.
