It is alleged: that, as the Commission has no right to regulate or control the Power Company in the respects contemplated by the rule nisi, it has no right to require the Power Company to come before it to show cause why it should not [***6] issue an order along the lines indicated; that a compliance with the rule by the Power Company would require considerable time on the part of its employees and considerable expense to the Power Company, and it would have no remedy to recoup its loss of time and money caused by the proposed illegal, void, and unconstitutional attempt to invade the rights of the Power company and to deprive it of its property without due process of law; that, under Code §§ 93-416 and 93-9901, it would be subjected to severe penalties of as much as $ 5,000 for each offense, and its officers, agents, and employees subjected to criminal prosecution for failure to comply with any such invalid order that might be issued by the Commission, and that unless enjoined, the Power Company would be subjected to irreparable injury and damage and a multiplicity of criminal actions against its agents.

To this petition the defendants demurred upon the grounds: (a) that the petition sets forth no cause of action; and (b) the petition shows on its face that the plaintiff had failed to exhaust its remedy before the Commission, having failed to make an appearance in response to the rule nisi. To the judgment sustaining [***7] this demurrer and dismissing the petition the plaintiff excepts.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner power company appealed the judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) dismissing its lawsuit seeking to overturn the order, issued by respondent state agency, commanding it to purchase a rival power company.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner power company appealed a judgment dismissing its lawsuit seeking to overturn respondent state agency's order compelling petitioner to purchase a rival. The court reversed the judgment below, thus overturning respondent's order. The court held that respondent possessed only such power as was granted to it by state law and that there was no state law authorizing respondent to command one power company to buy another. That order was accordingly set aside as unlawful.


OUTCOME: The judgment below was reversed, inasmuch as the court below erred in not overturning respondent's order. Respondent simply lacked the power to issue such a decree, it being a creature of statute and there being no statutory authorization for such an order.

 

1344 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Boatright v. Yates


No. 18733


Supreme Court of Georgia


211 Ga. 125; 84 S.E.2d 195; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 515


September 15, 1954, Argued  
October 13, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Before Judge Boykin. Carroll Superior Court. June 21, 1954.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers appealed the judgment of the Superior Court of Carroll County (Georgia), which dismissed their petition for an injunction against defendants, a county board of education and its superintendent, to enjoin the building of a new high school.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers sought to enjoin the building of a new high school in their county, alleging that the board abused its discretion in making the decision to build and that the hearing held on the matter was "utterly futile." The taxpayers also alleged that a statute empowering the board to reorganize the schools within its jurisdiction was unconstitutional. The trial court sustained the general demurrer of defendants and dismissed the taxpayers' petition. The taxpayers appealed, and the court affirmed. The trial court properly sustained the general demurrer because the taxpayers had an adequate and complete remedy at law, according to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 32-414, by appealing the board's decision to build the school to a state board of education. The court refused to pass on the taxpayers' constitutional challenge because a determination of the statute's validity was not necessary.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1345 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Pritchard v. Board of Comm'rs


No. 18690


Supreme Court of Georgia


211 Ga. 57; 84 S.E.2d 26; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 486


September 17, 1954, Argued  
October 11, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Before Judge Vaughn. DeKalb Superior Court. May 26, 1954.

C. F. Pritchard, a deputy sheriff of Richmond County, Georgia, from February, 1938, to August, 1953, petitioned the Superior Court of DeKalb County for issuance of a writ of mandamus absolute requiring the Board of Commissioners of the Peace Officers Annuity & Benefit Fund of Georgia to certify his eligibility for a pension under the act of February 1, 1950, of the General Assembly of Georgia (Ga. L. 1950, pp. 50, 58) and direct payment to him of a pension under said act. Briefly stated, his petition alleged the following facts: That, under the act of 1950, above cited, he made application and was admitted as a member of the pension fund and began making payments on January 29, 1951, and continued to do so through August, 1953; that on August 8, 1953, he made application for retirement under section 12 of the act, upon the ground that he was permanently and totally disabled, and that, notwithstanding he qualified in every respect required by the act, his application was disapproved on November 25, 1953.

To his petition the defendants filed a general demurrer on the ground that the petition failed to state [***2] a cause of action. The trial court sustained the general demurrer and dismissed the petition, to which judgment the plaintiff in error excepted, and brings his case to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner deputy sheriff challenged the decision of the Superior Court of DeKalb County (Georgia), which disapproved his application for disability benefits pursuant to the act of 1950, 1950 Ga. Laws § 12, and dismissed his petition against respondent, the Board of Commissioners of the Peace Officers Annuity & Benefit Fund of Georgia. The sheriff sought an action in mandamus to require the Board to certify his eligibility for benefits.


OVERVIEW: Section 12 had provided for a pension for any officer who had become totally or permanently disabled after having served a required length of time. The sheriff made application for retirement under § 12 on the basis that he was permanently and totally disabled. The sheriff contended that the act of 1951 § 4, which repealed § 12 of the act of 1950, was unconstitutional for the reason that it violated U.S. Const. art. I, § X, para. I, U.S.C.S. § 1-134, and Ga. Const. art. I, § III, para. II, O.C.G.A. § 2-302, which provided that no ex post facto law, retroactive law, or law impairing the obligation of contracts could be passed. The court affirmed the denial of the writ of mandamus because the constitutional provisions had not been violated. The court found that in the passing of the original act in 1950, the legislature specifically provided that all rights and benefits provided were subject to future legislative change or revision and that no beneficiary would have been deemed to have any vested right to any annuities or benefits provided therein. The court held that even if the sheriff had vested rights, there was no vested right to a continuation of the original plan.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1346 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Swiney v. Forest Park


No. 18693


Supreme Court of Georgia


211 Ga. 154; 84 S.E.2d 573; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 534


September 13, 1954, Argued  
October 11, 1954, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 10, 1954.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for injunction. Before Judge Guess. Clayton Superior Court. May 3, 1954.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners appealed the judgment of the Clayton Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained the demurrer of defendants, a city and its mayor and councilmen, in an action seeking an injunction enjoining defendants from enforcing an act enlarging the city limits.


OVERVIEW: The owners filed a petition for injunction, alleging that the enlargement of the city limits, pursuant to an act of the general assembly, made them liable for additional taxes and licenses for businesses conducted by them. The trial court sustained defendants' demurrer to the petition, and the owners appealed. The court held that the owners' contention that the notice of legislation was insufficient was without merit. The court found that, such a notice as that involved, signed by the duly elected representatives from the county in which the municipality was located, which proposed to amend the charter of a named Georgia municipality, necessarily referred to the General Assembly of Georgia, which would be in session within 60 days from the date of the first publication, since the Georgia Constitution required that such notice be published during a period of 60 days immediately preceding the introduction of the proposed legislation, and there was no contention that the notice was not published as required. The court also found that the words "to define said limits of said city" were sufficiently broad to include the extension of the corporate limits.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1347 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


West v. Housing Authority of Atlanta


Nos. 18662, 18666


Supreme Court of Georgia


211 Ga. 133; 84 S.E.2d 30; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 488


July 13, 1954, Argued  
September 14, 1954, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied October 14, 1954.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Before Judge Pharr. Fulton Superior Court. April 22, 1954.

This case arose when the plaintiffs (now plaintiffs in error) filed suit in Fulton Superior Court to enjoin the defendant Housing Authority from constructing a housing project in the City of Atlanta known as Project GA-6-7. The plaintiffs alleged: that they were the owners of properties within the project area; that the area in question was not a slum; that no necessity existed for the project which would justify the taking of their properties; that the real purpose of the project was not to provide housing but to create a racial barrier; that the plan was not submitted to or considered by the State Housing Authority Board as required by law; and that the plan was ultra vires and void because it failed to conform to the city zoning ordinances as required by the State Housing Authorities Law. It was also alleged that under the plan the housing would cost approximately $ 13,000 per unit, which was more than twice the sum required by private enterprise to provide similar accommodations; and that the expenditure of such sum constituted an unwarranted perversion of the [***2] authority vested in the Housing Authority under the Housing Authorities Law. By amendment it was alleged that the plan was unconstitutional and void because occupancy of the housing to be constructed was restricted to white people only. The prayers of the petition were for an injunction and general relief, and by amendment facts were alleged for the purpose of showing an actual controversy, and asking for a declaratory judgment.

The defendant filed an answer denying the material allegations of the petition, and demurrers directed to certain specific allegations. At a hearing on the demurrers, the allegations concerning the cost of the project, violation of the city zoning laws, and restriction of the project to white persons, were stricken from the petition. Exceptions pendente lite were duly filed to these rulings, and are now before this court.

The case proceeded to trial and, at the conclusion of the evidence, was submitted to the jury upon the following single question: "The determination by the Housing Authority . . . to proceed with Project GA-6-7, upon the basis that there is a shortage of decent, safe and sanitary dwelling accommodations for persons of low income within [***3] the area of the City of Atlanta, was (1) an abuse of discretion, or (2) not an abuse of discretion."

The jury found for the defendant, that its action was not an abuse of discretion. The plaintiffs' amended motion for a new trial was denied, and the present bill of exceptions was sued out within 20 days thereafter.

The plaintiffs complain of the ruling on demurrer striking three paragraphs of their petition; they complain on the general grounds of their motion for a new trial; and in their amended motion they insist that the court misconceived the law applicable to the case, and erroneously instructed the jury in such manner as to make a finding for the Housing Authority virtually inevitable.

The defendant by cross-bill of exceptions complains of certain rulings on its special demurrers to the petition.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed on the main bill of exceptions; cross-bill dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowners sought review of the decision of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which entered judgment in favor of defendant city housing authority, in the landowners' action for an injunction to enjoin the authority from constructing a housing project.


OVERVIEW: The landowners brought an action seeking to enjoin the housing authority from taking their property in order to construct a housing project for low-income city residents. The lower court entered judgment in favor of the authority, and held that it did not abuse its discretion and the court affirmed. The court found that there was no error in permitting the authority to condemn the property, even though the property had not been rezoned prior to the condemnation. The court determined that the landowners were not in a position to challenge the authority's alleged decision to only permit whites to occupy the new project because the landowners were not being unlawfully discriminated against. The court found that the landowners had no legal right to complain about the potential expenditures of the authority on the project. The court concluded that the lower court properly instructed the jury as to the pertinent standard of review and did not err in submitting only one question to the jury for its determination where the landowners did not propose any additional questions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the authority in the landowners' action to enjoin the construction of a housing project.

 

1348 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Gordy v. Dunwody


No. 18618


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 810; 83 S.E.2d 7; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 450


June 15, 1954, Argued  
July 13, 1954, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 27, 1954.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Before Judge Atkinson. Bibb Superior Court. March 25, 1954.

This case is an equitable one involving alleged trade-name infringement, brought by the plaintiff in error to enjoin the defendants in error from using in the name of their drive-in eating establishment in Macon, Georgia, the word "Varsity," thereby engaging in unfair competition with the petitioner and infringing upon his trade name, "The Varsity," under which he has continuously operated in Atlanta, Georgia, since 1928. In the first appearance here, Gordy v. Dunwody, 209 Ga. 627 (74 S. E. 2d 886), this court ruled that the lower court was in error in sustaining both general and special demurrers in so far as the allegations relating to the trade name are concerned, but not as to infringement of trade-mark or in striking certain allegations as to interference with future expansion of the petitioner's business. The case is now here after a trial in the lower court in which the jury returned a verdict in the form of answers to two questions submitted to the jury, the answers being against the contentions of the plaintiff. The exception is to a judgment denying a motion [***2] for new trial containing 29 grounds, 26 of which are special grounds added by amendment.

Seven of the grounds complain of the allowance in evidence of certain testimony or refusal of the court to strike certain testimony of witnesses. Grounds 4, 5, 10, 18, and 19 complain of the allowance in evidence of testimony as to the existence of other varsity eating establishments in other parts of Georgia and throughout the country. The grounds of complaint, in substance, are that the existence of such eating establishments other than in Georgia was not a material factor, and the petitioner's claim is that he only has an interest in the name as it applies to drive-in eating establishments in Georgia. Ground 9 complains of the allowance in evidence of information as to the status of Gordy's business, on the ground that it was irrelevant and immaterial since he was not claiming that this establishment had caused him to lose business. Ground 11 complains of hearsay testimony as to what a group of boys had told a witness in a "bull session" as to the fact that the businesses were not connected in any way. Ground 15 complains of testimony admitted in a deposition of one of the defendants that [***3] radio spot announcements of the Macon drive-in had contained the words "locally owned," because the witness admitted he had not heard the radio spot advertisements. Grounds 16 and 17 complain of the refusal of the court to strike testimony of a witness in regard to signs he had painted for eating establishments which contained the word "Varsity." Ground 20 complains of the allowance in evidence of the testimony of the defendants' manager that neither business was affected by the other on the ground that it was an illegal conclusion of the witness. Ground 21 complains of the admission in evidence of county court records showing the trade-name registration of a partnership, and its later dissolution to be thereafter conducted by only one of the partners, of an Augusta eating establishment using the word "Varsity."

Six of the grounds complain of the exclusion of evidence. Ground 6 complains of the exclusion of testimony of an employee of Gordy that a number of persons had complained to him of the quality of the food served in the Macon establishment. Grounds 7 and 8 complain of the exclusion of evidence that Gordy had had trouble before in instances in which the word "Varsity" had [***4] been used in the name of other eating establishments, and in one case in Cobb County he had obtained an injunction against the use thereof. Ground 12 complains of the exclusion of testimony that at one time the defendants had thought to compromise the case with Gordy. Ground 13 complains of the exclusion of testimony of one of the defendants, who also was in the brick business, as to what his attitude was in regard to other businesses using the same name as his brick business. Ground 14 complains of the exclusion of testimony of another defendant with regard to the building and opening of Pig'n Whistle eating establishments in several other places in Georgia.

Three of the special grounds complain of excerpts from the charge. Ground 24 complains of an excerpt that the jury, in determining whether or not the public would be likely to be deceived, would think of the public as composed of ordinarily prudent persons or reasonably cautious persons; the ground of complaint being that the test is not whether the public would be likely deceived, but whether a reasonably cautious person might be. Grounds 25 and 26 are complaints as to excerpts that, in order for the plaintiff to prevail,  [***5] he must establish by a preponderance of evidence either that the word "Varsity" was used with the actual intention to deceive or mislead, or that it is such an imitation that the nature and probable tendency of such usage is to deceive the public, because it failed to charge that by the use of the word "Varsity" plaintiff had acquired a right in its usage such that its use by the Macon establishment in an area where plaintiff's establishment and good will was known he would be entitled to recover irrespective of any actual intent to deceive the public.

Special grounds 27, 28, and 29 complain of the failure to charge as requested in writing, in substance, that (a) there was such an imitation here that a reasonably cautious person might confuse the two, (b) the mere fact that there are other eating establishments using the word "Varsity" would not constitute a defense, and (c) intent is one's state of mind and can be proved by circumstances from facts proved.

Grounds 22 and 23 are complaints of the failure of the court to submit special questions to the jury for findings of fact by special verdict, and because the court erred in submitting other special questions, and no others, to [***6] the jury for findings of fact by special verdict. The questions which were submitted and rejected were as follows:

"1. Has the plaintiff used in his business the trade name 'The Varsity' for substantially the period of time set forth in his petition? Answer yes or no.

"2. Did the plaintiff register his trade name and trade-mark as set forth in his petition? Answer yes or no.

"3. Did the defendants, or any of them, know at the time of the commencement of their business by them in Macon, Georgia, known as 'Varsity Drive-In,' that the plaintiff had the right of use of the trade name 'The Varsity'? Answer yes or no.

"4. Is the business of the plaintiff in Atlanta, Georgia, and the business of the defendants in Macon, Georgia, of the same type that is, do they both serve food and beverages to their respective customers? Answer yes or no.

"5. Are the methods of the defendants in their business in Macon, Georgia, and of the plaintiff in his business in Atlanta, Georgia, substantially the same in the serving of their respective customers? Answer yes or no."

The questions actually submitted were as follows:

"1. Was or is the use of the defendants of the word 'Varsity' in their [***7] operations and trade name originally or subsequently with the intention of deceiving and misleading the public into the belief that the goods and services of the defendants are the goods and services of the plaintiff?

"2. Was or is the use by the defendants of the word 'Varsity' in their operations and trade name such an imitation of the plaintiff's operations and trade name that the nature and probable tendency and effect of such usage would be to deceive the public and pass off defendants' goods or business as that of the plaintiff?"

The complaint is that the questions offered by the plaintiff covered the issues of fact which the jury had to decide and were not covered by the actual questions submitted.

A motion to dismiss the bill of exceptions has been filed on the ground that it was tendered and certified twenty-six days after the judgment complained of here was rendered, and since it was filed too late this court is without jurisdiction.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant trade-name owner sought review of a decision from the Superior Court of Bibb County (Georgia), which entered judgment on special jury verdicts in favor of appellee, an alleged infringer, in an action brought by the trade-name owner seeking to enjoin the alleged infringer from using the word "varsity" in the name of his drive-in restaurant.


OVERVIEW: The trade-name owner sought to enjoin the alleged infringer from using the word "varsity" in the name of his drive-in restaurant. The trade-name owner claimed that he had operated under the name "The Varsity" continuously since 1928. A jury returned special verdicts against the trade-name owner. The trial court denied the trade-name owner's motion for a new trial. On appeal, the alleged infringer filed a motion to dismiss the bill of exceptions on the ground that the bill was not timely filed. The court denied the motion where the time limit within which to tender a bill of exceptions was amended from 20 to 30 days, the amendment was valid, and the trade-name owner filed within 30 days. The court held, however, that: (1) where the trade name owner's request to charge the jury contained a statement that a jury could infer a charge was well founded from the fact that a witness did not appear to testify was an incorrect statement of the law and was rightfully rejected; and (2) it was not error for the trial court to charge the jury that in order for the trade-name owner to recover, the facts and circumstances would have to be such as would likely deceive the public.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision from the trial court, which denied the trade name owner's motion for a new trial.

 

1349 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Housing Auth. v. Spink


No. 18611


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 718; 82 S.E.2d 502; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 410


June 14, 1954, Submitted  
June 14, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Condemnation. Before Judge Paschall. Gordon Superior Court. April 1, 1954.



DISPOSITION: Transferred to the Court of Appeals. 

 

1350 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Redwine v. Schenley Industries, Inc.


No. 18572


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 769; 83 S.E.2d 16; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 452


May 11, 1954, Argued  
June 14, 1954, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 14, 1954.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for tax refund. Before Judge Pharr. Fulton Superior Court. January 20, 1954.

Schenley Industries, Inc., filed suit against Charles D. Redwine as State Revenue Commissioner of Georgia to recover various sums paid by it and its subsidiaries as income taxes alleged to be due by the Commissioner and his predecessors in office for the fiscal years ending December 31, 1938, through August 31, 1946, and the fiscal year ending August 31, 1948, the complaint being that claims for refund were filed within the time authorized by law but denied. The petition is in ten counts and, in substance, alleges that the petitioner, the defendant in error, is a foreign corporation acting as selling company for its various subsidiary companies who are also foreign corporations; that all of the distilling and producing plants of the companies are located in various States other than Georgia, and the sales office is located in New York City; that the regulations of the State Revenue Commissioner have been met particularly with reference to the registration of brands, the designation of resident and nonresident representatives who are the only agents or employees [***2] in Georgia and who solicit orders from customers in Georgia, which expressly provide that they are subject to written acceptance of the selling company in New York, such orders being forwarded first to the Revenue Commissioner for approval in accordance with the regulations and by him to the New York office, which alone had authority to accept or confirm the orders or offers to purchase; and that, if accepted, the products were shipped in interstate commerce by the distillery or producing company f. o. b. its distillery or producing plant to a State warehouse for the account of the wholesale customer in Georgia, and no accounts, collections, or billings were made in Georgia. In addition the petition set out a portion of section 8 of the "Wholesale Licenses" chapter of the regulations, which provides: "All alcoholic beverages, whiskeys and liquors shipped by distillers to a wholesale licensee in this State will be deemed to be the property of the wholesale licensee at the time the same is shipped. . . ." By reason of the above facts the petitioner alleges that neither it nor its subsidiary corporations have been doing business in Georgia within the meaning of the Georgia income-tax [***3] statute and did not have or receive any income from property owned or business done in Georgia, and the taxes were erroneously and illegally assessed and collected in violation of the interstate-commerce clause and the 14th amendment of the Constitution of the United States, and deprived the petitioner and its subsidiaries of the equal protection of the law and their property without due process of law in violation of these particular Code sections of the Georgia Constitution; and by amendment adds that, if it be determined, as a matter of construction, that Code § 92-3102 as amended and Code § 92-3113 as amended were intended to subject them to Georgia income taxes for the taxable periods involved, then such statutory provisions are unconstitutional as being in violation of the above named clauses of the Georgia and Federal Constitutions, for the reasons set out.

The Commissioner filed general and special demurrers and a plea of estoppel in bar which alleges that the petitioner and defendant, by and through Fred L. Cox, Deputy Director of the Department of Revenue, entered into an agreement in which petitioner and its subsidiaries, for and in consideration of the waiver of penalties [***4] by the Commissioner due to their failure to file the proper returns and pay the taxes when due, are forever barred from reopening the question of income-tax liability for the said taxable years 1938 through 1947, inclusive. Demurrers were filed to this plea, and after a hearing the court overruled the demurrers to the petition and sustained the demurrers to the plea of estoppel in bar. The exception here is to the above judgments against the Revenue Commissioner, the plaintiff in error here.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant State Revenue Commissioner sought review of the judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which overruled his demurrer to the petition for refund of income tax file by plaintiff taxpayer. On appeal, the Commissioner argued that the taxpayer was conducting a whiskey and liquor wholesale business that generated income from business done in the state that was subject to the income tax law.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was a foreign corporation whose employees solicited Georgia customers' orders for whiskey in compliance with the Commissioner's regulations. The orders were shipped in interstate commerce by the out-of-state distilleries f.o.b. to a State warehouse for the account of the Georgia customer and no collections or billings were made in Georgia. The taxpayer paid the income tax demanded by the Commissioner, but filed an action for a refund. The trial court overruled the Commissioner's demurrer and he appealed. The court found that the Commissioner's regulations provided that whiskey sold became the property of the purchaser f.o.b. shipping point, therefore it was illogical for the Commissioner to contend that the taxpayer was selling liquor within the state. The Commissioner made a plea of estoppel in bar alleging that the taxpayer had made an agreement with a Department of Revenue deputy director not to reopen the issue of income tax liability. The court stated that the office of Revenue Commissioner was statutory, that its powers were conferred by statute, and concluded that the deputy director did not have the authority to enter into the agreement pled as a bar.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court judgment that overruled the Commissioner's demurrer to the petition for income tax refund filed by the taxpayer.

 

1351 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


State v. State Toll Bridge Auth.


No. 18582


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 690; 82 S.E.2d 626; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 416


May 12, 1954, Argued  
May 31, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Declaratory judgment. Before Judge Hendrix. Fulton Superior Court. March 11, 1954.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff state officials appealed a decision of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which held that the act creating the State Toll Bridge Authority was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The Toll Bridge Authority Act (Act), 1953 Ga. Laws p.302, created a body to construct, maintain, and operate bridges to be built with the proceeds of revenue bonds of the authority. The bonds were to be repaid by tolls collected by the authority. The state officials challenged the constitutionality of the Act. The trial court upheld the Act's constitutionality. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that (1) the Act did not circumvent the constitutional prohibition on the state borrowing money because the revenue bonds were not debts of the state, (2) the Act did not grant public powers and privileges to a private corporation because the authority was an instrumentality of the state and a public corporation, (3) provisions of the Act which permitted the state to grant property to the authority were not illegal donations because the Act contemplated when the indebtedness of the authority was retired the property, including the constructed bridges, would be returned to the state, and (4) the fact that the authority was permitted to charge tolls for the bridge did not prevent it from being a tax exempt entity.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court that the act creating the State Toll Bridge Authority was constitutional.

 

1352 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Cook v. Sikes


No. 18573


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 722; 82 S.E.2d 641; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 418


May 10, 1954, Argued  
May 31, 1954, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied June 15, 1954.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for declaratory judgment. Before Judge Price. Liberty Superior Court. February 12, 1954.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, the Attorney-General of Georgia and several county officers, appealed a judgment of the Liberty Superior Court (Georgia) that overruled their objection to petitioner sheriff's petition for declaratory judgment. The sheriff's had sought a declaration that the Revenue Tax Act to Legalize and Control Alcoholic Beverages and Liquors (Act), Ga. Code Ann. §§ 58-1043 to -1044 (Supp. 1938), was unconstitutional and void.


OVERVIEW: One section of the Act required grand juries in Georgia's counties to investigate violation of state laws that prohibited the sale of alcohol. A grand jury found that the sheriff knowingly did not enforce the Act. The court reversed the judgment. The governor should have been a party to the action because the issue centered on the removal proceeding before him. Because the petition only alleged that the Attorney-General was performing his official duties, there was no controversy between him and the sheriff. Similarly, there was no controversy between the county officers and the sheriff because although the petition alleged that the county officers conspired, conspiracy was not present when the facts alleged conspiracy to commit a lawful act. Consequently, the petition did not state a claim for a declaratory judgment and the court lacked jurisdiction to rule on whether § 9-B of the Act was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that overruled the objections that the Attorney-General and the county officers had to the sheriff's petition for declaratory judgment.

 

1353 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Ball v. Peavy


No. 18559


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 575; 82 S.E.2d 143; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 397


April 13, 1954, Argued  
May 11, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Before Judge Thomas. Ware Superior Court. January 29, 1954.

W. M. Peavy (now defendant in error) filed an equitable petition in Ware Superior Court, praying for a restraining order and injunction against the Chief of Police and other city officials of the City of Waycross (the plaintiffs in error), to prevent them from trying him for the sale of fireworks in violation of a municipal ordinance and from interfering with him in his business of selling fireworks, the allegations being, in substance: that he had a proper county license from Ware County to sell fireworks; that his business is outside the corporate limits of Waycross, but within one mile of the corporate limits; that cases have been made against him and he has been summoned to appear before the recorder's court for the alleged violation of an ordinance which prohibits the sale of fireworks in the City of Waycross and within the zone of its police jurisdiction, defined by its charter as extending one mile beyond its corporate limits, said ordinance being in violation of the Constitutions of Georgia and the United States; and that he has no adequate remedy at law, and equity jurisdiction is invoked to avoid [***2] a multiplicity of suits and to prevent prosecution of the cases made and the making of further cases. By amendment the petitioner alleges that the section of the charter permitting police jurisdiction within one mile outside the corporate limits violated the Constitution of Georgia, in that the caption of the legislative act granting the charter afforded no indication of any purpose on the part of the General Assembly to extend the power of the City of Waycross beyond its corporate limits.

The restraining order was granted and, after an interlocutory hearing, the court granted a temporary injunction. The case proceeded to trial without the intervention of a jury on a written stipulation of facts, and a permanent injunction was granted; the decree of the court holding that both section 4 of the act of the General Assembly (Ga. L. 1909, pp. 1456, 1461), setting up the charter of the City of Waycross empowering it to exercise the powers enumerated outside the corporate limits and the ordinance pursuant thereto, are unconstitutional and void. The exception here is to this judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs in error, officials of the City of Waycross, sought review of a judgment of the Ware Superior Court (Georgia), which permanently enjoined the prosecution of defendant in error for selling fireworks in violation of a municipal ordinance and held both that the ordinance and 1909 Ga. Laws 1456, § 4, which set up the City's charter and under which the ordinance was enacted, were unconstitutional and void.


OVERVIEW: Defendant in error had a license from Ware County to sell fireworks, and although his business was outside the City's corporate limits, it was within one mile thereof. As a result, defendant in error had been charged with violating a municipal ordinance of the City that prohibited the sale of fireworks in the City and within the zone of its police jurisdiction, which was defined by the City's charter as extending one mile beyond its corporate limits. The court held that: (1) § 4 provided that for the purpose of protecting the peace, good order, morals, and health of the City, its corporate limits and its jurisdiction would extend for one mile beyond its limits as then defined or thereafter extended; (2) the caption of § 4 stated that it was an act to provide and establish a new charter for the City and to extend and define its corporate limits; and (3) because the title of the act afforded no indication of any purpose on the part of the General Assembly to provide the City with extra powers over the neighboring territory within one mile of the city's limits, the trial court did not err in holding it subject to the constitutional attack.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

1354 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Heard v. Pittard


No. 18563


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 549; 81 S.E.2d 799; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 371


April 13, 1954, Argued  
May 10, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Before Judge Pratt. Gwinnett Superior Court. February 12, 1954.

Dennis Heard and Willie Garrett, individually and as Sheriff of the City Court of Buford, filed a petition for mandamus against C. K. Pittard, as the duly qualified and acting Sheriff of Gwinnett County and of the City Court of Gwinnett County, and Charles C. Pittard, as the duly qualified and acting Solicitor of the City Court of Gwinnett County. In substance the petition alleged: On May 15, 1953, and on June 5, 1953, warrants were issued against Dennis Heard, charging him with possessing non-tax-paid liquor. If any offense was committed by Dennis Heard, such offense was committed within the jurisdiction of the City Court of Buford. Section 22 of the act creating the City Court of Gwinnett County (Ga. L. 1937, pp. 1184, 1191) provides: "Be it further enacted, that it shall be the duty of the sheriff of said County of Gwinnett, to make appearance bonds in all criminal cases of which the City Court of Buford would have jurisdiction of, returnable to the City Court of Buford." The defendant C. K. Pittard, as sheriff, took bond in each of the two cases against Dennis Heard, made returnable to the City [***2] Court of Gwinnett County. The defendant Charles C. Pittard, as solicitor, has drawn accusations against Dennis Heard in that court, and he will call the cases at the next term. Dennis Heard will be forced to respond to the bonds and go to trial, or in his absence will be rearrested and confined to the common jail of the county, in which event Dennis Heard will suffer irreparable injury and damages, which cannot be adequately compensated in money. Willie Garrett is the duly elected, qualified, and acting Sheriff of the City Court of Buford. The cases against Dennis Heard are within the jurisdiction of that court, and Garrett, as sheriff, will sustain a monetary loss in the event Heard pays a fine in the City Court of Gwinnett County or in the Superior Court of Gwinnett County. Each and every citizen of the City of Buford is entitled to have the cases returned to the City Court of Buford, and every citizen within the jurisdiction of that court has an interest in the disposition of the cases. It is the official duty of the defendant C. K. Pittard to return the cases to the City Court of Buford, and this duty is mandatory in character. The defendant sheriff threatens to return the [***3] cases to the superior court. A demand has been made upon the sheriff to return the bonds to the City Court of Buford, and this demand has been refused.

The prayers were: that rule nisi issue requiring the defendants to show cause why a writ of mandamus and injunction should not issue; that pending the hearing on the application for mandamus the defendant, Charles C. Pittard, be temporarily restrained and enjoined from calling the cases against Dennis Heard for trial in the City Court of Gwinnett County, or from forfeiting the bonds; that the defendant sheriff be restrained and enjoined from arresting Dennis Heard or placing him in jail pending the disposition of the application; for process; and other relief.

The defendants filed a demurrer to the application for mandamus, on the grounds that: (1) Only section 22 of the act creating the City Court of Gwinnett County is pleaded, and a construction of the entire act is necessary; (2) the allegations show no cause of action against the defendants; (3) there is no matter or thing of equity or equity jurisdiction set out, and the plaintiffs are not entitled to the relief prayed. The demurrer was sustained, and the petition dismissed.  [***4] The exception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a citizen and a law-enforcement officer, sought review of a judgment from the Gwinnett Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained the demurrer of defendants, a county sheriff and a county solicitor, to a petition for a writ of mandamus whereby the citizen and the officer sought to restrain the sheriff and the solicitor from calling cases against the citizen and to restrain the sheriff from arresting the citizen.


OVERVIEW: The citizen and the officer filed a petition for a writ of mandamus against the sheriff and the solicitor. The citizen had been charged with possessing non-tax-paid liquor, and the citizen and the officer contended that if the citizen had committed any offense it was in Buford County and not in Gwinnett County, where the sheriff and the solicitor had jurisdiction. The citizen and the officer sought to restrain the sheriff and the solicitor from calling the cases against the citizen and to restrain the sheriff from arresting the citizen. The trial court sustained a demurrer to the petition and dismissed it. The court held that: (1) the unambiguous language of the act creating the City Court of Gwinnett County, 1906 Ga. Laws 176, required the sheriff of Gwinnett County to return bonds in all criminal cases arising within the jurisdiction of the City Court of Buford to that court and was not in conflict with any other provision of the act; and (2) the petition was sufficient to show a legal duty resting upon the sheriff to perform the acts sought by the petition, and it was error to sustain the demurrer.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1355 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Buchanan v. Heath


No. 18434


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 410; 80 S.E.2d 393; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 331


January 11, 1954, Argued  
February 9, 1954, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied February 24, 1954.


PRIOR HISTORY: Complaint. Before Judge Fort. Talbot Superior Court. September 14, 1953.

James Buchanan filed a petition in Talbot Superior Court against Charles Heath, a section foreman of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, for the purpose of recovering double the value of three cows alleged to have been killed on the railroad, in that Heath failed to post a list of the different marks and brands of stock killed during the preceding weeks in which the cows were alleged to have been killed, in violation of Code §§ 94-705, 94-707. The defendant filed an answer denying, in the main, the allegations of the petition, and by way of further answer alleged the unconstitutionality of the above Code sections. General and special demurrers were filed to the answer and, after a hearing, were overruled, and the plaintiff excepted pendente lite to this ruling. When the case was called for trial, the plaintiff offered oral testimony and the defendant admitted in open court certain facts in an admission of facts, filed by the plaintiff. After the plaintiff rested his case, the court granted a nonsuit on motion of the defendant. The assignments of error [***2] here are on this judgment and on the previous pendente lite exception.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the owner of cows killed on a railroad, assigned error on a judgment of the Superior Court of Talbot County (Georgia), which granted a nonsuit on the motion of defendant, a railroad section foreman, in the owner's action to recover double the value of the cows under O.C.G.A. §§ 94-705, 94-707. The owner also assigned error on its previous pendent lite exceptions to the trial court's ruling that these statutes were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The owner alleged that the foreman failed to post a list of the marks and brands of stock killed during the preceding weeks as required by O.C.G.A. §§ 94-705, 94-707. The foreman filed an answer denying these allegations and also alleging that the statutes were unconstitutional. The owner filed special and general demurrers to the answer, which the trial court overruled. The parties stipulated to certain facts. On appeal, the court held that the stipulation of facts, together with the oral testimony, proved the allegations in the owner's petition and, therefore, that the trial court erred in granting the nonsuit. The court then considered the constitutional issues and rejected the owner's claim that these issue had not been properly raised. The court held that the statutes violated the Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment and the Constitution of Georgia because they subjected the section foreman to automatic liability for failing to report the killing of stock of which he had no knowledge and regardless of any mitigating circumstances. The court concluded that the granting of the nonsuit was harmless error.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the superior court.

 

1356 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Herrod v. O'Beirne


Nos. 18449, 18450


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 476; 80 S.E.2d 684; 1954 Ga. LEXIS 335


January 12, 1954, Argued  
February 8, 1954, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 10, 1954.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Before Judge Manning. Cobb Superior Court. October 1, 1953.

Dr. N. R. Herrod and other citizens similarly situated brought this petition against E. N. O'Beirne and Byron E. Reeves seeking to enjoin the defendants from constructing a cemetery on described property in Cobb County, Georgia, the petitioners being residents and property holders in the vicinity where the cemetery was about to be constructed. Other persons intervened and were made parties, who, in the view we here take, need not be set out.

It was contended that an act of the legislature of 1953 (Ga. L. 1953, Jan.-Feb. Sess., p. 2788), seeking to eliminate from the jurisdiction of the Cobb County Planning Board the property in question and providing that this property be zoned for cemetery purposes, was unconstitutional on a number of grounds. Certain other acts of the legislature of 1910, 1911, and 1935, as will be set out in the opinion in this case, were also attacked on constitutional grounds.

The trial judge held that the act of 1953, supra, was unconstitutional. He further held that, under the act of the legislature of 1943 (Ga. L. 1943, p. 902, sec. 9),  [***2] the sole Commissioner of Cobb County had the right to issue a permit for the construction of a cemetery, and declined to invalidate a permit so issued. The direct bill of exceptions complains of the ruling to the effect that the acts of 1910, 1911, and 1935 were constitutional, and the ruling refusing to invalidate the permit issued under the terms of these acts, and the judgment denying an injunction. The defendants in the court below by cross-bill complain about so much of the judgment of the trial court as held the act of 1953 to be unconstitutional, and raised certain other objections which, under the view we take of this case, it is not necessary to state here.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed on the main bill of exceptions.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant residents filed a bill of exceptions challenging rulings by the Superior Court of Cobb County (Georgia) that 1910 Ga. Laws 131, § 1, 1911 Ga. Laws 200, and 1935 Ga. Laws 384 (challenged acts) were constitutional. They also challenged refusals to invalidate a permit obtained by appellee permittees and to grant injunctive relief. The permittees filed a cross-bill challenging a holding that 1953 Ga. Laws 2788 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The residents sought to enjoin the permittees from building a cemetery on land that was near their properties and to invalidate a permit to build the cemetery that was issued by the sole Commissioner of Cobb County. The challenged acts empowered county commissioners to grant or refuse permits to establish specified institutions, including cemeteries, outside the limits of incorporated towns. Those acts were attacked as unconstitutional special laws, as the grant applied only to counties that had a specified population level or that were adjacent to counties with the requisite population level. The court held that 1953 Ga. Laws 2788 was invalid, as the legislature had no right to zone property and possessed only the authority to delegate the right to zone to counties and municipalities. The court held that the language in the challenged acts regarding population did not make those acts special laws and rejected claims that the challenged acts violated Ga. Const. art. I, § IV, para. I and that they were repealed by 1943 Ga. Laws 905, § 9. Finally, the court found it unnecessary to pass on the attacks made in the permittees' cross-bill on the zoning ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision on the main bill of exceptions and on the cross-bill of exceptions insofar as it passed upon the cross-bill.

 

1357 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Bailey v. State


No. 18254


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 52; 77 S.E.2d 511; 1953 Ga. LEXIS 465


June 10, 1953, Argued  
September 16, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Murder. Before Judge Wood. Fulton Superior Court. April 3, 1953.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia) convicted defendant of murder without a recommendation of mercy. The trial court overruled defendant's motion for a new trial.


OVERVIEW: Under his general plea of not guilty, defendant introduced evidence that he was insane at the time of the murder. Defendant alleged that the trial court erred in refusing to instruct the jury on the provisions of 1953 Ga. Laws 205, and 206. Because the statute was enacted after the commission of the crime, the State alleged that a jury instruction on the statute would violate express constitutional provisions prohibiting retroactive and ex post facto laws. The State also alleged that, since the jury found defendant sane and guilty of murder without a recommendation of mercy, any failure to charge the jury relative to statute was harmless error. The court held that the trial court committed reversible error in failing to charge the jury on the statutory provisions relative to insanity. The statutory requirements for a jury instruction on the insanity defense were for defendant's protection and did not constitute prohibited ex post facto conduct. Pursuant to his rights to due process, defendant was entitled to a jury instruction on the statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1358 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Phillips v. Atlanta


No. 18293


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 72; 77 S.E.2d 723; 1953 Ga. LEXIS 475


July 14, 1953, Argued  
September 15, 1953, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied September 28, 1953.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for injunction. Before Judge Wood. Fulton Superior Court. May 23, 1953.

Ezra E. Phillips and Inslee M. Johnson, as residents and taxpayers of the City of Atlanta, brought an equitable petition against the City of Atlanta and certain of its officials, alleging: that they are illegally performing certain official acts and duties which are ultra vires in an area of Fulton County outside the jurisdiction of the City of Atlanta, thereby causing an unauthorized burden on the taxpayers of that city; that the area involved was prior to December, 1952, unincorporated, but that under the Municipal Home Rule Law of Georgia a special election was held in this area, which resulted in a vote in favor of incorporating the territory into the City of East Point, which has adopted and become subject to the home rule law; that said law is of a general nature operating throughout the State; that, during the process of annexation of the area to East Point, the General Assembly of Georgia passed a special act amending the charter of the City of Atlanta placing the described area inside the corporate limits of Atlanta, and on February 16, 1953, said [***2] special act was approved by the Governor; that the special act violates art. I, sec. IV, par. I, of the Constitution, in that no special law shall be enacted in any case where provision has been made by an existing general law; and that Atlanta has no jurisdiction over the territory. The prayers were for rule nisi and injunctive relief. A demurrer was filed on several grounds, one of which was to the petition as a whole on the ground that all of the alleged rights of the petitioners were predicated in their entirety upon the Municipal Home Rule Law (Ga. L. 1951, p. 116, as amended by Ga. L. 1952, p. 46), and specifically section 3 (j) of said act as amended; and both said act and said section of said act are unconstitutional and void in that they are in violation of art. XV, sec. I, par. I of the Constitution of Georgia (Code, Ann., § 2-8301), in that said act does not provide for uniform systems of county or municipal government, and provide for optional plans for both. Upon the interlocutory hearing in pursuance of the rule nisi issued, the petitioners' prayers for injunction were denied and the petition was dismissed on demurrer, the court ruling that the Municipal Home Rule [***3] Act was unconstitutional in that it does not follow the constitutional directive of art. XV, sec. I, par. I of the Constitution. The exception here is to this judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayers appealed the judgment of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which denied their prayers for injunction and dismissed their petition. The taxpayers filed the equitable petition against respondents, the City of Atlanta and certain City officials, alleging that the City's annexation of an area violated the Municipal Home Rule Law of Georgia, 1951 Ga. Laws 116 as amended by 1952 Ga. Laws 46.


OVERVIEW: The City of East Point held a special election under the Municipal Home Rule Law and voted to incorporate the area into the City of East Point. Meanwhile, the General Assembly of Georgia passed a special act that incorporated the area into the City of Atlanta. The taxpayers brought the action to stop the City of Atlanta's incorporation of the area. The trial court found in favor of the City. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court found that the General Assembly could not delegate its legislative powers under Ga. Code Ann. § 2-1301. The court found that under Ga. Const. art. XV, § I(I), the General Assembly could have delegated its legislative powers only to the extent of allowing uniform systems of county and municipal governments to be established. The court found that the trial court's ruling that the Municipal Home Rule Act was unconstitutional was proper, and therefore, the City of East Point had no authority to annex the area. The court concluded that the taxpayers' petition was properly dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court, which dismissed the taxpayers' petition.

 

1359 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


McLucas v. State Bridge Bldg. Authority


No. 18284


Supreme Court of Georgia


210 Ga. 1; 77 S.E.2d 531; 1953 Ga. LEXIS 473


July 14, 1953, Argued  
September 14, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Bond validation; constitutional question. Before Judge Andrews. Fulton Superior Court. June 3, 1953.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Intervenor taxpayer objected to the issuance of revenue bonds by defendant State Bridge Building Authority (Authority) to construct and finance a bridge building project. The taxpayer objected to the validation of the revenue bonds and to a judgment declaring a lease contract between the Authority and the State Highway Department was valid and binding. The taxpayer appealed the adverse judgment.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer contended that the amended State Highway Board Act of 1950 (Act), which permitted the creation of the Authority, was unconstitutional because the revenue bonds that the Authority was authorized and empowered to provide for and issue were obligations or debts of the state. In affirming the judgment of the trial court, the court held that the Act, as amended, was constitutional. The court found that while the Authority was an instrumentality of the state, it was nevertheless not the state, nor a part of the state, nor an agency of the state. It was a mere creature of the state, having a distinct corporate entity. Its revenue bonds, as § 23 of the Act expressly and emphatically declared, were not obligations or debts of the state, nor a pledge of the credit of the state, but they were payable solely and exclusively from revenue derived from the use of its facilities. The court also found that the state was not directly, indirectly, or contingently obligated to levy or pledge any form of taxation toward the bonds or to make any appropriation for their payment. The bonds were always a corporate debt of the Authority and in no sense a debt of the state.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court, which declared that the Act was constitutional, was affirmed in the taxpayer's challenge to the Act's creation of a bridge building authority.

 

1360 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Wade v. Hopper


No. 18225


Supreme Court of Georgia


209 Ga. 802; 76 S.E.2d 403; 1953 Ga. LEXIS 414


May 12, 1953, Argued  
June 8, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Damages. Before Judge Anderson. Houston Superior Court. February 20, 1953.



DISPOSITION: Transferred to the Court of Appeals.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff non-resident motorist brought a damages action against defendant non-resident motorist under the Non-resident Motorist Act, 1937 Ga. Laws 732, as amended by 1947 Ga. Laws 305, and codified as O.C.G.A. § 68-803. A jury in the Superior Court of Houston County (Georgia) returned a verdict for plaintiff. Defendant excepted to the court of appeals, which transferred the case to the court because the constitutionality of the Act was at issue.


OVERVIEW: Defendant assigned error on the trial court's pendente lite rulings and on the judgment denying a motion for new trial. He contended that the trial court in Houston County had no jurisdiction because 1947 Ga. Laws 305, amending 1937 Ga. Laws 732, was unconstitutional. The court concluded that it was without jurisdiction to determine the appeal because the constitutionality of the 1947 amendment was not at issue. The 1937 act gave persons injured in highway accidents the right to bring actions against non-resident motorists who were involved in accidents on Georgia's highways. The amendment did not extend the right to non-residents or anyone else. Rather, it assumed that non-residents had that right under the 1937 act and merely restricted venue in the case of non-resident plaintiffs to the county in which the accident occurred. Thus, plaintiff's right to bring the action in Georgia was under the 1937 act, which permitted him to bring the action in any county in Georgia, and plaintiff properly brought his action in Houston County even though it was also the county in which the accident occurred.


OUTCOME: The court transferred the case to the court of appeals.

 

1361 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Tift v. Bush


Nos. 18134, 18144, 18145


Supreme Court of Georgia


209 Ga. 769; 75 S.E.2d 805; 1953 Ga. LEXIS 387


February 9, 1953, Argued  
April 14, 1953, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied May 13, 1953.


PRIOR HISTORY: Declaratory judgment. Before Judge Crow. Dougherty Superior Court. December 24, 1952.

M. W. Tift, George B. Mock, and Mallory Lippitt, Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Dougherty County, brought an action for declaratory judgment. J. W. Bush, Clerk of the Superior Court, and D. C. Campbell Sr., Sheriff, were named as defendants. The petitioners assert that the terms of an act of 1949 (Ga. L. 1949, pp. 1460-1465) are applicable to Dougherty County, and that the act is constitutional. The petitioners have called on the defendants to comply with the terms of the act. The defendants state that they have been advised by counsel that the act is unconstitutional and has no application to Dougherty County, and they do not intend to comply with the provisions of the act. The prayers were that the court enter a judgment declaring the act to be constitutional and to apply to Dougherty County, and for other relief.

The act of 1949 (Ga. L. 1949, pp. 1460-1465) provides that it shall apply "to all counties in the State of Georgia having, according to the official United States census of 1940, a population of not less than forty thousand inhabitants,  [***2] and not more than fifty thousand inhabitants, and to all counties in this State which may have by any future census of the United States a population of forty thousand inhabitants and not more than fifty thousand inhabitants." It is provided that in such counties the fee system for compensating the clerk of the superior court, sheriff, ordinary, tax collector, tax receiver, and tax commissioner shall be abolished (except fees paid by the State to the tax officials), and that the salaries of such officers shall be fixed by the commissioners of roads and revenues, or other county authorities, for the terms of such officers, at least ninety days before January 1, 1953. The minimum and maximum salaries for all the officers are prescribed. At least ninety days before January 1, 1953, the officers named shall furnish to the county commissioners a statement showing the assistants or deputies required by them, and the salaries recommended. After January 1, 1953, all fees accruing to the various officials shall be collected for the use of the county, and the method of distribution of the costs and fees is provided. The act is to take effect on January 1, 1953, except as concerning the determination [***3] of salaries and expenses, which part shall take effect on October 1, 1952.

The act shows an affidavit of the publisher of a newspaper in Troup County, accompanying the copy of a notice that legislation would be introduced applicable to Troup County, changing named officers from the fee to the salary system, and regulating the disposition of fees and costs. Also attached was a grand jury presentment showing that the grand jury selected for the November term of the Superior Court of Troup County recommended to the county representative that a bill be presented at the 1949 session of the State legislature abolishing the fee system in paying county officials, and substituting a salary system.

The defendants filed separate answers, in which they contended that the act of 1949 is unconstitutional on numerous grounds, and that it applies only to Troup County.

The trial judge entered an order declaring that the act applies only to Troup County, and that, if Dougherty County should come within the provisions of the act, it is unconstitutional because not advertised in Dougherty County.

The petitioners filed a direct bill of exceptions to this judgment. The defendants, in separate cross-bills,  [***4] excepted to that part of the judgment which held that the act was constitutional against all grounds urged except as set out in the judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed on the main bill of exceptions; cross-bill of exceptions dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff road commissioners sought declaratory judgment that defendants, city clerk and sheriff, comply with the provisions of 1949 Ga. Laws pp. 1460-1465, which required abolition of fees paid to certain officials in counties of a specified size. The Superior Court of Troup County (Georgia) found that the act applied only to its county and the commissioners appealed.


OVERVIEW: 1949 Ga. Laws pp. 1460-1465 provided that counties with a specified population, according to the Census, should abolish a fee system for paying specified county executives. The commissioners sought declaratory judgment finding that that their county was affected by the law. The trial court found that provision inapplicable in the commissioner's county and they appealed. The court found that, from reading the act, it was intended to apply only to the county in which it was advertised as a special law, and the only county to which it applied at the time of its passage. Because it was a special law, not a general law, any change in population in the commissioners' county did not change the scope of the law. The court found that even where other counties might have fallen within the population brackets set forth in the law under some future census, the restrictions and limitations of the act would made it inapplicable to any county that met those limits in the Census after that specified in the act.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court judgment.

 

1362 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Jenkins v. Jones


No. 18150


Supreme Court of Georgia


209 Ga. 758; 75 S.E.2d 815; 1953 Ga. LEXIS 392


March 10, 1953, Argued  
April 13, 1953, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied May 13, 1953.


PRIOR HISTORY: Habeas corpus. Before Judge Wood. Fulton Superior Court. January 24, 1953.

Arnold E. Jones, on his petition for the writ of habeas corpus, was, upon a hearing thereof, discharged from the custody of Herbert Jenkins, Chief of Police of Atlanta. To this order the respondent filed a bill of exceptions.

The undisputed facts before the trial judge were: The petitioner was being held by the respondent on a charge of violating an ordinance of the City of Atlanta, adopted in 1953, which made it a municipal offense to "operate a motor vehicle of any kind upon any public street or alley in the City of Atlanta while under the influence of intoxicating liquors or drugs," which ordinance provided that one guilty of its violation was subject to a fine of not exceeding $ 500, and a sentence to work on the public works or streets not to exceed 60 days, any or all of these penalties in the discretion of the trial judge. The petitioner contended that his restraint was illegal, because the ordinance he was charged with violating was unconstitutional, null, and void, in that, (a) it was a special law for which provision had been made by an existing general [***2] law (Code, Ann. Supp., § 68-307), wherein the operation of a motor vehicle on any street or highway of this State while under the influence of intoxicating liquors or drugs is declared to be a misdemeanor, and therefore said ordinance violated art. 1, sec. 4, par. 1 of the Constitution of Georgia (Code, Ann., § 2-401); and (b) the ordinance violated the due-process clause of the State Constitution (Code, Ann., § 2-103).



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent, chief of police of the City of Atlanta, Georgia (city) filed a bill of exceptions to a decision of the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia) that discharged petitioner from custody upon petitioner's writ of habeas corpus.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner filed for a writ of habeas corpus, challenging the validity of a city ordinance that punished petitioner for driving under the influence. Petitioner contended that the city ordinance was unconstitutional because the state had provided for the punishment of the same offense under an existing general law set forth in Ga. Code Ann. § 68.307. The trial court had granted the petition and discharged petitioner from custody, and the city filed a bill of exceptions. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court. The court held that the city ordinance violated Ga. Const. art. 1, § 4(1), Ga. Code Ann. § 2-401, and the ordinance was void. The court held that the city did not have authority to enact an ordinance that penalized the exact same offense that was penalized by a state statute. The court held that the Georgia General Assembly did not intend to confer upon the city or other municipalities in the state the authority to enact ordinances making it a penal offense to operate a motor vehicle on the streets of the municipalities while under the influence when there was a general law in force in the state making such operation a penal offense.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that granted petitioner's request for the writ of habeas corpus because the ordinance under which petitioner was being held was void.

 

1363 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Gay v. Lyons


No. 18080


Supreme Court of Georgia


209 Ga. 599; 74 S.E.2d 839; 1953 Ga. LEXIS 331


January 13, 1953, Argued  
February 24, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Mandamus. Before Judge Humphrey. Toombs Superior Court. October 20, 1952.

On September 30, 1952, George R. Gay filed a petition against the City of Lyons, its mayor, clerk, and members of council, seeking a mandamus absolute. The amended petition alleged substantially the following: On July 1, 1952, the plaintiff, the owner of an option to purchase a described lot in said city, filed his application with the clerk of the mayor and council to obtain a building permit for the erection of a filling station on his property. At that time there was in existence an ordinance making it unlawful to erect any building within the city limits without first submitting the plan of such structure to the mayor and council and receiving a permit in writing authorizing the erection of the same. On June 14, 1952, the mayor and council passed a resolution as contemplated by Georgia Laws 1946, p. 191, which authorized municipalities to enact zoning and planning ordinances and regulations, and appointed three members to constitute a planning board, and three members to constitute a board of adjustment. On July 16, 1952, the planning board presented tentative zoning recommendations to the city,  [***2] under which tentative plan the property of the plaintiff was zoned for residential purposes. The planning board held a public hearing on the tentative zoning plan, at which time the plaintiff appeared and filed written objections, in which he insisted that such plan violated stated provisions of the State and Federal Constitutions. These objections were overruled, and the tentative plan was recommended for approval by the mayor and council. Thereafter, the plaintiff filed similar objections to the proposed zoning ordinance with the mayor and council, which overruled his objections and approved the plans of the planning board without making any change in the same. Thereafter, the mayor and council refused the plaintiff's application for a building permit.

It was alleged that the plaintiff had complied with all laws and regulations of an ordinance of 1926, and with all laws and regulations of the city with reference to obtaining a building permit. It was charged that the refusal of the permit was unreasonable, arbitrary, and discriminatory, and an unlawful interference with the plaintiff's property rights; that the zoning ordinance did not provide a comprehensive zoning plan as [***3] contemplated by the act of 1946, and violated stated provisions of the State and Federal Constitutions; and that, unless the city be required to issue the permit, the plaintiff will suffer financial loss for which he cannot be compensated. The plaintiff's prayer was for the issuance of a mandamus absolute.

The defendants interposed to the petition as amended a general demurrer, which was overruled, but so far as appears from the record the defendants did not except to said order. The municipal authorities filed an answer, admitting certain allegations of the petition and denying others. The answer asserted that the city could not issue a permit to the plaintiff because the city had adopted, on August 22, 1952, a zoning ordinance, and the location of the plaintiff's proposed filling station was zoned for residential purposes, and the city was without authority to issue a permit for the erection of a filling station. They also filed what they denominated a "plea in bar," which alleged that the plaintiff had filed with the municipal planning board his written objections to the tentative plan; that these objections were rejected, and subsequently the plaintiff filed written objections [***4] to said plan with the city council, and these objections were overruled. Attached to this plea was a copy of the zoning ordinance which had been adopted by the city, which had placed the plaintiff's property in a district zoned for residential purposes only; that, under the act of 1946, appeals from the decision of the planning board shall be taken to the board of adjustment, and any party dissatisfied with the decision of the board of adjustment may appeal to the superior court. No appeal to the board of adjustment had been filed by the plaintiff; and, as he had not exhausted all of his administrative remedies, and it would be illegal for the city to issue a permit for the erection of a filling station on property zoned for residential use only, the plaintiff is not entitled to the writ of mandamus, and the petition should be dismissed. Subsequently, the defendants amended this plea in bar, and attached to the amendment the proceedings of the city council, the resolution showing the appointment of members of the planning board and of the board of adjustment, and the objections filed by the plaintiff to the proposed zoning ordinance, together with the zoning ordinance. To the plea [***5] in bar as amended, the plaintiff filed general and special demurrers. One of the grounds of demurrer was that the plea "fails to set out or show that the plaintiff has any other legal remedy, except the remedy sought in plaintiff's petition, mandamus." Other grounds of demurrer were that the ordinance was invalid and void as violating certain provisions of the Federal and State Constitutions. These demurrers to the plea in bar as amended were overruled, and the plaintiff filed exceptions pendente lite to this order, as well as to the order overruling his demurrers to the answer.

On October 20, 1952, the trial court, without hearing any evidence, but on the pleadings, entered an order sustaining the plea in bar and dismissing the plaintiff's suit. The case is in this court on a bill of exceptions, in which the plaintiff assigns error on the last order as well as on the orders complained of in the exceptions pendente lite.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owner sought review of a decision from the Toombs Superior Court (Georgia), which dismissed the property owner's action against defendant city officials for a writ of mandamus to compel the city officials to issue a building permit to the property owner.


OVERVIEW: The property owner brought an action against the city officials for a writ of mandamus to compel the city officials to issue a building permit to the property owner. The trial court dismissed the property owner's action. On appeal, the property owner contended that a board of adjustment was an administrative body that had no right or power to pass upon the property owner's contention that a zoning ordinance upon which the city officials based their refusal to issue the permit was unconstitutional. The court reversed the judgment of the trial court. The court held that: (1) the board of adjustment was an administrative agency and would have no authority or power to pass on the validity or invalidity of the zoning ordinance in question; and (2) because the sole defense of the city of the to issue the permit was that the zoning ordinance prohibited its issuance, if the ordinance, as contended by the property owner, was void, the property owner, in a mandamus proceeding that attacked the validity of the ordinance, could assert his right to the issuance of the permit by reason of the claimed invalidity of the zoning ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court, which dismissed the property owner's action against the city officials for a writ of mandamus to compel the city officials to issue a building permit to the property owner.

 

1364 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Housing Authority of Atlanta v. Johnson


No. 18068


Supreme Court of Georgia


209 Ga. 560; 74 S.E.2d 891; 1953 Ga. LEXIS 352


January 15, 1953, Argued  
February 24, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for injunction. Before Judge Pharr. Fulton Superior Court. October 13, 1952.

Sam S. Johnson filed his petition seeking to enjoin the Housing Authority of the City of Atlanta and the City of Atlanta from carrying out a proposed redevelopment project in the City of Atlanta. Knight Investment Company and Knight Ice Company intervened. It was alleged that the redevelopment project was being undertaken by authority of and in conformity with the provisions of the Redevelopment Law of 1946 (Ga. L. 1946, p. 157).
