Supreme Court of Georgia


207 Ga. 135; 60 S.E.2d 763; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 442



July 11, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Murder. Before Judge G. C. Anderson. Richmond Superior Court. April 3, 1950.

Charles Cade was indicted in Richmond Superior Court for the murder of one J. K. Joe, a Chinese merchant. The record discloses that this defendant, along with Curtis Wynn, Lincoln Mays, James Smith, and Johnny Hardge, formed and carried out a conspiracy to rob the deceased; that the deceased was a Chinaman about fifty years of age, and under the testimony of the coroner's physician, when his body was found, had been cut across the eyes, face, forehead, and nose, and his nose was broken; that there were numerous lacerations, and the right common carotid artery was severed by a stab wound in the neck, which caused immediate death. This defendant, in a written, sworn statement, which was admitted in evidence without objection, stated that he cut the deceased with a butcher knife to make him tell where the money was and to make him open his safe; that he called for the butcher knife to finish the deceased up after he had been robbed and tortured, but, in his statement, contended that the stab in the neck was made by Lincoln Mays just before they left the scene of the homicide; that this defendant, Curtis [***2] Wynn, and Lincoln Mays, left the scene of the homicide and went to a described house, where they divided the money. There was evidence by one of the State's witnesses that the defendant had stated to him that he killed the Chinaman; that he cut his damn throat, and in his statement to the jury the defendant stated that he handed the butcher knife to Lincoln Mays when he said "he is not dead," and told Lincoln Mays to finish killing him, and that Lincoln Mays took the knife and cut him. These statements of the defendant were corroborated in many particulars by other evidence.

When the jury had been purged as to relationship by the court, and the solicitor-general had put the usual voir dire questions to the first juror, and then informed the defendant that the juror was on him, counsel for the defendant -- basing his request upon the act approved February 25, 1949 (Ga. L. 1949, p. 1082) -- moved the court that he be allowed to ask each individual juror the following list of questions: "(1) What is your occupation? (2) What is your religious denomination, are you [sic]? (3) Do you attend church regularly? (4) Do you belong to any social or fraternal organizations? (5) Do you [***3] belong to any organizations that Messrs. Hains, Curry, and Kennedy are members of? (6) Were you still impartial toward the defendant, Charles Cade, after reading the accounts of the crime in the local papers? (7) What is your age? (8) Do you still feel unbiased after reading these articles in the Augusta Herald? (9) Do you do any business or have business with the local Chinese? (10) Have you any business or social connections with Mr. Curry or Kennedy? (11) Have you had any business or social connection in the past with Mr. Curry or Kennedy?"

The trial court made the following ruling: "I overrule your motion for that because that applies to civil cases only and doesn't apply to criminal cases; if it does, the act is unconstitutional because the caption of the act says nothing in regard to criminal cases, nor does that act seek to add to the general questions of the voir dire." After this ruling the defendant struck the first juror, and to the ruling and judgment of the court the defendant excepted pendente lite and in the only ground of the amendment to the motion for a new trial.

The jury returned a verdict of guilty without recommendation. The defendant filed his motion [***4] for new trial on the usual general grounds, and to the judgment of the trial court overruling his motion for a new trial as amended he excepts, and also assigns error upon his exceptions pendente lite above referred to.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment of the Superior Court of Richmond County (Georgia), which after a jury trial convicted him of murder and overruled his motion for a new trial. He claimed that it was error to refuse his motion to ask each individual juror several questions during voir dire on the ground that such questions were permissible pursuant to an amendment to O.C.G.A. § 59-705 made by 1949 Ga. Laws 1082.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and four other men conspired to rob a man. Defendant cut him with a butcher knife in an effort to make him tell them where he kept his money but denied that he inflicted a fatal stab to the man's neck. During the voir dire, defense counsel made a motion to be allowed to ask each juror 11 questions on topics from their religion to whether they knew any defendants, which was denied by the trial court on the ground that 1949 Ga. Laws 1082 (the Act) concerning challenges for cause, was unconstitutional as applied to criminal cases because its title made no reference to criminal cases. On review, the court found that statutes were to be construed so as to be consistent with the Georgia Constitution, that no law should contain matter different than that expressed in its title, that the Act repealed O.C.G.A. § 59-705 that referred solely to civil causes, and that O.C.G.A. § 59-806 already provided for broad voir dire in criminal actions. The court found that implementation of the Act would slow down trials and that so much of the Act as purported to apply to criminal case was violative of O.C.G.A. § 2-1908; Ga. Const. of 1945, art. 3, § 7, para. 8.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1384 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Reid v. Perkerson


No. 17091


Supreme Court of Georgia


207 Ga. 27; 60 S.E.2d 151; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 391



June 12, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus. Before Judge Edwards. Valdosta City Court. March 13, 1950.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner challenged the order of the Valdosta City Court (Georgia) that denied her petition for habeas corpus relief against respondent police chief arising out of her arrest for violating Valdosta's ordinance against possession of gambling paraphernalia.


OVERVIEW: The city enacted an ordinance that prohibited the possession of all gambling paraphernalia, including lottery tickets. Petitioner was arrested without a warrant for violation of the ordinance. She filed an habeas corpus petition against the chief of police, who demurred to the petition. The demurrer was sustained by the trial court. On review, petitioner alleged that she was wrongfully arrested without a warrant. Thus, the trial court had not jurisdiction, that excessive bail was required, and that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The court found that the court had jurisdiction despite the legality of the arrest. The court also found that it could not be said that bail was excessive in this case as a matter of law. The court further found that the ordinance did not violate the rule that an ordinance could not legislate on issues already covered by state statutes because the ordinance went further than Ga. Code Ann. § 26-6501, 6502, by criminalizing the mere possession of lottery tickets. Finally, the court found that the ordinance passed the "rational connection" test to survive a due process analysis under the Fourteenth Amendment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's sustaining the police chief's demurrer to petitioner's habeas corpus petition.

 

1385 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Bender v. Anglin


No. 17043


Supreme Court of Georgia


207 Ga. 108; 60 S.E.2d 756; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 440



June 12, 1950, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied July 13, 1950.


PRIOR HISTORY: Mandamus. Before Judge Shaw. Fulton Superior Court. January 9, 1950.

A. J. Bender, a retired member of the Fire Department of the City of Atlanta, petitioned the Fulton Superior Court for the issuance of a writ of mandamus absolute requiring the Board of Trustees of the Firemen's Pension Fund of the City of Atlanta to pay him $ 25 per month from August, 1942, to date, in addition to the $ 75 which he has been paid per month since his retirement in 1942. His contentions as made by his petition, briefly stated, are as follows: The pension fund was established by the City of Atlanta under the provisions of the act of 1924 (Ga. L. 1924, p. 167); and under this act as amended by the act of 1931 (Ga. L. 1931, p. 223), he, as a member of the fire department, was, after 25 years' service, entitled to retire as a matter of right and receive a monthly pension of $ 100 per month for the remainder of his life. He became a member of the fire department in 1915, and under the provisions of these acts he was assessed first 1 per centum of his monthly salary and later 2 per centum, which was paid into the pension fund up to the time of his retirement.  [***2] In 1935 the pension acts were amended (Ga. L. 1935, p. 450), and the amount of pension thereafter to be paid was reduced to $ 75 per month. In August, 1942, the petitioner made application for retirement and was placed on the pension roll, and since that time he has been paid the sum of $ 75 per month. In March, 1949, he made application to the defendants for an adjustment in his pension, and demanded that his pension be increased to $ 100 per month, to be retroactively applied to August, 1942. His application being denied, he then instituted the present proceeding, contending that the act of 1935 as applied to him was unconstitutional and void, as being (a) violative of art. I, sec. X, par. I, of the Constitution of the United States, in that said amendment impaired the obligation of the contract between him and the City of Atlanta whereby the defendants were obligated to pay him $ 100 per month, and that said act was an ex post facto law which attempted retroactively to change, modify, and annul the contract between him and the city; and (b) violative of art. XII, sec. I, par. V, of the Constitution of Georgia of 1877 because said act deprived him of a right granted to him under [***3] the act of 1924, as amended by the act of 1931, by reducing his pension without his knowledge or consent.

The general demurrers of the defendants to the petition being sustained, the plaintiff, by writ of error, seeks a reversal of the order dismissing his petition.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff pensioner sought review, by writ of error, of an order from the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which sustained the demurrers filed by defendant Board of Trustees of the Firemen's Pension Fund of the City of Atlanta (Board) and dismissed the pensioner's petition for an adjustment in his pension.


OVERVIEW: The pensioner was a fireman for the City of Atlanta, Georgia (City) prior to his retirement. When he was hired and began paying into the pension fund, the monthly pension amount was $ 100, pursuant to 1924 Ga. Laws 167 (1924 Act). During the course of his employment, the 1924 Law was amended by 1931 Ga. Laws 223 (1931 Act), which reduced the monthly pension amount to $ 75. Upon his retirement, the pensioner was paid $ 75 a month. On appeal, the court concluded that the superior court erred in sustaining the Board's demurrers and in dismissing the pensioner's petition. The court found that because the pension plan was not gratuitous, but required employee contribution, the plan created a contract between the City and the pensioner. The court concluded that the pensioner had a right under the contract to a pension in the amount of $ 100 and that the 1931 Act constituted an ex post facto law in violation of Ga. Const. art. I, § III, para. II. The court held that as the pensioner was a party to the contracted created by the 1924 Act, even though he did not retire until after the 1935 Act was adopted, he had a vested right in the $ 100 per month pension.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the superior court's judgment.

 

1386 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


South W. R. Co. v. Benton


No. 16980


Supreme Court of Georgia


206 Ga. 770; 58 S.E.2d 905; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 581



April 10, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Injunction. Before Judge Mallory C. Atkinson. Bibb Superior Court. July 5, 1949.

On March 25, 1947, L. O. Benton Jr., and Charles J. Haden, as stockholders in the South Western Railroad Company (hereinafter referred to as South Western), brought their action in behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, against the company and its named officers and directors, alleging that the South Western was incorporated by an act of the General Assembly of Georgia approved December 27, 1845, which act and the amendments thereto, accepted by it, constitute its charter; that the original charter of the defendant company was several times amended by the General Assembly of Georgia prior to the General Railroad Incorporation Act of 1892; and that each of these amendments was accepted by the defendant company.

It is alleged: that no amendment to its charter made any provision as to the sale of its railroad properties, and its charter is silent with respect thereto; that, therefore, the right to sell the entire properties of the company is governed by the general law as it existed at the time of the granting of the charter and the amendments; and that under the general law a majority [***2] of the stockholders are not empowered to sell the properties of the company.

It is further alleged: that the company is a prosperous, going corporation, able to achieve the objects of its incorporation, and neither its officers nor a majority of its stockholders have a right to sell its corporate property or so much thereof as may prevent the continuance of its business as a corporation and the carrying out of the purposes of its formation; that the present capital stock of the defendant company is $ 5,191,100, all of which is represented by common stock; that its properties are free from mortgages or other liens; that it owes no bonded indebtedness; that its current indebtedness on December 31, 1946, was $ 212,610.33, most of which has now been paid, and its current liabilities are less than $ 100,000; that the capital stock is represented by 51,191 shares, and that 50,471 of these shares are outstanding in the hands of the public; that, according to the report of the Board of Directors submitted to the 100th annual convention of stockholders held in Macon, Georgia, on March 13, 1947, its road and equipment property are worth $ 9,523,736.81, and its common stock has a book value [***3] in excess of $ 180 per share based on fixed assets alone; that in 1942 the Interstate Commerce Commission valued the road and equipment property at $ 12,830,257, and, according to this valuation, its common stock would have a value, based on fixed assets alone, of approximately $ 240 per share.

It is further alleged that the South Western Company comprises some 340 miles of railroad, bridges, depots, and appurtenances thereto, in the heart of the system of the Central of Georgia Railway; and the petition describes the various railroad lines and branches of the company.

It is further alleged: that, on December 19, 1932, the South Western was being operated by the Central of Georgia Railway Company under a long-term lease, which produced to the South Western a rental sufficient to pay stockholders an annual dividend of five percent, the annual rental being $ 259,550 and taxes and organization expenses; that on that date, in a stated case in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Georgia, a receiver of the property and assets of the Central of Georgia Railway Company was appointed, who continued to operate the properties of the Central and of the South Western,  [***4] under lease, until June 19, 1940, at which time the Central filed its petition in the District Court of the United States for the Southern District of Georgia, stating that it was unable to meet its debts as they matured, and that it desired to file a plan of reorganization under the provisions of § 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, and thereafter, in conformity with the act, certain persons were appointed trustees; that the trustees thereafter continued to operate the business of that company, subject to the control of the District Court and the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission until Merrel P. Callaway was appointed and confirmed as sole trustee on April 20, 1942; that he has since acted as sole trustee of the Central, and as such has continued to operate the lines of the South Western under lease; that on October 21, 1943, he adopted for the duration of the bankruptcy the South Western lease; that on January 28, 1944, the trustee filed his plan of reorganization with the United States District Court and with the Interstate Commerce Commission, pursuant to the Bankruptcy Act; that, with respect to the South Western, the plan provided: "Prior to or upon consummation [***5] of the plan, the debtor [Central of Georgia Railway Company] shall also acquire, if they can be acquired on the terms hereinafter set forth, properties at present leased to the debtor by the South Western Railroad . . . If any of these properties shall not be acquired as a result of the acceptance of the plan by the leased-line security holders, then and in that event the lease or leases of any line or lines not so acquired shall be disaffirmed as of such time at or prior to the consummation of the plan as the court may direct. The method of acquisition, whether through purchase, merger, or consolidation, shall, subject to the approval of the commission and the court, be determined by the trustee or by the reorganization managers when they begin to function. If the leased lines are acquired, the railroads of each of the three and the personal property appurtenant thereto and all the real estate owned by each lessor shall be conveyed to the reorganized company; each of said lessors shall waive any damages to which it has become or shall become entitled on account of any breach of lease; and the South Western Railroad Company shall waive all claims in respect to equipment. Such [***6] conveyances and waivers shall in each instance be the sole consideration of the delivery to each of the respective lessors of the securities proposed to be allocated to it as hereinafter specified."

It is further alleged: that the securities proposed to be allocated to the holders of the capital stock of the South Western were provided for in the plan as follows: "Holders of South Western Railroad capital stock would receive, for each $ 1000 of stock $ 423.80 in new first-mortgage Series A bonds, and $ 340.97 in new income mortgage Series A [B] bonds" of the proposed reorganized company; that the proposed new first-mortgage bonds would be secured by the first lien, subject as to equipment to the liens of equipment obligations, on all railroads owned by the reorganized company on consummation of the plan, including leaseholds and capital stocks of terminal companies, and also be a similar lien on the stock of the Ocean Steamship Company and certain other securities and property, and the mortgage securing them would contain an appropriate after-acquired-property clause; that the new income mortgage bonds would be secured by a lien, subject to the lien of the first mortgage bond, upon [***7] all property from time to time subject to the lien of the mortgage; that there would be presently issued, under the plan, $ 14,000,000 of Series A first-mortgage bonds, and $ 16,000,000 of Series B income mortgage bonds; that, of the first-mortgage bonds of the proposed new corporation, there would be issued to South Western approximately $ 2,100,000 thereof, and of the income bonds approximately $ 1,700,000, a total of approximately $ 3,700,000 [$ 3,800,000] of bonds for property worth in excess of $ 9,500,000.

It is further alleged that, almost immediately after the publication of this plan, the stockholders of South Western met in annual meeting at Macon, Georgia, on March 9, 1944, and passed a resolution to the effect "that the terms of the purchases proposed by the trustee are hereby declared to be grossly unfair and inadequate to South Western Railroad and are hereby unhesitatingly rejected," at which meeting there were represented 27,286 shares of the outstanding capital stock of South Western, all voting unanimously for the adoption of the resolution with the exception of one stockholder who owned 100 shares of stock, which position of the stockholders was reaffirmed at [***8] the next annual meeting held on March 8, 1945.

It is further alleged that the plan of reorganization was approved by the District Court on June 25, 1946, and other allegations are made in the petition with reference to subsequent meetings of directors and stockholders, and other actions taken respecting the offer, which we do not deem it necessary to set out in specific detail.

It is further alleged that, on March 13, 1947, despite the previous rejection of the plan by the directors and stockholders of South Western, the directors approved the plan, subject to the assent of said acceptance by the holders of a majority of the stock of South Western, and proposed to submit its acceptance to a meeting of the stockholders to be held on March 28, 1947, a letter being sent on March 14, 1947, by the President of South Western to the stockholders, notifying them to this effect.

It is alleged that in this letter the president stated: "Under the laws of Georgia, the assent of a majority of our stockholders is required to a sale or lease of our railroad properties. Should the stockholders, desire to accept the offer to purchase the physical properties of our company contained in the plan [***9] of reorganization, such acceptance must be authorized by a vote of a majority of the stockholders."

It is further alleged that in his reference to the laws of Georgia, the President of South Western was referring to §§ 94-328 and 94-329 of the Georgia Code of 1933, copies of which sections are attached to the petition as Exhibit "B"; and it is alleged that these sections are not applicable to the South Western for the reason, among others, that "The sections were not intended by the General Assembly of Georgia to apply to the South Western Railroad Company; were not intended by the legislature to amend the charter of the South Western Railroad Company; and, if so intended, have not been accepted as a part of the charter by the stockholders of the South Western Railroad Company."

It is further alleged that, if the said Code §§ 94-328 and 94-329 should be construed by the court to be applicable to the present situation of the South Western, and the previous actions by its directors, they could not regulate and govern a sale of the properties of South Western, as they would be unconstitutional and void as being in violation of article I, section X, paragraph I of the Constitution of [***10] the United States (Code § 1-134), which provides: "No State shall . . pass any . . law impairing the obligation of contracts," and of article I, section III, paragraph II of the Constitution of the State of Georgia (Code, Ann., § 2-302), which provides: "No . . law impairing the obligation of contracts . . shall be passed."

It is further alleged that the charter granted to the South Western by the General Assembly of Georgia, and accepted by it, is a contract between the State of Georgia and the South Western Railroad Company, and its stockholders, the benefits of which inure to the stockholders, including the plaintiffs, and the obligation of which cannot be impaired by the sections of the Code above referred to, or any other act of the General Assembly.

The plaintiffs pray: (a) For process; (b) that the defendant officers and directors of the South Western Railroad Company be restrained and enjoined from holding a stockholders' meeting on March 28, 1947, and from submitting to such meeting the proposed plan to sell the railroad properties of the South Western Railroad Company; (c) that, if the court should not restrain and enjoin the holding of the stockholders' meeting, as herein [***11] prayed, and if at that meeting a mere majority of the stockholders should vote in favor of the acceptance of the plan and the resulting sale of all the railroad properties of the defendant corporation, the officers and directors of the defendant company be restrained and enjoined from carrying such action of the stockholders into effect; and specifically that the officers and directors be restrained and enjoined from filing with the District Court of the United States for the Southern District of Georgia, or with the Interstate Commerce Commission, any acceptance of the plan, and that the officers and directors of the defendant company be specifically restrained and enjoined from selling to the reorganized company, or to any one else, or any other company, all the defendant company's railroad properties, rights, and franchises, and be specifically restrained and enjoined from executing any written instrument which might convey the fee-simple title to the property just mentioned unto the reorganized company or any other company; and be specifically restrained and enjoined from doing and performing any act in behalf of the South Western Railroad Company which might tend to consummate [***12] the plan of reorganization of Central of Georgia Railway Company with respect to the acquisition of the properties of the South Western Railroad Company; and (d) for such other and further relief as to the court may seem meet and proper.

Subsequently this petition was amended by striking Charles J. Haden as party plaintiff at his request, and certain other persons, to wit, Dr. W. G. Lee, I. L. Domingos, Gordon S. Chapman, J. P. Illges Jr., and Charles Loridans, were permitted to intervene as parties plaintiff.

To this petition the defendants filed an answer, in which they admitted certain allegations and denied others. It was admitted that the South Western was chartered by the act of the General Assembly of 1845, as alleged in the petition, and it was alleged that this charter had several times been amended, and that these amendments had been accepted by the company; and that, in its original charter as so amended, there is no provision with respect to the sale of its railroad properties. But the defendants deny that the right to sell the entire physical property of the company is governed by the general law as it existed at the time of the grant of its original charter and the [***13] amendments thereto; and say, on the contrary, that the right to sell its physical properties is expressly authorized by the act of the General Assembly of Georgia of 1933 (Code, §§ 94-328, 94-329) upon the assent to said sale by a majority of its stockholders. The answer makes further allegations with reference to the act of the board of directors in recommending to the stockholders the acceptance of the offer under the plan of reorganization because of the limits of time fixed by the Interstate Commerce Commission within which the South Western must vote to either accept or reject the plan, under the penalty of being deprived of its right to either accept or reject the plan, and the reasons why the board of directors had changed its position and recommended acceptance. The defendants deny that the charter of the South Western and the amendments thereto constitute such a contract between the South Western and its stockholders as to require the unanimous vote of the stockholders to effect a sale of its properties.

It is alleged by the defendants' answer that, when Central of Georgia Railway Company, successor in title to Central Railroad & Banking Company of Georgia, went into receivership [***14] in December, 1932, it was then operating under lease three different railroads, naming them, including the South Western; that the General Assembly of Georgia -- knowing that, under the general railroad laws of this State as they existed at the time of the receivership of the Central in December, 1932, the leased lines of the Central could not lease or sell their properties by reason of the fact that the General Railroad Law, as codified in §§ 94-303 and 94-318 of the Code, did not apply to them -- passed an act in 1933, codified as § 94-328 of the Code, authorizing any railroad corporation organized under the laws of Georgia, which had theretofore leased its properties for a long term of years to another corporation, which lease had terminated and the lessor was not a going concern or equipped to continue the operation of a railroad company, to sell or lease its properties, rights, and franchises to another railroad company upon such terms as may be agreed upon by the board of directors of the selling or lessor corporation and assented to by the holders of a majority of its stock; that the act of 1933 was not forced upon the South Western against its will or the will of its stockholders,  [***15] and in no sense impaired the obligation of the contract between South Western and the State of Georgia; that, on the contrary, this act was adopted by the General Assembly for the benefit of all leased lines in this State coming within the provisions of the act; and that South Western came within its provisions. This answer was filed on April 19, 1947.

On April 24, 1947, and after the issuance by the District Court of the United States for the Southern District of Georgia of an injunctive process enjoining the petitioners from prosecuting their action in the State courts, the trial court granted a temporary injunction restraining the defendants as prayed.

To this order and judgment the defendants duly excepted pendente lite, and error is assigned thereon in the main bill of exceptions.

Subsequently, Central of Georgia Railway Company and Merrel P. Callaway, as trustee of its property, filed their intervention by permission of the court, subject to demurrer, and alleged that the plan of reorganization of the Central as promulgated by the Interstate Commerce Commission was approved by the United States District Court on June 24, 1946, and by order of the United States District Court [***16] it was provided that the plan of reorganization be consummated at a stated hour on July 1, 1948; and that the plan was so consummated. This intervention set out certain provisions of the plan of reorganization with reference to the acquisition of the properties of the South Western. It was alleged: that the South Western not only had power to sell its property, rights, and franchises to another railroad corporation, upon such terms as may be agreed upon by the board of directors, and assented to by holders of a majority of its stock under the provisions of the act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved March 10, 1933 (Code §§ 94-328, 94-329), but also under the General Railroad Law of 1892 (Code §§ 94-311, 94-318); that at common law a private corporation has power to sell its property in order to liquidate the business, on the vote of a majority of its stock; and that the legislature having sanctioned a sale of the property of South Western, it has the same power to sell as a private corporation. It is alleged that the Code sections referred to do not in any sense impair the obligation of the contract between the stockholders of the South Western; that, even if these Code [***17] sections, which are general laws of the State and do not impair any vested right of the stockholders of the South Western, should be held to be amendments of the charter, they are not fundamental and do not affect the object or purposes for which the corporation was created, and do not affect any rights of stockholders.

The intervention makes various other allegations with reference to the condition of South Western, its alleged inability to operate as a railroad company, the cost of equipping it to operate as such; and alleges that, in the exigencies which confront the South Western, it would have the power to sell its property on a majority vote of its stockholders, even though it had no express power in its charter to sell, especially in view of the fact that the State, by the Code sections above referred to, has evidenced its consent to the sale upon a vote of a majority of the stock of the company.

The intervenors prayed: that the court decree that South Western has power to accept the offer made to it in the plan of reorganization of Central, by a vote of a majority of its stock, that the acceptance by South Western on such vote is valid and binding, and that South Western [***18] may convey its property to Central in consummation of its acceptance; and that the court decree, in the exigencies in which South Western finds itself, that it has power to convey its property to Central on a vote of the majority of the stock; and for general relief.

Subsequently, both South Western and its officers and Central and its trustee amended their answer and intervention, respectively, making the allegations and seeking the relief referred to in the second division of the opinion.

There are other allegations in the amendments to the plaintiffs' petition to the effect that, even if a sale could be authorized by a majority vote of stockholders, the transaction here involved does not amount to a sale, but it is a mere exchange of properties, which is not authorized by the charter of South Western or by the Code sections relied upon by the defendants and intervenors; and that, even if the transaction be declared a sale, the consideration therefor is grossly inadequate.

There were also other amendments to the answer and intervention, in which it was alleged that the question of adequacy of consideration was res adjudicata under the decisions of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals [***19] and of the United State Supreme Court in the litigation between these parties in those courts; but, in the view we take of the case, we do not deem it necessary to set out in detail these contentions of the parties as contained in their pleadings.

To the plaintiffs' petition the defendants and intervenors interposed various general and special demurrers, all of which were overruled by the trial court.

To the answer and the intervention as amended the plaintiffs interposed many general and special demurrers, the general demurrers being to the effect that neither the answer nor the intervention as amended set up any defenses to the plaintiffs' petition. These demurrers were sustained, and a final decree was entered on the pleadings as follows:

"(1) It appears to the court that Dr. W. G. Lee, I. L. Domingos, Gordon S. Chapman, J. P. Illges Jr., and Charles Loridans, individually, and as members of the Stockholders Protective Committee of the South Western Railroad Company have intervened herein as parties plaintiff, and that Charles J. Haden has been stricken as a party plaintiff.

"(2) The plaintiff and plaintiffs-intervenors have moved the court for a judgment or decree in their [***20] favor on the pleadings in the cause. It is now considered, adjudged, and decreed:

"(a) That the said motion be granted, and the defendants enjoined as prayed;

"(b) That the officers and directors of South Western Railroad Company be permanently enjoined from carrying into effect the action of the stockholders of South Western Railroad Company taken at the meeting of March 28, 1947;

"(c) That the officers and directors of South Western Railroad Company be permanently enjoined from transferring or conveying to the reorganized Central of Georgia Railway Company, or to anyone else, or any other company, all the defendant company's railroad properties, rights, and franchises based on the aforesaid action of the stockholders;

"(d) That the officers and directors of the defendant company be permanently enjoined from executing any written instrument which might convey the fee-simple title to the properties just mentioned unto the reorganized company, or any other company, based on a mere majority vote of the stockholders of the defendant company;

"(e) That the officers and directors of the defendant company be permanently enjoined from doing and performing any act in behalf of South [***21] Western Railroad Company which might tend to consummate the plan of reorganization of Central of Georgia Railway Company with respect to the acquisition of the properties of the South Western Railroad Company.

"It is further considered, ordered, adjudged, and decreed that the costs of this proceeding, to be taxed by the Clerk, be assessed against the defendants herein."

To the judgments on the demurrers proper exceptions pendente lite were filed by both the defendants and the intervenors, and error is assigned thereon in the main bill of exceptions, and exception is also taken to the final decree. We do not deem it necessary to set out in detail the various grounds of demurrer which are not ruled upon because of the direction given to the case in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, railway corporation, officers, and directors, appealed the judgment of the trial court (Georgia), which granted an injunction in favor of plaintiff stockholders, holding that the railway corporation's charter contained no authority for the corporation to sell its property without the full consent of the stockholders.


OVERVIEW: The stockholders brought an action against the railway corporation and its officers and directors, seeking to prevent the sale and reorganization of the corporation. The stockholders contended that a majority of the stockholders were not empowered to sell the properties of the railway corporation because the railway corporation's charter was silent, and the general law at the time of the railway corporation's incorporation required an unanimous consent of the stockholders. The charter of the railway corporation was granted by the state under the Georgia Code of 1863 and was limited. After several legislative amendments, the charter contained no specific authority to sell its franchise or property. The court held that the powers of a corporation organized under a legislative charter were only such as the statute conferred. The U.S. Const. art. I, § 10 and the Ga. Const. art. I, § 3, para. 2 provided that no state could pass any law impairing the obligation of contracts. Thus, the court concluded that the stockholders had a right to stand on their contract. The stockholders could not be forced into an enterprise that was not included in the charter.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's intervention to enjoin the railway corporation and its officers and directors from selling the corporation's property without the full consent of the stockholders or legislative mandate.

 

1387 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Davis v. Atlanta


No. 16998


Supreme Court of Georgia


206 Ga. 652; 58 S.E.2d 140; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 532



March 14, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for injunction. Before Judge Pharr. Fulton Superior Court. December 3, 1949.

STATEMENT OF FACTS BY DUCKWORTH, CHIEF JUSTICE.

The City of Atlanta having levied ad valorem taxes on the property of certain wholesale produce dealers doing business at the Georgia State Farmers Market, an equitable petition was brought by them to enjoin the collection of such taxes. The petition alleges: that the business and assets of the businesses above are carried on, in, and upon the State Market as a part of the operation of the same, which is created and operated by the State of Georgia through its Commissioner of Agriculture; that the petitioners have subjected themselves to the rules and regulations of the Commissioner, and are a necessary part, adjunct, and parcel of the market; that without them there would be no State Market; that the Market is an agency or branch of the State performing governmental functions; that the State retains complete control over the Market, and the municipality has no right to impair the functions by taxation; and that, in order to avoid a multiplicity of civil actions, criminal prosecutions, and the petitioners having no adequate remedy at law, a [***2] permanent injunction be granted.

General demurrers were filed, to the effect that no cause of action was set forth, that there was an adequate remedy at law, and that the taxes levied are valid and legal. After a hearing an order sustaining the demurrers and dismissing the petition was filed. The exceptions here are to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers appealed a judgment by the Fulton Superior Court (Georgia), which ruled in favor of defendant city in the taxpayers' claim to enjoin the city from the collection of ad valorem taxes on the property of certain wholesale produce dealers doing business at the state farmers' market.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers' petition alleged that the business and assets of the businesses were carried on, in, and upon the farmers' market as a part of the operation of the State, which was created and operated by the State through its Commissioner of Agriculture. The taxpayers claimed that the State retained complete control over the market, and the city had no right to impair the functions by taxation. Upon review from a judgment in favor of the State, the court held that the fact that privately owned property was devoted exclusively to a public use did not make it public property so as to exempt it from municipal ad valorem taxation. The court stated that private property could not be converted into public property by the simple declaration of the Georgia General Assembly.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1388 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Glustrom v. State


No. 16960


Supreme Court of Georgia


206 Ga. 734; 58 S.E.2d 534; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 564



February 14, 1950, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied March 30, 1950.


PRIOR HISTORY: Certiorari. Before Judge Pharr. Fulton Superior Court. October 31, 1949.

Johnny Glustrom was charged in the Criminal Court of Fulton County "with the offense of misdemeanor, for that the said Johnny Glustrom in the county aforesaid on the 17th day of April, 1949 did transport distilled spirits in violation of regulation 602 of the Commissioner of Revenue of the State of Georgia." Regulation 602 is set out in the accusation in full. In so far as material in the present case, the regulation provides: "A wholesaler or a retailer shall transport distilled spirits only in a motor vehicle registered in his name with the Commissioner and bearing his name, all his license numbers under the Act, and the addresses of all his places thereof in prominent letters in the English language, and only between sun-up and sun-down on a week-day, and only if each such shipment is accompanied by an invoice or itemized list thereof showing in detail the number of cases, the size of containers, type, brand and price of the distilled spirits included in such shipment, and the point of origin and the point of destination thereof."

It is alleged in the accusation [***2] that "the said Johnny Glustrom, a licensed retail liquor dealer, being licensed to sell distilled spirits under a license issued by the Commissioner of Revenue of the State of Georgia pursuant to an Act known as the Revenue Tax Act to legalize and control alcoholic beverages and liquors and the rules and regulations promulgated under the provisions of said Act, did transport 2 cases of whisky [containing 24 bottles of named brands of whisky]. Said distilled spirits were transported by Johnny Glustrom, a retailer, in a motor vehicle which was not registered in his name and with the Commissioner, and bearing his name, or his license number under the Act, and addresses of all his places of business were not painted prominently and displayed on at least two sides thereof in prominent letters of the English language, and said shipment was not accompanied by an invoice or itemized listing thereof showing in detail the number of cases, size of containers, type, brand and price of distilled spirits included in such shipment, and the point of origin, and the point of destination thereof, all are required by said regulation."

The defendant demurred to the accusation on the ground that there [***3] is no valid law in the State making it a misdemeanor to violate Rule 602, promulgated by the State Revenue Commissioner. It is contended that the only statute purporting to make the violation of such rules a misdemeanor is section 20 of the act known as the "Revenue Tax Act to Legalize and Control Alcoholic Beverages and Liquors" (Ga. L. 1937-38, pp. 103, 121, Code, Ann. Supp., § 58-1069). It is insisted that, in so far as such act seeks to make a violation of the rules of the State Revenue Commissioner a misdemeanor, the act is unconstitutional and void, being an unlawful, unwarranted, and unconstitutional attempt on the part of the General Assembly to delegate to an administrative official authority to define a crime, in violation of the following provisions of the Constitution of 1945: "The legislative, judicial and executive powers shall forever remain separate and distinct, and no person discharging the duties of one, shall, at the same time, exercise the functions of either of the others, except as herein provided." Art. 1, sec. 1, par. 23 (Code, Ann., § 2-123). "The legislative power of the State shall be vested in a General Assembly which shall consist of a Senate and [***4] House of Representatives." Art. 3, sec. 1, par. 1 (Code, Ann., § 2-1301. "No person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property, except by due process of law." Art. 1, sec. 1, par. 3 (Code, Ann., § 2-103). The section is further attacked as being in conflict with the 14th Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. It is further contended that the section is unconstitutional, in that it fails to fix or establish any standard, or define any limits, within which the commissioner must act in promulgating rules.

The defendant's demurrer was overruled, and he was found guilty. He was sentenced to pay a fine of $ 500, including costs, and sentenced to serve twelve months on the public works, the sentence for service on the public works to be suspended on payment of the fine. His petition for certiorari to the Superior Court of Fulton County was sanctioned and, upon hearing, was overruled. The exception is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the denial of his petition for certiorari from the Superior Court, Fulton County (Georgia) following his conviction of a misdemeanor for violating a rule promulgated by the State Revenue Commission pursuant to the Revenue Tax Act to Legalize and Control Alcoholic Beverages and Liquors.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged and convicted in criminal court with the offense of misdemeanor, for transporting distilled spirits in violation of Ga. Comm. Rev. Reg. 602. His petition for certiorari was overruled and defendant appealed. In reversing, the court held that the accusation charging a violation of Reg. 602 did not charge defendant with a crime under the constitution or laws of Georgia; therefore, defendant's demurrer should have been sustained. The court noted that the power to adopt rules and regulations, administrative in character and for policing of a particular business authorized by law, was not to be confused with the power to enact a criminal statute.


OUTCOME: The judgment denying defendant's petition for certiorari following his conviction of a misdemeanor for violation of a rule promulgated by the State Revenue Commissioner was reversed.

 

1389 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Capitol Distributing Co. v. Redwine


Nos. 16887, 16901


Supreme Court of Georgia


206 Ga. 477; 57 S.E.2d 578; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 494



January 12, 1950, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied February 17, 24, 1950.


PRIOR HISTORY: Petition for injunction. Before Judge Byars. Fayette Superior Court. August 26, 1949.

Capitol Distributing Company and numerous others, as plaintiffs, brought their equitable petition against Charles D. Redwine, alleging that he is Revenue Commissioner of Georgia and a resident of Fayette County. It seeks to enjoin him from making further threats and attempts to levy and collect taxes under an act of the General Assembly, approved July 30, 1949, asserted to be unconstitutional on grounds and as to provisions which will be more particularly pointed out in the opinion.

The original petition was demurred to by the defendant on grounds as follows: that no facts were set out such as would constitute a cause of action or would warrant the equitable relief prayed or other equitable relief; and that there was no equity in the bill, because the facts show that the plaintiffs have a plain, adequate, and complete remedy at law. Under three separate amendments the plaintiffs amplified the allegations of the petition. The third amendment, among other things, added three exhibits and amended paragraph 14 of the petition to read as follows:  [***2] "The said 1949 amendment to the wine laws was added to House Bill Number 1, of the 1949 Extraordinary Session of the legislature, as an amendment thereto, by adding an additional paragraph numbered 2A, which contained the amendment to the wine laws, in which form the bill was read, voted on, and passed. Said act, as read before the legislature and voted on by said legislature, differs from the act approved and signed by the Governor, in that the words 'to increase the excise taxes upon the domestic wines, foreign wines, and domestic and foreign fortified wines' before the final words, 'and for other purposes,' were not in the caption while the act was before the legislature. Photostatic copies of the original act and its caption and pertinent amendments thereto, certified by the Secretary of State and designated Exhibits 'D', 'E', and 'F', are attached to the petition and hereby made a part of this paragraph by reference."

The defendant renewed his demurrers to the original petition and urged additional demurrers to paragraph 14 as amended and the three said exhibits, for the reason that it contains only matter which is surplusage, irrelevant, immaterial, and illustrates no issue;  [***3] and that the facts and things set out by way of amendment to paragraph 14 and exhibits "D", "E", and "F" may not properly be proven by evidence, as it must be conclusively presumed that the bill as transmitted to the Governor, approved by him, and enrolled by the Secretary of State truly represents the action of the legislature.

After hearing argument on the demurrers to paragraph 14 as amended, including the three named exhibits attached and referred to, the presiding judge entered the following order: "After hearing, it is ordered that the foregoing special demurrer be and the same is hereby overruled." The defendant thereupon filed exceptions pendente lite, and the same are the subject of the cross-bill in case No. 16901. The general demurrers to the petition as amended were sustained and the suit was dismissed. On exceptions to that order and judgment the main case, number 16887, is now before this court. Attached to the original petition is a copy of the act in dispute, which reads: "1949 Extra Session: Act No. 1 (House Bill No. 1). An Act To amend an Act approved March 23, 1935, entitled 'An Act to provide for license and excise taxes upon the business of dealing in malt [***4] beverages; to allocate funds derived from such taxes; to provide for the enforcement of this Act; to repeal laws in conflict with this Act; to provide for the holding of an election to ratify or reject this Act; and for other purposes,' as amended by the Act approved March 30, 1937, appearing in printed Georgia Laws 1937, pages 148 to 154 inclusive, and as further amended by Act approved December 13, 1937, appearing in Georgia Laws, Extra Session 1937-1938, pages 173 and 174, and as further amended by Act approved March 24, 1939, appearing in Georgia Laws 1939, pages 101 to 103 inclusive, by striking the figures '$ 4.50' in line three, section five, as amended by the Act approved March 24, 1939, and inserting in lieu thereof the figures '$ 9.00', and by striking the word 'two' in line twelve, said section as amended, and inserting in lieu thereof the word 'four'; providing the period for which this amendment shall remain in force; to increase the excise taxes upon domestic wines, foreign wines, and domestic and foreign fortified wines, and for other purposes.

"Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same: Section [***5] 1. That the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved on the 23rd day of March, 1935 entitled 'An Act to Provide for License and Excise Taxes upon the business of Dealing in Malt Beverages,' etc., appearing in printed Georgia Laws of 1935, pages 73 to 81 inclusive, as amended by the Act approved March 30, 1937, appearing in printed Georgia Laws of 1937, pages 148 to 154 inclusive, and as further amended by Act approved December 13, 1937, appearing in Georgia Laws, Extra Session 1937-1938, pages 173 and 174; and as further amended by Act approved March 24, 1939, appearing in Georgia Laws 1939, pages 101 to 103 inclusive, be and the same is hereby amended by striking the figures '$ 4.50' in line three, section five, as amended by the Act approved March 24, 1939, and inserting in lieu thereof the figures '$ 9.00', and by striking the word 'two' in line twelve, said section as amended, and inserting in lieu thereof the word 'four,' so that said section as amended will read as follows:

"'Section 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that there is hereby imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages an excise tax in the sum of $ 9.00 for each container sold as [***6] hereinafter specified, containing not more than 31 gallons, and at a like rate for fractional parts, where the beverage is sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, such beverages being commonly known as tap or draft beer, and where the beverage is sold in bottles, cans or other containers, and not sold in or from a barrel or bulk container as above specified, there is hereby imposed upon the business of selling for each twelve ounces or proportionally thereof, so as to graduate the tax on bottles or cans of various sizes, Provided, there shall be no excise tax on sales of malt beverages sold to persons outside of this State for resale or consumption outside of this State, nor upon sales of malt beverages sold to stores or canteens located on United Army Posts or Reservations. There shall be paid by every brewer, wholesale dealer and retail dealer the following annual State License Tax or Registration Fees: For brewers $ 1,000.00, For wholesale dealers $ 500.00, For retail dealers $ 10.00. Said fees shall be paid on each place of business operated and shall be paid to the State Revenue Commissioner when such brewer, wholesale dealer or retail dealer enters business, and annually [***7] thereafter, so long as such business is operated and conducted.'

"Section 2. Be it further enacted that this Act shall continue in force until the 30th day of June, 1951, but that after that date the licenses, and taxes as imposed in an Act approved March 23, 1935, entitled 'An Act to provide a license and excise taxes upon the business of dealers in malt beverages; to allocate funds derived from such taxes and so on' as appears in Georgia Laws of 1935, on pages 73 to 81 inclusive, as amended by the Act approved March 30, 1937, as appears in the printed Georgia Laws of 1937, pages 158 to 164 inclusive; as amended in the printed Georgia Laws of 1937-1938, pages 173 and 174, inclusive, as amended in the printed Georgia Laws 1939, pages 101 to 103 inclusive, shall again become effective and shall thereafter remain in full force and effect until altered or repealed by the General Assembly. It shall be the duty of the State Revenue Commissioner to make diligent inquiry into such application for a license or permit to carry on the business described in this Act, and to refuse to grant a retail license or permit to any applicant who is not registered voter of Georgia; or to persons of [***8] bad character; or for other good and sufficient causes as the said Commissioner may deem proper for the best interests of this State. A retail license or permit as provided for herein may be granted only to the actual owner of such business, giving preference whenever possible and practicable to those applicants who are veterans of any of the wars of the United States of America.

"Section 2-a. That an Act approved March 30, 1937, Ga. Laws 1937, page 851, which Act related to the manufacture, sale and taxes of wine, as amended by an Act approved February 6, 1938, Ga. Laws, Ex. Sess. 1937-38, page 185, and as further amended by an Act approved March 27, 1941, Ga. Laws 1941, page 234, is hereby amended by striking in its entirety Section 3 of the said Act of 1937 and substituting in lieu thereof a new section to be numbered Section 3 which shall read as follows: Section 3. The following taxes shall be levied and collected on all wines manufactured, sold, possessed, or offered for sale within the State: (a) on domestic wines having an alcoholic strength of not more than 14 percents alcohol by volume -- ten cents per gallon. Domestic wines are hereby defined and declared to be those [***9] wines manufactured wholly within this State and of fruits and berries grown only within the State of Georgia and produced by natural fermentation. (b) On Foreign wines having an alcoholic strength of not more than 14 percents by volume -- one dollar per gallon. Foreign wines are hereby defined and declared to be wines which are imported in whole or in part in the State of Georgia, or manufactured in the State of Georgia from products imported in whole or in part from without the State of Georgia and produced by natural fermentation. (c) On foreign and domestic wines whether fortified or not having an alcoholic strength of more than 14 percents by volume -- two dollars per gallon.

"Section 3. In the event any part of this Act shall be held unconstitutional it shall not invalidate the remainder thereof.

"Section 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

(s) Fred Hand

Speaker of the House.

(s) Joe Boone

Clerk of the House.

(s) Marvin Griffin

President of Senate.

(s) George D. Stewart

Secretary of Senate.

Approved: (s) Herman E. Talmadge

Governor."



DISPOSITION: Judgment  [***10] affirmed on the main bill of exceptions. Cross-bill of exceptions dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers appealed a judgment from the Fayette Superior Court (Georgia), which was entered in favor of defendant Revenue Commissioner and sustained the Commissioner's demurrer to the taxpayer's equitable petition against the Commissioner, seeking to enjoin him from making further threats and attempts to levy and collect taxes under an act of the General Assembly asserted to be unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers contended that there were irregularities during the process of the legislation such as to controvert any valid reference to wines in the title. Specifically, the taxpayers contended that the regulation, control, and taxation of malt beverages was a separate subject-matter from that of wines. On appeal, the court found that the act did not contain a dual subject-matter within the meaning of the constitutional provision that no act should contain more than one subject. The court could not consider the grounds of discrimination and unconstitutionality, which were raised by the taxpayers. The court concluded that there was no error in sustaining the general demurrers, which attacked the taxpayer's petition as amended on grounds that no cause of action was set out, nor did the taxpayer's allegations warrant the granting of the equitable relief prayed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment on the main bill of exceptions and dismissed the cross-bill of exceptions.

 

1390 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Redwine v. Southern Co.


No. 16885


Supreme Court of Georgia


206 Ga. 377; 57 S.E.2d 194; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 345



January 12, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Declaratory judgment -- construction of Constitution. Before Judge Hooper. Fulton Superior Court. August 13, 1949.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff in error Georgia State Revenue Commissioner appealed a judgment by the Superior Court of Fulton County (Georgia), which ruled in favor of defendant in error domesticated foreign corporation in its action to obtain a declaratory judgment that its stock was exempt from Georgia ad valorem taxes.


OVERVIEW: The corporation sought a declaration that its stock was exempt from Georgia ad valorem taxation pursuant to Ga. Const. art. 7, § 1 and O.C.G.A. §§ 92-130, 2-5404. The court affirmed the superior court's judgment in the corporation's favor and found that the corporation, as a domesticated foreign corporation, was entitled to the same exemption that a domestic corporation enjoyed under those constitutional and statutory provisions. As a domesticated foreign corporation, the corporation effectively was a resident of Georgia, was entitled to equal protection pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 2-102, and was entitled under O.C.G.A. § 2-5403 to be taxed in the same manner as a similarly situated domestic corporation. The court rejected the Commissioner's argument that the desired exemption was unconstitutional on the ground that it was not enumerated specifically as an exemption. To construe the constitutional exemption as to confine its application to property owned by a domestic corporation, and to deny its application to the same class or species of property when owned by a domesticated foreign corporation would have offended O.C.G.A. §§ 2-5403, 2-102, and U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

1391 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Moultrie Milk Shed, Inc. v. Cairo


No. 16865


Supreme Court of Georgia


206 Ga. 348; 57 S.E.2d 199; 1950 Ga. LEXIS 347



January 12, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for injunction. Before Judge Crow. Grady Superior Court. July 21, 1949.

This is a suit by Moultrie Milk Shed Inc., against the City of Cairo, its Mayor and Council, and the Chief of Police, seeking an injunction to prevent the defendants from enforcing a city ordinance which prohibits the sale of milk within the city limits unless it has been pasteurized in a plant located in Grady County, which is the county in which the City of Cairo is located. The main contention of the petitioner was that the ordinance was void: first, because there had not been conformity with the requirements of the charter in the process of its adoption; and second, because it was arbitrary, discriminatory, unreasonable, and offended the equal-protection clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions.

The petitioner alleged: that the ordinance was not intended as a health measure, and did not by its terms afford protection to the public health, but that its sole purpose and effect was to create a trade barrier for the benefit of a named concern, which has the only pasteurizing plant located in Grady County; that pasteurization and distribution of milk is regulated and controlled by State law,  [***2] with which the petitioner had fully complied; that the petitioner sells only the highest quality of pure, wholesome, and pasteurized milk to all of its customers, many of whom reside in the City of Cairo; that the process of pasteurization is for the purpose of freeing milk from any contamination, and the distance from the pasteurizing plant to the point of consumption is immaterial; that the petitioner's plant and milk are regularly and properly inspected by competent inspectors, and laboratory tests are made by State officials from samples taken by the inspectors and sent to the State laboratory; and that the inspection of all milk in the State is by the above process. It was further alleged: that the city had, after a hearing, canceled the petitioner's license to sell milk in the City of Cairo because it did not have a pasteurizing plant in Grady County as required by the ordinance; that the city authorities had made one criminal case against the petitioner's agent; that the petitioner excepted in due form, is prosecuting a review by certiorari, and has complied with the law in procuring a supersedeas in each case; but the defendants have informed the petitioner that, notwithstanding [***3] such supersedeas, it is their purpose and intention to arrest and prosecute the petitioner and any of its employees and agents who attempt to sell and deliver any milk in the City of Cairo. This allegation is admitted in the answer of the defendants to be true. There were further allegations that, because of such express intention of the defendants, the petitioner is unable to get any employees who are willing to sell or deliver the petitioner's milk within the city; that, as a result thereof, the petitioner is sustaining losses and is threatened with the complete destruction of its business in the City of Cairo; that the petitioner purchases its milk from producers under contracts which require it to take delivery, and unless the petitioner can deliver to its customers in Cairo, it will have a large quantity of milk that it will be unable to dispose of, which will deteriorate and become a total loss.

Upon the interlocutory hearing there was evidence introduced showing the material facts alleged in the petition; these facts were not disputed. At the conclusion of the hearing the presiding judge, in rendering judgment, recited in the order that, in his opinion, the ordinance in [***4] question was unconstitutional and void; but that its validity had been raised in the hearings before the city authorities, where it was held valid, and, since these rulings were being brought under review by the writ of certiorari, which was the proper remedy, that it be ordered and adjudged that the prayer for an interlocutory injunction be denied.

The exception here is to that judgment. Errors are also assigned upon rulings made during the hearing excluding evidence offered by the petitioner which tended to show the motive and purpose of the city council in adopting the ordinance.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff dairy sought review of the decision of the Grady Superior Court (Georgia), which denied the dairy's request for an injunction to prohibit the enforcement by defendant, the City of Cairo, of an ordinance that banned the sale of milk in the city that was processed in any plant outside of the county in which the city was located.


OVERVIEW: The city passed an ordinance that no milk could be sold that was not processed in the county where the city was located. The dairy sought an injunction to prohibit the enforcement of the ordinance. The trial court refused to grant the relief requested by the dairy. On appeal, the court reversed the judgment of the trial court. The court held that it was alleged and admitted that the city threatened prosecution of all employees and agents of the dairy for each and every sale or delivery of milk made within the city. There was also an allegation that, because of this expressed intention, the dairy was unable to secure the necessary employees for the operation of its business. The court held that this evidence amounted to a plain case of injury to property. The court further held that, although a city was given express authority by its charter to adopt ordinances to protect the public health, it could not demand that a company that was engaged in a lawful business injurious to no one be arbitrarily prevented from carrying on a lawful business. The location of the dairy did not have any relationship to the health and safety of the milk it produced. The ordinance was therefore void.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1392 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Copeland v. Leathers


No. 16874


Supreme Court of Georgia


206 Ga. 280; 56 S.E.2d 530; 1949 Ga. LEXIS 455



November 17, 1949, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied December 1, 1949.


PRIOR HISTORY: Injunction. Before Judge Guess. Clayton Superior Court. August 29, 1949.

Roy Leathers, as Solicitor-General of the Stone Mountain Circuit, brought his petition in the Superior Court of Clayton County, Georgia, against J. T. Copeland, alleging in substance: that the defendant is the owner and operator of a certain tourist camp and cabin camp, restaurant and cafe, and dancing place, known as Silver Slipper, located on Highway 42 outside the limits of any city or town in the County of Clayton; that the said place of business is being operated, and business at said place is being carried on by the defendant himself, and through his agents, servants, and employees; that the business engaged in by the defendant is that of renting cabins to guests and other persons for lodging, and serving food and drinks to be consumed upon the premises; that the defendant by himself and through his agents, servants, and employees who have had charge of the register kept at said place for the registering of guests and other persons occupying the cabin camps and tourist camps, have knowingly written or have knowingly permitted to be written incorrect license [***2] numbers of the automobiles transporting such persons and guests as have occupied said tourist camps and cabin camps, and have failed to write or cause to be written the true and correct license number of motor vehicles transporting the guests and other persons to said place for the purpose of occupying said tourist camps and cabin camps; and that the defendant by himself and through his agents, servants, and employees, has knowingly failed to write or cause to be written, in and upon the register kept at said place of business for the registration of guests and other persons occupying said cabins, the true and correct name of the manufacturer of said motor vehicle used in transporting the guests and other persons registering as guests and occupying cabins at said place of business.

The petition prayed: (a) that process issue; (b) that the defendant be served with a copy of the petition and order; (c) that the defendant be temporarily enjoined from conducting and carrying on the business at the place alleged, either by himself or indirectly through his agents, servants, and employees; (d) that a hearing be had; (e) that upon the hearing the defendant be permanently enjoined from conducting [***3] and carrying on the business as alleged; and (f) for other and further relief.

To this petition the defendant filed two demurrers, but the only grounds of demurrer argued and insisted upon by counsel for the plaintiff in error in their briefs are the general grounds numbered 1 in both demurrers and ground 2 of the second demurrer, which grounds were: (1) that the petition sets out no cause of action; (2) the plaintiff's petition fails to set forth a legal cause of action cognizable either in law or equity against the defendant; and (3) that the statute upon which said proceeding and petition is based is unconstitutional and void, for that said statute contains subject-matter different from that which is expressed in the title thereof, in violation of the Constitution of Georgia (Code, Ann., § 2-1908), which provides: "No law shall pass which refers to more than one subject matter, or contains matter different from what is expressed in the title thereof," in that there is nothing in the title to said act with reference to providing penalties other than against persons who operate such establishments for immoral purposes, or who violate other provisions of said act in the operation [***4] of restaurants, cafes, or places where food and/or drinks are sold; that no reference is made in said title to any other penalties, and particularly to the section undertaking to provide for the issuance of an injunction against persons operating an establishment such as is herein attempted.

The trial court overruled the defendant's demurrers, and to this judgment the defendant excepts.

The defendant by his answer admitted that he was the owner and operator of the tourist camp and cabin camp, restaurant and cafe, and dance place, known as Silver Slipper, located on Highway 42 outside the limits of any city or town in the County of Clayton; that the place of business was being operated by the defendant by himself and through his agents, servants, and employees; and that the business engaged in was that of renting cabins to guests and other persons for lodging, and serving food and drinks to be consumed upon the premises. All other allegations of the petition were denied.

On the hearing two members of a former grand jury of Clayton County were sworn as witnesses and testified that they, in company with a named county police officer, went to the place of business of the defendant,  [***5] and secured from him his registration records in the form of cards upon which guests had registered. It was stipulated that these records were secured from the defendant without any subpoena or search warrant, and that, upon demand for his registration record, the cards were delivered to them by the defendant, and that they were the original cards from the place of business of the defendant known as Silver Slipper. The plaintiff solicitor-general testified: that he had 2400 of the cards which were turned over to him by the grand jurors who secured them from the Silver Slipper; that he had examined all of the 2400 cards; that none of them had entered thereon the name of the manufacturer or make of the automobile; and that 225 of the registration cards have no letters thereon from the license plates or tags of the automobiles, but have only numbers thereon, without giving any information as to what initial the tag or license plate bore, and what State the tag or license plate was from. Ten of the cards were admitted in evidence, over the objection of counsel for defendant, the grounds of which objection will be referred to in the opinion. This witness testified that the 10 cards [***6] offered were similar to the 2400 other cards, with the exception that some of them do have a number, but that none of them has the make or name of the manufacturer of the automobile that brought the passengers to the place.

The defendant offered no evidence.

The trial court took the case under consideration and thereafter entered the following order and judgment: "Restraining Order: After consideration it is ordered and adjudged that the restraining orders heretofore granted be, and are, continued in force and effect, and defendants are restrained from operating, renting, selling, or otherwise conducting tourist cabins commercially or for public use."

To the judgment overruling the objections to the admission of the registration cards and admitting them in evidence, and to the judgment granting a restraining order, the defendant also excepted.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed with direction.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff Solicitor-General of the Stone Mountain Circuit petitioned the Superior Court of Clayton County (Georgia) to enjoin defendant business from continuing to operate a tourist and cabin camp because of prior violations of 1945 Ga. Laws 326. The trial court overruled the demurrers of the business. The trial court restrained the business from operating, selling, or otherwise conducting public tourist cabins. The business appealed.


OVERVIEW: The Solicitor-General alleged that the business violated 1945 Ga. Laws 326 by failing to require resort guests to provide correct vehicle identification and license plate numbers. The business alleged that 1945 Ga. Laws 326 violated the Georgia Constitution, O.C.G.A. § 2-1908, that limited a statute to one subject matter. The court held that the 1945 Ga. Laws 326 was constitutional and enforceable. The purpose of the act was the regulation of tourist camps and to provide penalties for violating certain statutory provisions. The business alleged that the trial court erred in admitting guest registrations into evidence that had been supplied to the Solicitor General's office by the business. The court held that the registrations were properly admitted into evidence and substantiated that the business routinely failed to enforce the statutory provisions for a complete registration of the guests and the complete vehicle information for every guest. The court held that the business was bound by the acts of its agents.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment, but directed the trial court to modify the order to eliminate the restraint as to the sale of the property.

 

1393 of 1995 DOCUMENTS


Collins v. State


No. 16818


Supreme Court of Georgia


206 Ga. 95; 55 S.E.2d 599; 1949 Ga. LEXIS 630



October 12, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Intent to defraud. Before Judge Frankum. Stephens Superior Court. July 15, 1949.

Jeff Collins was indicted by the grand jury of Stephens County, Georgia, for an alleged violation of the act of 1941 (Ga. L. 1941, p. 480; Code, Ann. Supp., § 26-2812), which declares that it shall be a felony for any person, with the intent to defraud, to use the proceeds of any payment made to him on account of improving real property, for any other purpose than to pay for labor or service performed on, or materials furnished by his order for the specific improvement, while any amount for which he may be or become liable for such labor, services, or materials remains unpaid. The last sentence of the act is as follows: "A failure to pay for the material or labor so furnished shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud."

The defendant interposed to the indictment a general demurrer, in which he attacked the constitutionality of the act on three grounds: (a) It violates art. 3, sec. 7, par. 8 of the Constitution of Georgia (Code, Ann., § 2-1908), in that it refers to more than one subject-matter, and contains matter different from what is expressed in the title thereof. (b) It violates [***2] art. 1, sec. 1, par. 21, of the Constitution of Georgia (Code, Ann., § 2-121), which declares that "There shall be no imprisonment for debt." (c) It violates the equal-protection and due-process clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States (Code, § 1-815). The demurrer was overruled on every ground, and the exception here is to that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision by the Stephens Superior Court (Georgia), which overruled his demurrer to the indictment charging him with violating O.C.G.A. 26-2812, which declared that it was a felony for any person to convert certain proceeds with the intent to defraud.


OVERVIEW: An indictment charged defendant with violating O.C.G.A. § 26-2812. Defendant filed a demurrer claiming that the statute was unconstitutional. The trial court overruled defendant's demurrer. On appeal, the court affirmed. Defendant claimed that the last sentence of the statute was a different subject matter not included in the title of the statute.
